TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows: the unjust and inequitable nature of the Government's policy to restrict Childcare Assistance where a parent is outside the workforce to 12 hours per week. This policy will cause hardship to lower income families, to the children of those families, and child care workers. The Government should be condemned for breaking its promise to ensure access and affordability in child care.

Under the Government's policy parents will have to pay full cost fees after 12 hours of childcare per week if one parent is outside the workforce. This will widen the gap between rich and poor, and many child care workers may lose their jobs.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Senate should oppose the passage of this Bill into law.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Guide
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.We are opposed to the sex guide endorsed by Ms Lawrence, Minister for Health in the Keating Government, and published in the December issue of Cleo.
2.We believe that the sex guide encourages dangerous sexual practices which could have serious medical and moral effects.

PARA.TAB: We request the Senate to call on Ms Lawrence to withdraw her endorsement of this sex guide and for the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, to indicate his disapproval.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education: Freedom of Choice
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the Citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That we:
(1) Affirm the importance of quality education for all the children of this Commonwealth of Australia irrespective of their religion, nationality or sex;
(2) Support the rights of parents to have freedom of choice of the school for their child;
(3) Support the right of all non-government schools to maintain their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos;
(4) Support the freedom of choice in staffing of all Churches and religious organisations.
(5) Support freedom of religion and the right of all Churches and religious organisations to maintain their distinctive foundational ethos.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate oppose any attempts to introduce legislation that would jeopardise these freedoms and rights and which would force Schools, Churches and religious institutions to compromise their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray:

PETITION.TITLE: Radio Station 2UNE
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
The deficiencies in the current broadcasting licence of Radio Station 2UNE-FM.

Support the extension of the permitted service area for Radio Station 2UNE so that it may broadcast to all students and staff of the University of New England and their families residing in the Armidale district.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS AND OTHER LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Bob Collins) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a replacement explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The main amendments in this bill will change the existing unfair dismissal provisions of the Industrial Relations Act 1988. The handling of cases will become simpler, more effective and less legalistic.

These proposals reflect the outcome of discussions with employer representatives, the ACTU and state governments. The amendments have been widely welcomed by leading business groups, including the ACCI and the MTIA, and have the support of the union movement as part of the latest accord between the government and the ACTU.
The changes will make a good system even better.
The bill will also make minor amendments to other legislation.
Unfair Dismissal Provisions
A number of fundamental minimum entitlements for Australian employees were introduced into the Industrial Relations Act by the Industrial Relations Reform Act 1993.

A key initiative was to ensure that employees are guaranteed a fair level of employment protection. This gives effect to the internationally recognised standards contained in the ILO's Termination of Employment Convention. This step was necessary to address the removal or restriction of protection under the industrial relations agendas of conservative state governments.

The Industrial Relations Act now ensures that employees have a remedy if they are unfairly dismissed. The legislation was not intended to supplant other fair remedies under state laws which met the international standard. Instead it meant that an employee whose protection was inadequate, or who had no remedy at all, could use the federal system.

The legislation has been operating for over 17 months. It has been used by employees to differing degrees in all states and territories. It is the only relevant remedy for dismissed employees in Victoria, which removed any fair protection under the much criticised 1992 Kennett industrial legislation. It is worth noting that 45% of all applications filed under the federal system have been from Victoria. There has also been increasing recourse to the federal system by dismissed employees in New South Wales, which does not cover all employees under its industrial legislation, and in Western Australia.

This has been a new field for federal legislation, which previously only provided remedies where dismissals were discriminatory, leaving the general area of unfair dismissals to state laws. Clearly, by enacting the legislation, the Commonwealth has filled in gaps in employment protection: gaps which had previously existed or which were created by regressive state legislation.
The government has carefully monitored the operation of the legislation, including by consultation with the National Labour Consultative Council and state industrial relations ministers.
As a result of the consultative process, we now propose four changes to the existing provisions.

First, all applications will commence in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Applications now begin in the Industrial Relations Court of Australia, which refers most of them to the commission for conciliation. This first procedural step can be streamlined, with greater emphasis on trying to resolve cases by conciliation first. The court will only become involved if conciliation fails and the parties do not wish to have the matter resolved by voluntary arbitration. The government expects that the great majority of cases will continue to be resolved by negotiation and conciliation.

Ninety-four percent of all cases have been settled through conciliation or mediation, or have been discontinued after negotiation. Two-thirds of these were settled after the commission conciliated. Only six percent of cases have been determined by the court.

Secondly, the act will allow consent arbitration of unfair dismissal claims, when the parties choose this option. The Australian Industrial Relations Commission will conduct the arbitration. The commission's decision will be binding and enforceable by the court. Parties will therefore be able to avoid the need for a hearing in the court, by choosing a less legalistic way of resolving the claim.

The third amendment will clarify when state law provides an acceptable alternative to the federal remedy. The government has always intended that dismissed employees use state remedies, rather than the federal provisions, when the state remedies provide satisfactory protection against unfair dismissals. The existing test of what is an acceptable alternative remedy has two elements. The remedy must be provided under machinery which gives effect to the ILO convention, and the remedy must also be one which the court decides is adequate.

This aspect of the legislation has operated more strictly than anticipated, so that only state laws which virtually replicate the federal legislation could be treated as adequate alternative remedies. Most states have indicated that they are willing to provide protection against unfair dismissal which will meet the requirements of the ILO convention but which may involve a different approach from that taken under the federal laws. This has been accepted by the members of the NLCC as an acceptable approach. Accordingly, under these amendments, if the court is satisfied that an alternative remedy meets the relevant requirements of the ILO convention, no remedy will be available under the unlawful termination provisions of the Industrial Relations Act. It is of course implicit in this new provision that the state law must genuinely conform to the ILO convention if it is to be regarded as satisfying the requirements of that convention.

Under the amendment, a state will be able to give effect to the convention in its own way. Provision will also be made to give greater certainty to a state as to what will be taken to be an adequate alternative remedy. This is in response to requests by some states for such a provision. Accordingly, a state law will be taken to be an adequate alternative remedy where it requires the relevant state tribunal to give effect to the convention and gives it the necessary powers to do so. This does not prevent a state from choosing another suitable approach to meeting the requirements of the convention.

Whichever approach is taken in the state law, it must also provide for the making of late applications by dismissed employees who mistakenly applied for a remedy in the federal system rather than under the relevant state law.

The fourth change is of particular importance. The act will be amended to make it clear that a breach of an employer's obligations will not automatically lead to a remedy. It has been suggested that remedies are given for breaches based only on procedural grounds without regard to the overall circumstances. Such a situation should not exist. For example, there should not be any guarantee of a remedy where the only defect in the employer's conduct has been some failure to provide procedural fairness and the employee's conduct warrants dismissal.

To make it clear that this situation is not intended, the court will be required to consider all the circumstances in deciding whether a remedy of reinstatement or compensation should be granted and, if so, what the remedy should be. In other words, the court will weigh up all of the circumstances, and may, even though an employer has not met a statutory requirement, decide that a remedy should not be given to the employee. This approach is consistent with the long standing practice of industrial tribunals.
Other Legislation

The bill includes two amendments of the Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988. The first will clarify that no employee injured prior to the commencement of that act is entitled to have his or her compensation entitlements indexed after the age of 65.

The second amendment will clarify that injuries sustained in the course of travel to or from work are not compensable if they occur wholly within the boundary of the property on which the employee's residence is located.

The bill will also provide a mechanism for ensuring that determinations of the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal are free of sex discrimination. This mechanism has already been provided in relation to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the remuneration tribunal.
Stevedoring legislation will be amended by this bill to reflect current usage; `waterside workers' are now better described as `stevedoring employees'.
There are also minor technical amendments about industrial relations jurisdiction in coal industry matters.All these amendments are explained in more detail in the explanatory memorandum.
Financial Impact

The Australian Industrial Relations Commission has consulted employer groups and the ACTU about the best way to ensure that the new arrangements operate efficiently, effectively and quickly for all parties.

The commission is proposing innovative methods to ensure the speedy listing and determination of applications under the amended provisions. To support this, the commission is constructing some new hearing rooms and support facilities for the parties and their representatives, in Sydney and Melbourne, at an estimated one-off cost of $1 million. There will also be some additional staff required to advise and assist applicants and other parties. The cost of the additional staff over a full year is estimated to be $0.5 million.

A reduction in the resources required by the court is expected. However it is not possible to estimate with any certainty what that reduction will be before the new arrangements are better established and the court has dealt with the balance of its caseload under the existing legislative arrangements.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the order of the Senate of 31 August 1995 referring a matter to the Legal and Constitutional References Committee be modified as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Paragraph (a), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:
"(a)the reasons for the alleged severe limitations which may have been imposed on the management of Mrs Faulkner's case in relation to access to legal aid; and".

This motion is to modify the wording of a matter that has been referred to the Legal and Constitutional References Committee. The original motion was put and debated on 31 August 1995 following some detailed discussions with the Attorney-General's Department and the chair of the Legal and Constitutional References Committee, Senator Ellison, about the particulars of the case in hand.

PARA.TAB: Following that debate, the committee met and concern was expressed by some senators that the wording of the reference prejudged the issue. As a consequence, the chair of the committee, Senator Ellison, approached me about these concerns and modification was agreed to to clause (a) of the reference. Clause (a) now reads:

SPEECH.PARA: the reasons for the alleged severe limitations which may have been imposed on the management of Mrs Faulkner's case in relation to access to legal aid;

I can assure the Senate that the original wording of the reference was never intended to imply any prejudgment on the issue. In fact, the whole tenor of the reference was to determine whether an independent inquiry is justified into the conduct of the case.

PARA.TAB: I do not intend to discuss any further the particulars of the case as they have been more than adequately canvassed during debate on the original motion. I trust that this amendment to the original wording of the reference will satisfy all members of the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion ought to be carried because it does improve the thrust of the terms of reference. I made clear on the last occasion this matter was before the Senate that I have some real problems about this reference. I do not for one minute say that the Senate cannot investigate this matter, but I have some doubts about whether it is an appropriate thing to investigate in all the circumstances, but I will not go through that again.

PARA.TAB: I would have pressed my objections even stronger if it had been going to a committee which was not as good as the Legal and Constitutional References Committee in which I have great confidence. I have great confidence in the chair of that committee, Senator Ellison. I will not persist with the objection I might otherwise have had. I still—and I will be saying this before the committee—have some real problems about this sort of reference.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this reference was originally drafted I was not party to the considerations that were taken into account. I understand that the intention always was that it was a reference into alleged conduct and that the advice from the clerk's office was that the wording in its original form did the job it set out to do. However, concerns were raised in relation to whether we were making a prejudgment.

PARA.TAB: I understand fully those concerns and I agree with the mover of the amendment, Senator Margetts, that this makes it clearer and that any objective reader coming to the reference now would see that it is clearly a matter that we are looking into on the basis that nothing has been proven to date, nothing has been prejudged, and that we are looking at whether there should be an independent inquiry. I fully support the amendment moved by Senator Margetts.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly put on record the Australian Democrats' support for the amendment and the motion as amended, for the reasons stated by previous speakers.

DEBATE.TITLE: WILDLIFE PROTECTION (REGULATION OF EXPORTS AND IMPORTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1995

TALK.START.PARA: —There was one outstanding question when we left this matter last night. We were debating the issue of the time for which somebody needed to have owned a pet—we are talking about certain species of parrot—before that pet could be taken overseas by that person when permanently leaving Australia. In teasing that out I asked a question in relation to the possibility that parrots from Australia might become environmental hazards in other countries. That part of the question has not been answered.

PARA.TAB: I have privately discussed this matter with some of the ministerial advisers. It would be useful to record the fact that there may be some risk associated with the export of parrots from Australia into areas with similar environments where, as rabbits have done in Australia, those parrots might become a significant environmental penalty in that new country.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, in respect of the concern that Senator Coulter has raised, the legal export of these birds would not cause a problem because the quarantine requirements of the importing countries would ensure that was the case. The problem is caused by the illegal export of birds.

—That was not the point. We are discussing two issues. One issue is that these birds carry diseases. The minister has answered that. I am still not absolutely convinced that the methods used by AQIS and importing countries would guard against disease but I think we have adequately covered that.

PARA.TAB: On the second issue, if birds, say, galahs, are escaping and breeding in the wheat belts of North America, that might pose a hazard to that environment in the same way as rabbits have in Australia. I understand that an answer could be given to that question and it would be useful to have it on the record.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Not one that will satisfy Senator Coulter. If Senator Coulter is asserting that Australia should extend its quarantine obligations to protect the wheatbelts of North America, I think he is asking a bit much of the service. I hear the concern that Senator Coulter has raised. I tell you what, though, they would have to be very sexually active galahs to breed into such flocks that would threaten the wheat crops of North America.

PARA.TAB: The responsibility for determining whether the birds are legally imported into the United States, of course, rests with the authorities of the United States. It is a matter for them and their regime to determine whether the birds can be legally imported. I am sorry that Senator Coulter does not believe that that addresses his question. We are clearly on two different wavelengths here, because I believe that it does.

TALK.START.PARA: —This opens a new area, and we could go on all morning. What the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) is now saying, if I hear him correctly, is that Australia has no responsibility whatsoever for the global environment and that we should be permitted to export birds out of this country which may be a hazard in the country into which they are imported.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps North America is not a good example because they might have quite good rules in relation to the importation of animals, but I would have thought there is some responsibility on this country not to export animals which may become a hazard in other environments, whether or not that other country has some controls. I understand the answer to the question asked of your officers was that there is more illegal export of parrots than there is legal export of parrots, and that is where the hazards might lie rather than in the answer that you have given.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say, in terms of the tack you are taking, Senator Coulter, I understand your concern and your fellow feeling with galahs and the problems they might cause in North America. But it is a fact, regrettable though it might be, that the total number of birds that are exported in this category—that is, as pets—is very small. It is perhaps several hundred a year.

PARA.TAB: Although the Australian authorities, quarantine and customs—I have to say with some success—routinely and regularly intervene with the illegal trade, unfortunately, because of the extremely high value of Australian birds overseas, it is a very lucrative trade. There is no question that the smuggling problem is a far greater hazard to countries overseas from the illegal trade than from the legal trade.

Of course, I was not making any such ludicrous suggestion as Senator Coulter is putting. I simply think that Senator Coulter is getting the quantum, the size, of the problem out of proportion. In any case, most people want to take only one or two birds as pets. The countries to which they are being imported—and I think it is a fairly imperialistic stance you are taking, Senator Coulter, in that regard—actually do have authorities and quarantine requirements of their own that are exercised. AQIS, the Australian quarantine authority, is in active liaison in a very pro-active way with quarantine authorities around the world in those countries. It is not a simple one-way street, Senator Coulter, that you are putting to me that I am suggesting at all. There is active liaison constantly between the Australian quarantine authorities and overseas countries.

I might add, to the great credit of AQIS, that AQIS has been in a position and is currently in a position of providing expert technical assistance to a great many countries in terms of their quarantine environment. That is something we continue to do on a daily basis. We do not believe that the problem is as great as Senator Coulter is suggesting. Regrettably, the illegal trade—the officers' information was absolutely correct—poses a far greater risk than the very small legal export of these birds as pets.

TALK.START.PARA: —What the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) has referred to is one of the reasons why the Greens (WA) suggested that this clause should be opposed. If I can just remind my colleagues and the minister, the question that was being asked when I opposed this item related to a change which has been requested in this bill. Previously, people who wanted to take a pet out of the country were required to prove they had had that as a pet for three years. Now they do not have to prove that they have had it as a pet for three years. They may have had it as a pet for half an hour, a week or whatever. In fact, it is irrelevant. That requirement is being removed.

PARA.TAB: The concern being raised was that this could represent a loophole by which numbers of native Australian animals could be taken from the country and it could provide a loophole for smuggling and illicit trade in our native animals—the concern that Senator Collins expressed. I think the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) made light of that and said that it was extremely unlikely that it could be used as a loophole.

At one level, I would be prepared to accept advice—in fact, that is why I asked the question—that it will not constitute a loophole, that it is simply a way of easing some of the bureaucratic nightmares that ordinary householders might have of taking their pets with them when they are going out of the country permanently. My concern is that, by not having any kind of duration attached to that status, people who are leaving the country permanently could be used as an avenue for getting large numbers of birds out two by two, so to speak—a kind of Noah's ark—which would allow illicit trade. As Senator Collins mentioned, the species that are listed—the sulphur-crested cockatoo, the galah, the corella, the cockatiel and the budgerigar—are very prized overseas.

I am prepared to admit that it may not be the loophole that we were concerned about, but I do not think the argument has been addressed; neither has the case been defended for why the three years is such a burdensome requirement. In my view it also covers the point that Senator Coulter raised that somebody can just say that what they have immediately in their hand—a bird in the hand, so to speak—is a pet and we do not know where that bird has been prior to that. There may be other concerns that have been raised by taking it so quickly through quarantine. I think the minister has addressed that by saying that we have to trust our quarantine process and also the legal requirements of other countries.

I am not going to push it but I think I can continue to say we have the numbers—I am not sure because Senator Kemp has not spoken—to defeat this item. Proof of owning an animal is being reduced from `the exporter has owned and kept the animal as a household pet for not less than 3 years immediately preceding the export' to `the exporter kept the animal as a household pet immediately before the export'. I repeat to the minister that the reason for that change I do not believe has been argued thoroughly so as to remove the possibility of a loophole existing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already spoken on this item—I have checked the Hansard—and I did not plan to revisit it. We have canvassed the arguments. I listened to what the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) said, and I think he explained it quite well. It is a balancing factor. We are mindful, in view of the representations that we have received—I do not say on a regular basis but people have brought this to our attention—of the problems of the three-year test to establish whether people have owned their pet for three years. This has caused concern.

PARA.TAB: The government, in cutting down the number of birds which can be taken out of the country as pets, has moved in the sort of direction that we would want in relation to this. The government has cut that number from six or seven to two. In that sense, it has moved in the direction that we would support. The government has recognised the problem of many householders in attempting to establish ownership of birds over the three-year period.

Also, in weighing up the arguments, it seems to me that it is a bit of a long bow and a fairly tough test that people have to establish they are permanently leaving the country before being allowed to take two birds with them. It seems to me that permanent departure from the country, even if it does not entirely close the loophole that you are worried about, senator—

TALK.START.PARA: —It does.

—it at least shuts it fairly firmly; it may leave a small crack for someone. But I would need to hear stronger arguments, I think, to come down on the side of supporting the proposal that you have put to this chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. Senator Kemp is correct. I can reassure you, Senator Chamarette, that the Noah's ark syndrome is not a problem; in fact, that is a story I personally did not believe in when I was five years old. But I have checked. It is a maximum of two birds. That physical indication to you, senator, was, I assure you, a question of numbers. I did not mean it to be an offensive gesture—otherwise it would have been one bird.
—I took it in that spirit.
—Senator Chamarette, it is not a problem. It is two; it is very tough.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, the only representations I have received on these matters—and basically they have been from ANCA—have been complaints about the rigorousness with which the tests are applied. It is not a rubber stamping procedure at all; quite the reverse. ANCA, in fact, very thoroughly check out the bona fides of the individuals concerned, the status of their departure, and everything else, before such approval is given. It is a very rigorous process. Two birds is it in a lifetime.
Item 2 of Schedule 6 agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a number of other issues on which I need to seek some views from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), who is at the table. I think it was agreed before this debate started that, as we went through the amendments that were promised by the Democrats and then by the Greens, we would come back and address some of the other clauses in the bill so that we can ensure that all issues have been effectively covered.

PARA.TAB: Can I put this to the minister: although I have the greatest of respect, Senator Collins, for your competence and your widely encompassing knowledge on a range of issues, some of the questions that I have I think relate specifically to the knowledge of Senator Faulkner. Is he coming into the chamber, or has he been called away and cannot be here for his bill?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner will, of course, be coming into the chamber today, but he is detained on official business at the moment, to his regret. I am here to represent him. I will attempt to struggle with your questions, Senator, if you wish to put them. But Senator Faulkner will not be here.

PARA.TAB: But I would say—and I am not suggesting that we needed it—that we might have had some advice that you did wish to pursue a number of issues in here. My advice, Senator Kemp, even though it obviously was astray, was that, with the exception of this sole matter—and, in fact, I have often remarked that it is a brave person indeed who predicts what will happen in the Senate—I was told quite categorically this morning that this would take no longer than 10 minutes. You always send out for a thermos and a cut lunch when someone says that to you in here. I will just have to struggle on, as Senator Faulkner is not available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Minister. I do not want to detain the Senate too long on this aspect. I think at the start of this debate I did canvass that I had a number of matters I wished to raise. But from the point of courtesy, I deferred to my colleagues who were pursuing a number of amendments. I think also I advised the department that I had a number of issues I wished to raise. I think, if people gave that advice, they did not give it on a well based fashion and they certainly seemed to ignore views which I put in this chamber and privately.

PARA.TAB: One of the concerns that have come up with this bill and one of the matters I wish to raise concerns some of the issues the avicultural people have raised with the minister and with the department. I have said before that there seems to be a diversity of views amongst the aviculturalists on particular issues in relation to this bill. Of course, there are a large number of people and a number of groups who are interested in this area. It is probably not surprising that there is some diversity of views.

I am aware, and I have had discussions with the department, that, for example, the Avicultural Federation of Australia, I think, is one of the important groups in this area. They have expressed some concerns about the registration scheme for exotic birds. They were concerned initially that the consultation process had not run its full course. But, in view of the fact that the bill had been brought in, I am pleased to say that they then approached us in a very constructive fashion, sought urgent talks with the department and raised a number of issues with the department. At this time I wish to see whether the particular concerns they raised with the department have been effectively addressed by the government.

One of the issues raised was about the membership of the exotic birds committee. We have had that debate, so I will not canvass those particular issues again; but that was one of their concerns. Another issue I would like to get the minister's views on relates to the time period to review species which may be put on the register. I understand that there are quite a number of steps which will be required and that there are some 300 species to be reviewed. The Avicultural Federation of Australia is concerned that, if adequate consultation is not built into the process, then the scheme is destined to start with a lot of dissatisfied bird keepers. I wonder whether the minister could tell us how the registration scheme will be introduced and what will be the consultative arrangements set up to ensure that those who are involved and have a particular interest have an appropriate input.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, can I reassure Senator Kemp on the question of consultation. There has in fact been widespread consultation in respect of this bill. I will make two short quotes. One is from a letter that was received from a major aviculture group. It reads, `We fail to understand this attitude'—that is that there has been no discussion—`as we have been in receipt of five newsletters from ANCA. We have been delighted at the meetings held in various states to allow all aviculturalists to discuss the proposal with staff from ANCA.' A second avicultural group stated, `If any person felt they were not consulted, it would be due to them not availing themselves of the lines of communication available, certainly not through any fault of ANCA.'

PARA.TAB: In respect of the process that is going to be engaged upon, Senator Kemp is correct in the number of the species involved—it is about 300. It is believed that there are around 300 species of exotic birds. Of these, at least 11 species have established feral populations and are already designated as pests. Both the common starling and the common miner are established in the wild in Australia and they do compete with native birds for roost and nest sites, to the detriment of native birds.

The magnitude of the potential pest problem requires that those species that do pose a risk should be identified and documented at the national level. The review of pest potential of bird species will be completed by an independent consultant. The list of species to be reviewed has been compiled from information supplied by zoological institutions, states with a registration system already in place and a list referred from the aviculture industry. So the industry itself is in fact cooperating with this exercise in providing relevant information to the process.

The contract is due for completion by December this year. The consultants will be required to assess approximately 270 species on their agricultural and environmental pest potential. The exotic bird committee will advise the minister on the final list of species to be registered, taking into account the need to register species considered as high risk and birds that are classified internationally as endangered species.

As the decision making process will directly involve aviculture, through representation on the exotic bird committee, affected individuals will be aware of what birds will be subject to the scheme well in advance of it coming into effect. There will be direct involvement and consultation with the industry, which will be playing an active role in the process.

TALK.START.PARA: —That will hopefully provide some comfort. It is true that some groups have mentioned that the consultation process went well, as far as they were concerned, and that other groups were less than happy. It is important that every attempt is made to ensure that all major groups feel that the consultative process has been worked through properly. As I said, as a result of my discussions with Mr Ian Woolcock, the Chairman of the Avicultural Federation of Australia, I know that that organisation has expressed concerns. It moved quite quickly to ensure that it had discussions with the department to see whether those particular issues can be effectively addressed.

PARA.TAB: One of the matters raised by the federation was the concern that no bird keeper will be required to pay more than one registration fee for any bird. Of course, I suspect that this may well depend on the policies that the states may also adopt in relation to their own schemes. I wonder whether you are able to make a commitment that no bird keeper will be required to pay more than one registration fee for any bird.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp, you are correct. This does involve discussion with the states. I do understand that some sections of the community or the industry involved would welcome a single registration system that covers both the exotic and the native species of birds. The minister certainly does consider that this is a desirable goal, but due to constitutional constraints the Commonwealth can only introduce, as I am sure Senator Kemp is aware, an exotic registration scheme.

PARA.TAB: The concept of bird keepers dealing with only one government agency for registration and keeping the system as simple as possible, as Senator Kemp wants, is desirable. That is certainly our view. The issue is being progressed through discussions with the relevant state and territory agencies with this firmly in mind. The discussions at this point in time are still in progress.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Minister. I am not sure you have gone quite as far as the Avicultural Federation of Australia would have liked you to go on that, but I note that you are aware of its concerns. I think your aim is to avoid more than one fee being imposed. Would that be a correct interpretation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —What I said is that this is a matter that has to be progressed through discussions with the states. Discussions are active; they are still in progress.

—Minister, I note that you have just repeated what you said earlier. I was hoping to see whether I could push you slightly further. In view of the more recent advice that you have just been given, is there anything you wish to add to your earlier comments on the registration fee?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —All I can do is reconfirm the advice. The Commonwealth's desire is to have a one-stop shop and one fee. I understand that there will be a meeting with the states later this month where those issues will be resolved. That is certainly the position that the Commonwealth is taking.

—The Avicultural Federation of Australia felt that there needed to be a review of the penalties. The federation—this touches on some debates that we had earlier in this chamber—has suggested that the powers of inspectors appear to be extreme for an offence of holding an unregistered bird. I do not wish to re-canvass the issues which we discussed yesterday on that. Minister, is there any general comment that you are able to make about the particular concern that the Avicultural Federation of Australia has raised regarding the penalties relating to the keeping of illegal—that is, smuggled—birds? They say that the powers of inspectors and the penalties appear to be extreme for an offence of holding an unregistered bird. There will be a variety of views on that, but that is the view that the federation has raised. Can you make any remarks on that to address that issue?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The maximum penalty is set at five years' imprisonment. That is a maximum penalty which the courts would determine from time to time. I would respectfully disagree with concerns that that is too severe. I have already mentioned two exotic birds that are major pests in this country which compete with our native birds to the great detriment of those species.

PARA.TAB: I personally believe—and I have no hesitation in saying so—that the deliberate avoidance by a person of the requirements to register an exotic species and the deliberate act of a person to avoid those prescriptions and to illegally bring a bird into the country which, in fact, could well be diseased, apart from anything else, is a serious offence. I believe that the penalties are appropriate.

The powers of inspectors under this act are not really different from the powers of inspectors under a whole range of acts, both state and federal. This is something which is constantly raised—whether they are civil aviation inspectors or inspectors in Queensland. For example, the Queensland semen inspectors have the legal right to knock on a person's door at two o'clock in the morning and demand the production of semen at an instant's notice. If you look at that relevant Queensland act, you will find those powers in there. The powers are largely consistent with inspectorial powers that are provided at both Commonwealth and state level.

TALK.START.PARA: —We all agree that where people are involved in the smuggling of species, which are quite contrary to the laws of this country, it may impose, for reasons the minister stated, serious risks. However, I point out that the federation has raised a number of issues relating to how the law will operate. As the discussions continue over the coming months, undoubtedly they will raise with the minister further concerns which they see occurring.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the reason I wanted to have the minister in the chamber was that I wanted to look at some of the issues that state governments have raised regarding this bill. As I said, the bill has the broad support of all major players and we certainly strongly support the bill. In my discussions with a number of states there seemed to be a variety of issues which had been left hanging or there are a number of matters that the states still were not clear on. I want to get for the record the nature of the consultations which have been carried out with the states and find out whether, as far as the government is concerned, any major issues which have been raised with it by the states are not effectively addressed in this bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The question was so broad that I certainly am not aware of what particular concerns Senator Kemp is raising, nor are the officers who are here. The question was all encompassing. I mentioned already, on the question of registration and so on, that a meeting has been set down between the federal government and the states for the end of this month. I assure Senator Kemp that that consultation will continue. If he can be a little more particular about the individual concerns that he says have not been addressed, I might be able to get advice for him. The question was very broad.

—Before I ask a couple of more particular questions, I want to get clear in my own mind and for the record the nature of the consultations which were carried out. Specifically, the states, presumably, were given copies of the draft bill well in advance and presumably came back to the department with comments on that bill. Is that correct?
—Yes, it is correct. I am advised that we received comments and suggestions in response to the circulation of the bill from each state and territory.

—One of the issues, for example, which has been raised with me relates to schedule 3, management programs and controlled specimens. Item 4 provides that management programs currently in force which have not had a time period of approval included in the declaration cease to be approved on the operation of the amendments. The view of one of the state governments was that this seemed to be unduly restrictive and it would seem to be more appropriate to allow a longer period for such programs to be replaced.

PARA.TAB: The example given to me is that this item would directly impact on the wildflower industry program operating in Western Australia. The currently approved program provides for an export industry which has been estimated to be worth $15 million each year. Exports would be jeopardised if the current program approval is revoked prior to agreement being reached on a replacement program. I understand that negotiations with ANCA over such a replacement program are in a difficult phase and it may take some time to reach a suitable agreement on a replacement program. The view that was put was that it may be more sensible to include in the bill a provision that programs currently approved for an unspecified period remain approved for, say, two years after the amendments enter into force, thereby giving adequate time for negotiations on a replacement program. I wonder whether the minister can address those specific concerns.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter is being actively discussed with the Western Australian government. It will be six months before this legislation comes into effect and discussions will be held with the Western Australian government during this time.
—The expectation would be that agreement would be reached, presumably. What would happen if agreement was not reached?
—I am assured there is a very strong expectation that agreement will be reached.
—The minister did not address the other leg that if agreement was not reached—
—It is a nonsense.

—It is not a nonsense for those in the industry. The question has been posed. There have been concerns raised. The arrangements relating to enforcement are in schedule 9. One state has raised with me a concern that item 1 clarifies arrangements which can be made between state and territory authorities not only for the enforcement of the act but for the administration of particular provisions. Some states have expressed concern that the Commonwealth will not be adequately contributing to the costs of the states in the enforcement and administration of the federal act. Can the minister address those concerns?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have addressed them already, but I will address them again. These concerns, which are known—and Senator Kemp knows they are known—are to be raised directly at the consultations that have already been set down between the Commonwealth and the states for the end of this month, as Senator Kemp well knows. If you prefer, we can actually adjourn consideration of this bill until later today if you want to question the minister. I think that would be regrettable, considering that there is support across the chamber for the bill. The matters will be addressed at the end of the month at that meeting.

—Thank you for stating what you know to be in my mind. Sometimes you are right; sometimes you are wrong. I have always found it is handy to get things on the record and in Hansard. Sometimes we ask questions of which we may well be aware of the answer. We believe it is important that the official record of this bill contain certain statements and assurances from the minister.

PARA.TAB: A number of other issues have been raised, but it is not my intention to delay the bill. As I said, I was a little surprised, in view of the exceedingly cooperative attitude which has prevailed during the negotiations on this bill and my flagging that I wished to raise a number of questions, that the relevant minister was not in the chamber and was apparently under the impression that the debate this morning would take only some three minutes.

I conclude my remarks by saying that the coalition supports the bill before the chamber. Some amendments have been made to the bill with the support of the coalition. I think the debate has been a constructive one. A number of issues have been better elucidated. It seems to me, from my discussions with a wide range of groups, there are still quite a number of issues which are not effectively addressed in this bill. Undoubtedly, the Senate will in coming years have a chance to revisit this legislation. Hopefully, some of those concerns can be addressed at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some concluding remarks. I think I made them yesterday. I made them to the officers. This whole area is an area of extremely complex legislation. It did seem to me, from going through it, it is an area that is ripe for review and simplification, to try to bring the various acts, schedules and other things into some uniform legislation—perhaps into a native species protection act or something which covers threatened species, both imports and exports, and which tries to amalgamate a number of pieces of legislation.

PARA.TAB: It has been quite difficult to find one's way through the 1982 act and this amending bill that we are dealing with together and the other pieces of relevant legislation which are related to it. What we found on several occasions when we were looking at amending this particular piece of legislation was that those items were picked up somewhere else in other legislation. That seems to me quite unfortunate. It must be difficult for people outside, as well as for the officers inside, to try to interpret this. I make a plea that the government consider reviewing this over the next couple of years and come up with a more integrated approach to this whole area of proper management and protection of Australia's wildlife.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Bob Collins) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 18 September, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this bill be now read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: upon which Senator Lees had moved by way of amendment:
"1.For the reasons set out in paragraph (3), further consideration of the bill be postponed and be an order of the day for Monday 20 November 1995;
2.Senators who have spoken to the motion "That this bill be now read a second time" may speak again to that motion for up to 20 minutes each when the bill is again called on;
3.The reasons referred to in paragraph (1) are as follows:

Passage of the bill now would be precipitate and ill-advised in the absence of imminent or forthcoming information, recommendations and necessary consultations which bear directly on the likely purpose, impact and effectiveness of the bill, including in particular:

PARA.TAB: (a)publication, by the Australian Early Childhood Association and the National Children's Services Forum, of the planning model for the children's services industry; and
(b)publication and distribution of a discussion paper on a National Framework for Children's Services by the Council of Australian Governments, which is due in a matter of weeks; and

(c)possible shifts in the Government's position regarding an hourly or daily limit to be applied to eligibility for Child Care Assistance for non-work related child care—a limit that would be made possible by the passage of this bill".

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are at the summing-up stage of the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. In summary, that bill was proposing to introduce clear guidelines about up to 12 hours of child-care assistance for occasional care for families using child care where one parent or the sole parent was not in the work force or not studying, training or looking for work as defined in other parts of our child-care program.

PARA.TAB: What have we heard from the opposition? What have we heard from the Democrats and the Greens? Mostly from the opposition, the most amazing contradictory contribution that I have ever heard. I do not have it from you, Senator Troeth, but would you like to make it clear whether you are opposing this bill or supporting the amendment?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be supporting the amendment moved by Senator Lees.

—I was very pleased to get it from you, Senator, because there had only been a whisper around the corridors that the opposition had now changed its view. It opposed this bill in the House of Representatives, opposed it in this place and now, with a nice little piece of opportunism, has decided to support the amendment—contradicting all your own words, Senator, contradicting your principles and contradicting what you say is your objection to this bill. A classic example of good opposition policy, behaviour and performance! But I will come to that in more detail as I go through this.

PARA.TAB: The government does not support the Democrats' amendment. This is a bill with savings of $141 million over four years to 1998-99 and those savings are an important part of this government's overall economic program. The Democrats and the Greens have stated that they cannot say at this stage whether they would support the measure even if it came up again in late November. I am very concerned about why you would want to defer a piece of legislation with the possibility that you would not support it then.

I do note that Senator Lees in her speech made the contribution that the Democrats are very supportive, in the large part, of the government's child-care program. I acknowledge that, Senator Lees, but I certainly do not accept your amendment or the arguments that you have put in support of the deferral motion.

The measure is due to start on 1 April 1996. As the budget decision was announced in May this year, child-care centres and families would have had almost a year to adjust. What we would be doing with this motion to defer is putting that off for another 12 months. That blows out the government's savings projections from this measure. I particularly want to return to the hypocrisy of the opposition in now changing their minds on what they plan to do in this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nobody is guaranteeing, I think as you have just said, that it will be passed in November. It is simply an opportunity for planning to take place.

—We are very pleased that the opposition and the Democrats wish to run the government, but that is not how it happens in this place. We do not even know what `planning' means. We certainly know that in this place it is very difficult for government to get its legislation through.

PARA.TAB: The opposition, as I have said, voted against this measure in the lower House. They have made it quite clear that they totally oppose the idea of 12 hours child-care assistance for families where one parent or the sole parent is not in the work force. They now want the measure deferred until November in the hope, of course, that it will never come on but so that they cannot quite be charged with obstructing this legislation totally.

You have changed your view, Senator Minchin. I heard your speech the other day and reread it to make sure. You were totally opposed to it and now, with a nice little opportunity, your view on this has changed dramatically. It fits quite nicely with your hypothetical child-care policy as explained to us by your own party yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get on with it.

—Senator, come on! I have listened to these contributions for quite some time. I am certainly going to make clear the message that I want you and the people listening to hear. They need to know about the two-faced opposition approach in this area.

PARA.TAB: The opposition does not support this measure. They are opposing a fair and equitable measure that it is fiscally responsible. They are opposing an opportunity for some 31,000 extra families to have a place in child-care centres. They are opposing the return to a fair balance between the priority for working families and work related care and up to 12 hours of occasional care for families with one parent not in the paid work force. This is an absolute hypocrisy on the part of the opposition.

In particular, I want to pick up on the points made by Senator Minchin in his contribution. He said on a number of occasions that the opposition supports women who want to be at home with their children, that he does absolutely. In the same breath he then says that they should be entitled to 50 hours child-care assistance. That is a nonsense. If you want to be at home with your children, why on earth would you want to have them in child care for 50 hours?

One of the arguments put in other places, and seemingly endorsed by you, was that some families benefit from having child care, that they are not really very good at being parents and that child care is better for them. That is an absolute insult to the parents in Australia. It is an absolute insult to suggest that parents cannot cope with their children and that the way they cope is by sending them off to child care. If you want to support women being home with their children—it is usually women that you talk about—why on earth would you be insisting that they have an entitlement to 50 hours child care? Secondly, I remember Senator Minchin saying that there is no guarantee the savings in this legislation would be achieved. I tell you what: if you oppose it, it is absolutely certain that they will not.

The Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) and the Treasurer (Mr Willis) are very interested in the behaviour of the opposition on this piece of legislation. Yesterday you were asking questions about increases in taxes. You were asking about this government not reducing its deficit. You were asking about the impact on family. But when it comes to the opportunity to put your own seeming preferred view into effect, you will not support this government in its fiscally responsible, fair and equitable process in this piece of legislation.

You have also made some comment about the cost of child care to government rising by up to 18 per cent a year over the last number of years. Absolutely. That is because we have established a child-care program and seen its massive expansion. One of the reasons we had to do that was that for seven years the Fraser government did nothing about child care. Your policies now, you tell us, are hypothetical. Your policies then were nonexistent. Of course it is this government's commitment to expanding child care. We do not blush for that increase. You go around as though it is some kind of negative. It is a very big plus. Ask the families of Australia whether they appreciate child care, whether they appreciate their child-care assistance, whether they appreciate the opportunity to participate in the work force or to study or to train or to do voluntary work if it is contributing to their employment prospects—all of those things.

That leads me straight on to Senator Minchin's notion that we have in this bill—I think you were saying it is in this bill—a 19th century definition of work. The only thing 19th century in this place is you. You cited the example of your wife maybe doing some voluntary work. If people are doing voluntary work towards getting employment, that is covered under the bill. You have got completely out of touch arrangements. If a person is working in the paid work force, if a person is studying, if a person is training, if a person is looking for work, that person remains as entitled to the child-care assistance as ever.

You would be hard-pressed to find a family who would want child care assistance for a reason other than it would be a benefit for them or an opportunity for them to visit a doctor or attend other appointments or whatever. Most families are busy doing all those things I have described. We have also allowed for the concerns of families with an emergency. Let us say a parent is taken sick or some other crisis happens. Then, of course, those families will be eligible for child-care assistance to cover them for whatever hours are needed during the time of that emergency. The same applies for families with a child with a disability or children of parents with a disability and families at risk. All of those categories remain the same.

We are trying to make sure that the priority for work related care and our continuing commitment to occasional care is back in balance. I made that point during the committee hearing, and I say it again. In most cases, the median figure of hours used by families for occasional child care is 12 hours. That figure was not an arbitrary choice. The figure very closely corresponds with what families use in preschool and/or kindergarten and have been using for many years now. A successful program for children in the naught to five years group can be implemented in those sorts of hours. It has been a lovely assistance to families over all those years. It seemed entirely appropriate to settle on that figure, particularly as it corresponded with the median use of people using occasional care in our long day care centres.

The government has set in place a child-care system of which we can be proud, but we do not rest on our laurels. We continue to look for improvement. We continue to look for that improvement in the delivery of services and in offering more flexibility and in funding arrangements. We do have—and I note Senator Lees referred to this—COAG, the Council of Australian Governments, examining the roles and responsibilities of the Commonwealth states in a Commonwealth process that is looking at administration and funding arrangements; not at the priority of access, not at the balance between work related and occasional care but at the best administration and funding arrangements, areas of duplication and so on.

Even if COAG does come up with suggestions and ways in which we can best provide more or better family friendly services and what I call seamless delivery of services for families in the naught to five or preschool age group, none of that, in any way, contradicts the intention of this legislation—none of it. That COAG document will also be complemented by the EPAC inquiry.

Under this government, child care, as most people would know, has been elevated to a very significant economic issue. It is not a welfare issue but a very critical part of our labour market programs and our economic policies. Child care is crucially important to Australia's economic and social development. EPAC is going to be looking at the long-term goals for child care and what its place might have to be in five or 10 years time. It is not about what we might want to do today, tomorrow or next year.

As I said before, the Fraser government wanted nothing to do with child care, and now the opposition has gone from opposing the legislation to agreeing to defer it only as cheap political opportunism. As we heard yesterday, the opposition has a hypothetical child-care policy.

This government has expanded child care and child-care subsidies. The primary focus of the program is to assist families in the work force to manage their work and family commitments. Occasional care, as I have said, has always been an important part of the program. We have always recognised the importance of child care for families when one parent was at home, not for respite because that is covered under the priority of access but for take a break arrangements and so on when parents might have an appointment or some other requirement in their lives where they would be assisted by not having their little children along with them.

One thing that certainly has not been touted by the opposition is that under this legislation the present limit of four hours of occasional care in occasional care centres would have increased to 12 hours. I hope you all appreciate what you have just done: continue the restriction of occasional care through occasional care centres. Four hours in those centres at the moment would have been extended to 12 under this legislation. That would have given many more families greater opportunities.

The level of child-care assistance going to families with a parent at home has been increasing by two percentage points a year over the last few years. If this trend continues, up to 35 per cent of child-care assistance outlays could be for non-work-related care. This change would not have affected most centres but it clearly affects some centres, particularly those in certain parts of Queensland, where up to 40 per cent of the hours, and sometimes even more, are used for occasional care.

To skew the fairness and equity of this program across the whole country, you have bought a pup. To assist some child-care centres—and no parents—you are actually prepared to defer this piece of legislation. In fact, the opposition is putting a cover on its opposition to it.

It is estimated that 31,000 extra families would have an opportunity to participate in child care. You are denying them that. If you are in, whacko, you can keep it and go for it. If you are out, too bad. That is the opposition approach to fairness and equity. It is not ours.

I just make it clear that all the parents concerned about this who have contacted our office have made it absolutely clear that it does not appeal at all to be charged for 12 hours child care when you are using it for only four. The idea of paying for the four, five or six hours of child care they actually use, rather than the 12 hours they are being charged for, is particularly attractive to them.

The people of main concern here are the centres which may have difficulty with their charging practices. The government was and still is prepared to help any of those centres. We are not about making it difficult: we are about giving support in every way possible.

Senator Lees made the point that you cannot go changing horses in midstream, to use a metaphor, meaning you cannot change the practices that child-care centres came into business with an understanding of. No child-care centre was set up on the understanding that it could operate on 50, 60 or 70 per cent occasional care. If it was, it was ignoring the priority of access guidelines.

I remind you that it was only a couple of years ago that we tightened the child-care assistance entitlement whereby centres were charging families for a whole week when children were only using care for only two days. There was a considerable amount of double-dipping. No centre in Australia admitted it was doing it but we have saved over $9 million since we tightened the screws on that.

That was clearly a change of practice affecting centres but no centre was prepared to defend the double-dipping. I appreciate the point you are making, that we need to ensure that things are not made impossible for centres but, on balance, with a considerable amount of thought, this legislation and the government's approach takes account of other needs.

The other thing that needs to be said is that the action of delaying this legislation will effectively consign many families to continued unemployment. These are opportunities lost that will be bitterly felt by those families. It will also disadvantage non-working families, whom those opposite are claiming to champion. As I have said, some 31,000 families, many with one parent not working, will not be able to get places.

I have given the government's definition of `work'. If that is 19th century, all I can say is poor Senator Minchin. If he thinks that our work-related program of entitlements for child-care assistance is a 19th century concept, he certainly has not been reading his history.

One of the things we recognised with people returning to the work force—particularly with women—is that, if they had to train, study or do a bridging course, child care assistance was just as important then as it was when they finally went into the paid work force. Our child care arrangements have always had that preparatory stage as a critical part of work related definitions. I suspect that there was nothing in the 19th century definitions that entitled women to study or train at all, much less get child care assistance while they did it. So Senator Minchin is hopelessly out of date on that point.

I have also explained at length the reason why we have set the figure of 12 hours. It is not an arbitrary figure. As I pointed out in the committee hearings, it is the median use of child care for families. A very significant number of families would not be affected at all, and a few would have to drop their hours by a couple only. The 12 hours is broadly in line with—and, in many instances, more generous than—the level of developmental sessions provided for in the largely state funded preschools. Rather than disadvantaging families with a parent at home, this initiative will enable many of those families who currently cannot access child care or who can access only a very limited number of hours to increase their access to 12 hours. The government opposes the deferral of this piece of legislation. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to draw the attention of the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) specifically to paragraph (3) of my amendment, where I go through some of the reasons for postponing the consideration of this bill. If the minister were to read my speech and look through the committee stage of this legislation, she would also find some other reasons. She questioned, for example, why some families want more than 12 hours in category 4, and most of that was addressed in the committee process and during the speeches yesterday.

PARA.TAB: I draw the minister's attention to paragraph (3) of the amendment and the fact that the government is undergoing a series of different planning proposals relating to child care. Also, the Australian Early Childhood Association and the National Children's Services Forum are looking at planning models for the industry. It simply is not good enough for you to decide out of the blue that you are going to change the rules without looking at all the implications.

You have come in here and suggested that those savings are concrete and absolutely justified, but I accept Senator Minchin's discussions yesterday when we looked at this—there is no justification for picking those numbers. Worse than that, those numbers are forward estimates. You have argued—and you argued during the committee stage—that you are not trying to bankrupt any centres, particularly those in Queensland, which are over-reliant on category 4. During the committee hearings, the department said that it was looking at forward estimates and trying to discourage new centres from setting up in areas where there are already plenty of services for category 4 children.

The message we are sending by not throwing this legislation out—which was our alternative—but by deferring it for several months is that we are still looking at the issue. As I said in my speech yesterday, the system is in a mess. Not even local government can tell those people who are interested in setting up a centre how many centres are on their books, where the centres are operating and how many children are accessing them. That basic information is not available for people who are looking at going into the child care industry, so we need a planning process in place.

People will be certainly warned, after hearing of this long process in the Senate, that they really need to do their homework. Even community based centres in our own state, Minister, are being caught in this net. One centre is opening in Noarlunga after many years of pressure only to find that a private centre has already been established there. Even in our home state, we see cases where, because there is no planning, extra services are going into some areas while there are still no services in others.

As for the 31,000 extra places, it really amazes me where you can get that figure from if the category priority system—category 1, 2, 3 and 4—is operating. If you are going to police it properly and make sure it is operating, you will solve a lot of the problems that you are arguing about anyway. If there are category 4 parents in with category 1 parents—in other words, those parents who are working and waiting to get in—priority of access rules apply. The centre needs to explain to those category 4 parents that they are sorry, but there are category 1 parents waiting, so they need to either shuffle their requirements or leave the child care service altogether.

So where, Minister, you get 31,000 extra places from, I really have to wonder. Surely the only shuffle is going to be between category 4 and category 4—not, as you were suggesting, having working parents having to go on the dole or lose their jobs. In inner Melbourne already, people can go from centre to centre and find that they are absolutely full. There is no full-time, five days a week care available. While there are a few category 4 people in there, they are generally only taking up a half or maybe 1 1/2 to two days. So for your suggestion that we are in any way, through our actions in this place, disadvantaging parents who are now trying to get into the work force, I really would like to see some specific evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On behalf of the coalition, I would like to make a contribution to the reasons why we are supporting Senator Lees's amendment. As the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) questioned the reasons why the coalition was supporting the amendment, I feel that in the interests of transparency in the Senate it is certainly fitting that I should give the reasons for that.

PARA.TAB: For the minister to display her total overreaction to the position announced by the coalition I find absolutely astonishing. As she has pointed out, I, representing the coalition, said in the second reading debate that we were opposing the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill 1995, and that has not changed. We simply would like to take a much longer look at the bill to see whether some of the reasons that the minister has quoted in her speech are really going to apply.

In fact, Minister, it is not the coalition that has changed its mind; it is the government that has changed its mind. Mr Keating in his election speeches in 1993, as you very well remember, announced that child care was a right. Now it is not a right. As Senator Chamarette pointed out in the second reading debate yesterday, suddenly we have women who deserve child care and we have women who do not deserve child care, and that will come about if this legislation put forward by the government is passed.

The coalition is coming to a reasoned decision, which we want to look at over a period of time. Why is this political opportunism? We are simply thinking the issues through, and I do not see how opposition to the bill necessarily countermands a long look at the legislation. You talked about being fair and equitable to parents. How can you say that when you are slamming the door of child care in the faces of people who need it, and people who are seeking it, on a basis that has so far been commercially available?

What about the position of centres which have taken a commercial decision to cater for the non-working portion of the child-care market? What happens to them? You say that they should have known under your guidelines that their priority of access should be for working parents. What about centres in rural and remote areas? You know very well that the major proportion of the market for those particular centres is not for the working part of the population; it is for people who need occasional care, and suddenly you are saying that they cannot have it.

You will remember, Minister, that in the committee inquiry into this legislation I asked your department this: what would centres do if they had taken a commercial decision to cater for that end of the market and suddenly found that, with the passing of this legislation, part of their market was chopped out? The answer of your department was that those child-care centres should simply relocate. Come on! How do we go about relocating bricks and mortar or suddenly shifting a commercial operation from where you have chosen to have it to another part of Australia? This just is not possible.

You also know very well that the expansion of child-care centres under your department has been totally unplanned, that there is an oversupply in some areas and that there is no supply in others. As Senator Lees has witnessed, people are driving around looking for work related care, but to do it this way and to regulate the market is not the way to do it.

A friend of my daughter who is expecting a baby in December recently spent several days looking for a place for that child because she wishes to return to part-time nursing after the baby is born. She is unable to find a place within a large area of suburban Melbourne. This is a total indictment on your so-called planning processes. If your planning processes are so brilliant, how is it that the very large expansion in child-care centres has not been better regulated? What you are trying to do is use a financial and an hours regulation to take the place of the planning process. That is simply not good enough.

Witnesses at the recent Senate inquiry said to us that, if the existing priority guidelines were made to work properly, there would be no need for this new legislation. Senator Lees has certainly gone along with that. Why aren't the priority guidelines working properly? Is this because your department does not see that they are implemented properly or make the positions clear to centres? What is it? Again, it is an indictment on your department and your administration of it.
