In the interests of a proper look at this legislation, which will affect thousands of children, thousands of families and many child-care centres throughout Australia, we believe that further consideration of the bill should be postponed and we should look at it again on Monday, 20 November. At the moment, the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee has a reference on early childhood and the planning mechanisms that are in operation in the early childhood area. Witness after witness has said that the child-care centre program at the moment is in chaos and that many people are simply not aware of what is available and where it is. Again, I suggest that this is an indictment on your department. Therefore, the coalition are supporting the amendment moved by Senator Lees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to speak to the Australian Democrat amendment and reiterate that the coalition has not changed its position. We remain opposed to this bill. That was the position of the coalition taken some time ago and announced and reiterated here. The Democrats have said that their amendment, which proposes that this be postponed to 20 November, does not in any way guarantee that they will support the passage of the bill. Therefore, in supporting their amendment we are in no way contradicting our original position.

PARA.TAB: That was a position reached after due and proper consideration of what we regard as the improper motives of the government in driving a wedge between Australian women. They are driving a wedge, as I said in my earlier speech, between those who are in the `paid' work force and those who are not.

The Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) has stood up and said that voluntary work that is towards getting paid employment will count. That eliminates almost all voluntary work from being `work related' for the purposes of this bill. As Senator Lees said, people may be working at the tuckshop at school on a voluntary basis and wish to put their child into child care, or they might be doing readings at school or something of that sort.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Senator. You don't do it for 50 hours a week.

—That is not work related. It is not towards getting paid employment as a tuckshop worker, but they will be cut out by this. The minister uses the argument that we want women at home to have access to child care for 50 hours a week. That is nonsense. We are not saying 50 hours a week. We are saying do not restrict it to 12. I do not know where she gets this 50 hours from in that sense.

PARA.TAB: We are not saying they want to have their children in child care for 50 hours a week. We are saying that they should have the right to have their children in child care for more than 12 hours a week and not have this arbitrary limit placed on it because the bureaucrats decide that it is not work related and therefore they can have only 12 hours a week. That is an absolute nonsense. It is a Dickensian view of what is work and what is not. It is a nonsensical approach to the lives of modern Australian women. It does not fit in with the way they live, how they work and how they operate in the community. That is why we think this legislation is so wrong.

I draw the Senate's attention to the correspondence I guess we have all had from the Australian Federation of Child Care Associations, which describes the current situation as a `major crisis'. It says that if this proposal goes ahead it:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . will result in the closure of some services, the loss of child care workers' jobs, an increase in long day care fees for all parents . . .

It reminds the government that up until now it has apparently respected the parents' right to make their own decisions regarding the need for child care. That clearly will not be the case after the passage of this. There will be this arbitrary bang: once you hit 12, that is it—out; forget it. You are denied access to child care. As the federation says:
. . . the choices and rights of non working parents are threatened by this decision.
. . . child care centres who have made financial commitments based on current government policy are now finding that their investments are being endangered and in some cases destroyed.
The federation goes on in that vein, criticising what it properly regards as an unconscionable restriction:
The limiting of hours for Non Work Related Child Care Assistance will decrease the number of places available, due to the closure of centres.
That is a statement made by the Federation of Child Care Associations, who ought to know. It continues:

The cost of child care for all parents will rise as a result of this decision, the number of available services will drop and non working, single, low income families will be discriminated against . . .
That is why we oppose this bill.

PARA.TAB: The federation has given us several case studies of families affected by this bill. I will draw the Senate's attention to one particular case which I think is quite glaring and shows how nonsensical this proposition is. The case study reads:

SPEECH.PARA: One income family, caring for two children aged 6 months and 2 years. Living in a flat without a garden or playground. This family is dependent on one low income and needs Child Care Assistance to access child care for the older child.

The 2 year old is very active, enjoys the company of other children in a centre setting and has been attending the nearest child care centre (which is 45 minutes distance by car) for 3 days a week. This enables the parent at home to spend individual time with the infant—
the six-month-old child—

and the older child to benefit from regular time at the centre. The centre is able, over the 3 days, to provide continuity of developmental experiences for the 2 year old. The child has the opportunity to access a playground and a variety of toys over the 3 days.

This family is now limited to 12 hours of child care for their 2 year old. This means the child can only stay 1 full day or two morning or afternoon sessions—when it has previously become used to attending on Mon, Wed and Fridays.

That is a classic case of a low income family struggling on one income. The parents who are trying to do the right thing by their children will be disastrously affected by what the minister is proposing in this bill. Several other case studies to that effect have been given where people will be badly hurt by what the government is proposing in this bill.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me the problem largely is that the government's approach to child care—which this federation says is now crisis ridden—is, in a sense, producer driven; it is not consumer driven. You are not motivated by giving consumers of child care the maximum flexibility, the maximum choice in the arrangements they want to make as to how they bring up their children. This limit of 12 hours cuts right across that. It does restrict and limit the access of consumers of child care in a way which, as I have said, I think is unconscionable.

As I have said, the government is clearly driven by wanting to save money—and, as we have said, because we think government expenditure is out of control, that is not an unreasonable motivation. But this is not the way to go about it. This is not the way to achieve savings. We have had evidence to the effect that this could well result in much less saving than the government has predicted.

We are well on record as indicating—and have the credentials in this area to do so—where we think expenditure savings can be made. We will say again and again that the child-care cash rebate should be income tested. At the moment it is a totally non-income tested subsidy for the use of child care which very high income families have access to and which is, in effect, a subsidy paid for by some of these low income families who will now be hurt by this 12-hour limit which the government has placed on low income families. They will now no longer have access to child care but their taxes, in effect, will be going to subsidise rich families having access without any restriction whatsoever to the child-care cash rebate. I repeat: we are on record as saying that the child-care cash rebate should be income tested, which would produce savings to the government.

So we do ask the government to seriously rethink this legislation. We think it is wrong and, in this instance, we support the Democrats' amendment to give the government time to rethink this bill and, hopefully, withdraw it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Senator Lees, it is important to know that what is proposed in this legislation is necessary, or can be judged as being necessary, whether or not you ever have a planning process. This is about making sure that there is a fair spread of access to child-care places right now. You must ensure that you do not confuse the two. It is very important that we do get that priority of access clarified and operating. From listening to Senator Troeth in particular, it certainly seems that she contradicts herself entirely in terms of saying that you cannot get any places, and there is no need for priority of access.

PARA.TAB: Also, listening to Senator Troeth, she would suggest that what we are doing now is stopping occasional care, that mothers at home cannot have access and that the whole world is about to change. In fact, all we are doing is making clear the priority of access guidelines and allowing the 12-hour limit for the non-work related care as it is defined. You need to tell the truth here and not obfuscate, as you have been doing.

An opposition that says, `We oppose this bill, but we do not really want to oppose it until November,' is a daft opposition, if ever I have heard one. Do you oppose it or not? We know why you are not opposing it today. You have opposed it in the other place. You oppose the bill, but you say, `We think we'll leave our opposition until November'—not because the Democrats, or the government or the Greens might come up with your support, but because you oppose it. You are on the record as opposing it, but you would like to wait around and oppose it in November. It is absolutely pathetic. You have said it. You have confessed out of your own mouth.

Another point that is important to remind all listeners is that there is still a very significant unmet demand for children between the age of nought and two. In Queensland already there is a change happening. Some of the centres, recognising the importance for changing, are taking many more children between the ages of nought and two, particularly the 12 months and older age group. That change is already happening. That is the sort of change we would like to encourage in centres.

Centres that are looking at a restriction or a limit on the number of people coming to them properly have to look at where else there will be commercial opportunity for them—and that is in moving into baby places. The number of baby places in the private child-care centres is still very significantly less than the baby places in the community based sector. If you want to make serious commercial decisions, then you go where the opportunity is. Some of the centres are beginning to do that, even before the 12-hour occasional care was put in. So you will find that the good centres, the financially viable centres, the centres that are really able to make the best of it, are already making those moves and they are picking up the opportunities for meeting the work related needs of families with children between the ages of nought and two.

Senator Troeth made a point about rural and remote areas, where we know that most of the care is occasional care. You could count in a very small number the private centres that have opened in rural and remote areas. The rural and remote centres have been put there by the community based sector and the government is setting them up precisely because we want to go to an equitable distribution of child-care centres.

Senator Troeth says that there is no planning. It is a scandal to so deliberately misrepresent the facts. The high needs areas are defined across all the states. Our community based, our family daycare, our occasional care and our outside school hours care centres have all been based on needs and planning for distribution. That is actually the case. The reason we are in the rural and remote areas is that we recognise the need there and we have been prepared to put the centres there. So if we want to talk in a serious tone and talk facts, let us do that. Let us not so skew the facts, which is what it looks as though you are deliberately intending to do.

The planning process for the community based centres, for the family daycare, for the government centres has always been there. That is why there is the distribution of child-care centres across the country that we have. The problems that Senator Lees mentioned about the failure to be able to get a child-care place in the heart of Melbourne because most of the centres are filled with work related care is a very important point. A very large number of the centres said that this proposal would not affect them at all, because 99 per cent of the children or families using them are there for exactly that reason—work related care.

Although we have put so many places up, there is still an unmet demand for work related care and it is not even across the state. We are saying that, in centres where non-work related care is provided in large part to many of the families, it is time for those centres to rethink and to modify so as to look at meeting work related needs as a priority. Some of those centres do not even maintain waiting lists. They do not canvass the work related needs in the area.

I was fascinated to find out that Senator Troeth and Senator Minchin want planning, regulations and all those sorts of things. It would be interesting to know what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) thinks about planning and regulations. On the one hand, those opposite say that they want no interference and that they want to let the market get on with it but, on the other hand, they suddenly want all this direction. They are contradicting themselves; they have been caught saying one thing and then saying something else.

The opposition, in standing up and speaking to the amendment, have made real idiots of themselves. They say, `We oppose this bill, but we think we'll wait until November to oppose it.' Senator Lees has made her argument quite clear. At least she has put up an amendment. She has actually spelled out the reasons why she thinks we should defer it. I do not agree with her, and I do not agree with the decision to defer it, but it puts her streets ahead of the opposition.

I remind Senator Lees that I do not think it is persuasive to say that the Early Childhood Association or the National Children's Services Forum will be looking at this area and coming up with all sorts of proposals. In the meantime, people cannot find places in child-care centres. If it is a fully work related child-care centre, then it is a matter of recognising the fact that unmet demand, which is one of the factors we take into account in allocating places, certainly means that there is a need for more places. But, in other parts of Australia besides urban Melbourne, there is still a large amount of unmet demand for work. That unmet demand for work is running alongside centres that have got places occupied by occasional care users.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where?

—That is just the data, Senator. They are the facts. I have already commented on the COAG paper. It is not about to change the nature of child care this week or next week. It is not about to recognise or create places or any of those things. It looks at how better we can balance child care and preschools.

PARA.TAB: Senator Troeth, that just reminds me of that extraordinary remark you made about what would happen if centres had to relocate. Over the years, centres have to relocate; kindergartens have to relocate; schools have to relocate. Talking about relocation reminds me to ask you: just how many school relocations has Premier Kennett put onto the Victorian people in the last 12 months? Just how many child-care centres and preschools has Premier Kennett relocated in Victoria? Of course relocation sometimes happens. In fact, Mr Kennett is making an art form of it. Community based centres may have to relocate; private centres may have to relocate.

On the whole, while we still have a large amount of unmet demand, we do not anticipate centres closing. It is certainly not my intention to see them closing. As much as possible, we are about helping them to change their charging practices, to create waiting lists and to test the water for the unmet demand across this country, particularly in Queensland and New South Wales, so that they can face the problems confronted by parents who are working and who cannot get a place for their children under two.

There is a massive demand. The demand is so significant that we are now looking at two levels of high need areas to assist centres in planning. We are drawing the high need areas on the current figures and drawing a new set of high need areas based on the needs for work related care for children under two. There are opportunities. There is still a lot unmet demand. We still have a skewing of the system in some parts. This process would have set this balance in train to get it right.

Senator Minchin, we are not driving a wedge between women at home and women at work. The opportunity for women to use occasional care and for women to use work related care has been part of the child-care policy since we set up this program and moved with the development of child care. You may want to argue about the difference between 12 hours, 10 hours and 14 hours, but it is also part of the process. It is not saying that this is a dramatic shift. We have always recognised the need for women at home to have the opportunity to use child care. To suggest that we are now cutting it out, that this is going to drive a wedge between families or that if you are at the tuckshop you cannot use child care is way over the top, Senator. You know it. You ought to apologise to people for so misrepresenting the facts. We are about making child care available to many more families than currently receive it. It is fair; it is appropriate; it is fiscally responsible.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Lees's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a correction to the explanatory memorandum relating to the Child Care Legislation Amendment Bill.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 26 June, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Electoral and Referendum Bill, which is, in effect, bill (No. 1). We had anticipated that both this bill and the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) would be debated together. I will certainly be speaking on the basis that the two bills are to be debated concurrently. My remarks will be directed to both bills.

PARA.TAB: From an opposition point of view, we do find the way in which the amendments to the Electoral Act are being dealt with very odd indeed. Why they are being split into two bills has never been made clear to us. Why we are not dealing with both bills together is still not all that clear to us. The process by which these bills are being dealt with is messy. The bills are a response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on the conduct of the 1993 federal election, yet we still have not had from the government a formal response to that report. It is normal for there to be a response and then legislation flows from that formal response to a committee report. That pays committees due respect. In this case we have the legislation before any formal government response to the committee report. That is most unsatisfactory.

Most of the recommendations in the report have bipartisan support and are implemented in these two bills. They are mostly technical and are designed to improve the conduct of federal elections. They deal with matters like silent electors, enrolment objection process, canvassing in hospitals and nursing homes, authorisation of advertising material, roll reviews, overseas electors, close of rolls, bulk nominations, interstate voting, and procedures relating to the Court of Disputed Returns. We do support this bill and bill (No. 2), which we had expected to be debating today as well, but we will be moving amendments to both bills. I would like to comment on a number of those specific issues and also on amendments proposed by the Democrats.

There is the matter of Australian Electoral Commission advertising, which is dealt with in this bill. The government proposes to remove the requirement that the writs for elections and notices relating to redistributions be advertised in not less than two newspapers circulating generally in each state or territory. The government wants to change that requirement to just one newspaper.

We really do not believe that the current requirement relating to newspaper advertisements should be changed. We do not see any reason for that. In our two larger states, the government's amendment could deprive a very large number of voters of information about elections. There are two newspapers circulating generally in both New South Wales and Victoria, but in each state one of the two newspapers has much lower circulation than the other. On that basis and given that it is possible under the amendment for the commission to choose in each of our two major states the newspaper which has the least circulation, we do not think this particular proposal is justified.

There is also an amendment relating to gender I wish to comment on. The government is proposing that information relating to the gender of voters be provided for the purpose of medical research and health screening surveys. We do support that amendment. However, we do propose that it be extended to allow gender information to be provided to senators, members and political parties. Our understanding is that the government is prepared to accept that proposal.

We put that proposal for a number of reasons. In commonsense there cannot be privacy implications about gender. One's gender is generally obvious. The proposal will ensure that MPs and political parties do address voters correctly and not get the gender wrong in writing to voters. It does acknowledge the fact that the major parties already have computer programs which enable them, with a fairly high degree of accuracy, to determine gender anyway. So we think it is sensible to allow that information to be provided, and we understand that the government accepts that.

There is also a matter of age discrimination, which I would like to mention. We do intend to move amendments to prohibit age discrimination within the Electoral Commission. We are waiting to see if the government can sort this matter out. Subject to receiving some information about that, we will proceed with our amendment. It is in response to complaints from many casual employees of the commission who are denied employment once they reach a certain age—and that is 65. The government has said the amendment we propose would put the AEC out of step with all other government agencies and that there would be a more appropriate legislative vehicle for removal—

TALK.START.PARA: —Hard luck.

—Yes. The government has been saying this for years and years. Colleagues of my mine who have been here longer than me say, `We've heard that one from the government before, and we still haven't seen anything.'

PARA.TAB: Paradoxically, I noticed in the media the other day that, in relation to the National Gallery, the government itself is considering amending legislation to allow Mrs Betty Churcher to stay beyond the compulsory retirement age of 65 years. The spokesman for the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Mr Lee, confirmed yesterday that amending the act was a possibility and could be done this year.

So the government itself is looking to do in relation to the National Gallery what we believe needs to be done in relation to the Australian Electoral Commission. So we really do not believe the government's opposition is well founded. However, if the government can convince us that it can make arrangements to allow casual employees over the age of 65 to be employed by the Electoral Commission, then we will certainly give that favourable consideration.

I want to refer to the matter of general postal voters. We acknowledge and express our gratitude that the government has accepted our proposal that voters on the register of general postal voters be sent ballot papers as soon as they are received by the relevant DRO without the need to complete a postal vote application form. As we say, we record our appreciation of the government for accepting what is a sensible reform. It will make it much easier for remote voters, in particular, to participate in elections. We will move an amendment to further improve the government's amendment, and we understand the government is prepared to accept that.

I will touch on the matter of prisoner voting. Although it is not dealt with directly in the bill before us, it is dealt with in the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2). I want to place on record our position on that matter. The government was originally intending to remove any restriction on the right of prisoners to enrol and vote. Following our strident opposition to that proposal and what was a remarkable community outrage about it, we are pleased to see the government has withdrawn that unacceptable proposition, although I understand it still remains part of the Labor platform. Labor still remains, in its platform, committed to letting all prisoners vote, no matter what the seriousness of their offence is.

We acknowledge that the current arrangements relating to prisoners are unworkable—that has been made quite clear to us—in that the disqualification refers to the maximum possible penalty for the offence and not the actual sentence being served. We do welcome the government's recognition of the need for some restriction on prisoners' voting rights, which they have now had to concede. We also agreed that it should be based on the actual sentence, which is what the government is proposing.

We have a strong view that the actual sentence which triggers the disqualification should be reduced from five years to 12 months. It is our view that if someone commits an offence serious enough to be placed in a prison for 12 months or more, they should lose the right to vote while they are in prison. Punishment of 12 months or more in prison should involve the loss of the entitlement to vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party just wants to win a few marginal seats.

—That would appear to be the case. The 12-month period was, of course, in the Electoral Act before Labor came to office. While it was based on maximum possible sentence, the period of disqualification was 12 months. We opposed the government when it changed it to five years, so our position is consistent. We have been consistent right throughout on this issue. I also make the point that it is consistent with the period of imprisonment which disqualifies someone from being a member of parliament. Frankly, we do not see why prisoners, some of whom have committed horrendous crimes, should be treated more favourably in relation to their right to vote than members of parliament are treated in relation to their right to sit in this place.

PARA.TAB: The change we propose would also bring the law into line with that prevailing in New South Wales, the biggest state and the state with the biggest prison population. In fact, half the prisoners in Australia are in New South Wales prisons. It therefore makes eminent sense for Commonwealth law to accord with the law in the state of New South Wales; that is, a 12-month disqualification.

I also note that the government was originally intending to prohibit canvassing within six metres of a divisional returning office or a prepoll voting office. We indicated our concern about that prohibition and we are grateful that the government has seen fit to remove that proposal. The government was also proposing, I think at the behest of the Electoral Commission, that preliminary scrutiny of declaration votes could commence on the Monday prior to polling day. We were also very concerned about the proposal. Again, we are grateful for the government's removing that proposition.

A very important issue that will be debated in the discussion of these bills is truth in advertising. Senator Lees, on behalf of the Democrats, will be moving an amendment to provide for truth in advertising which, in effect, will restore the old section 329(2) of the Electoral Act. Of course, that was put in by the Labor Party. The Labor Party itself introduced that section in 1983. It got close to the 1984 election and thought, `We might want to lie our way back into office in 1984. Let's get rid of this section as quickly as possible.' So they tossed it out.

We have given this matter very careful consideration in the meantime. We have taken a decision that we will support this amendment. It is our view that recent ALP advertising campaigns, at both the state and federal levels, have been so utterly dishonest and deceptive that a provision of the kind proposed is now required to ensure that Australians get honest elections. We call on the government to show its bone fides and support this amendment as well.

It is almost certain that the ALP will have already prepared an advertising campaign for the next federal election which is deliberately designed to mislead and deceive voters about coalition policies. We have no doubt that you have John Singleton and Bob Hogg beavering away, working out what outrageous claims they can make about coalition policies. You will say and do anything to lie your way back into office. When you announce the election, then you will see the policies. Just tell us when the election is.

TALK.START.PARA: —I Take a point of order: I think the senator opposite used a word that is not parliamentary, that being `lies'. I would ask him to remove it straightaway.

—If I can speak to that point of order; the word was used in the generic sense. It was not applied to any particular member of the Labor Party. It was used as a corporate entity and it is perfectly permissible under standing orders, as under the general laws of libel, to use it in that sense.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—I didn't actually hear the context in which it was said—

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order: as I understand the situation, Senator Minchin was referring to the Australian Labor Party and its operatives right around the country, and was not reflecting on a particular senator or a combination of senators on the other side. If he had said `Labor Party senators on the other side would lie their way back into the office,' that, I would submit, may well be unparliamentary and ought be withdrawn, but—
—Running around the country lying their way into office.
—Minister, would you mind? Just give it a rest for a while, would you? This is an important point of order. If you listen, you might even understand it.
—Order! Continue with the point of order.
—Reflecting on a political party which may or may not have representatives in this chamber is, with respect, not unparliamentary and therefore ought be allowed.
—I do not uphold the point of order. I take it that it was used in the generic sense, but I would caution Senator Minchin. It is probably a dangerous area in this debate.

—I note your words of caution. In the ideal world an amendment to provide for truth in political advertising should not be necessary. It would be much better if Australian political parties conducted themselves with some integrity and some respect for truth and honesty, then such a law would not be necessary. It is quite clear to us, following the ALP campaign, in particular, in 1993 that such a law is necessary. The ALP campaign in that election was, in our view, utterly dishonest and misleading.

PARA.TAB: We have now reached a point where the Electoral Act should make it an offence to produce electoral advertisements that are clearly dishonest and deceptive. We do not think any party should be able to mislead the electors in such a way that it gets back into office with impunity. That is our view of what happened in 1993. All those chickens will come home to roost in 1996.

We are going to support the proposed amendment. We challenge the government to accept this amendment in the interests of ensuring honest elections in Australia. I point out that such a provision, as proposed by the Democrats, has operated in South Australia in the South Australian Electoral Act since 1985. It was put in there by the Bannon Labor government. The Labor Party itself proposed this provision and put it into the South Australian Electoral Act. I had to work under that provision as a state director and was happy to ensure that all Liberal Party ads complied with the act.

There was never any challenge to any of our advertisements during my period as state director. The irony is that it was the state Labor Party secretary in South Australia who was successfully prosecuted for breaching the provision put in there by the Bannon Labor government for producing a misleading and deceptive ad in the state campaign of 1993. He now has a conviction recorded against him. This sort of legislation does work. It has been proved to work in South Australia and it should be part of the federal law.

We also have the situation where the Labor Party conducted one of the most deceptive campaigns in Queensland just this year. The Premier of Queensland has had to concede, at the behest of the coalition, that a provision of this kind will be installed into the Queensland Electoral Act. The Commonwealth should do likewise.

There are a few other matters I would like to raise in relation to electoral matters. The bill before us and bill No. 2 fail completely to address several other issues which we, the coalition, referred to in the joint standing committee inquiry into the 1993 election. That inquiry did reveal very widespread concern about the integrity of the Australian electoral system.

It is in fact the case that both the government and the Electoral Commission admit our system of electoral enrolment and voting is wide open to fraud and abuse. They make the claim that it is not being abused. They can see it is a walk in walk out, wide open system—a system designed purely on the basis of the honesty of those who seek to enrol. They say it is not being abused. They cannot prove that it is not being rorted. It is impossible for the government and the Electoral Commission to prove it is not being rorted. They cannot establish there is no systematic and endemic electoral fraud.

We have had a very recent case where fraud was revealed. A gentleman in Victoria, who was seeking to defraud the social security department, successfully enrolled, falsely, 12 individuals on the electoral roll. He was doing this in order to defraud the social security department because at that stage the social security department fairly unwisely relied on the electoral roll as one of its mechanisms for proving the identity of people. The department has since ceased doing that because it also realised how hopeless the electoral roll is to rely on people's identities.

That gentleman was convicted for getting 12 false enrolments. It was discovered by the fraud section of the Department of Social Security; it was not discovered by the Australian Electoral Commission. Clearly, the Electoral Commission has no mechanisms by which to detect these people. They cannot tell me how widespread this is, how many other individuals there are who have falsely enrolled 12 other people.

I gather that this gentleman had found people who had died some 50 years ago, put their names on the roll and found addresses for them. If those names had not been discovered, anyone could have voted in those names and no-one would have known the difference. There is no way to detect whether anybody had voted in the names of those 12 people. We have clear evidence of the rorting of the electoral roll but we do not know how widespread it is and the government cannot tell us.

The coalition members of the joint standing committee recommended in the face of all this that, to strengthen the integrity of the system, individuals claiming entitlement to enrolment should be required to provide the Electoral Commission with proof of their identity, together with evidence of citizenship, by production of a birth certificate, a current passport or a certificate of naturalisation. For the integrity of the electoral system which, as we say, is wide open to question, we also recommended that subdivisional voting be reintroduced.

We recommended that the Electoral Commission trial a system of voter cards in a by-election so that when people come to vote they have to establish who they are. Today you can just walk up and say that you are your next-door neighbour, vote in their place and no-one would know the difference.

The coalition members of that committee went on to say that section 245 of the Electoral Act, which compels electors to vote, be repealed. I do not want to pursue that cause at this stage but it was clear to us that the principle that everybody should be compelled to vote underlines the problem with the integrity of the electoral system. The theory seems to be that if you compel people to vote you have to make it as easy as possible for them to get on the roll and vote. Therefore, section 245 is a major factor in the weakening of the integrity of our electoral system and the accuracy of the electoral roll.

Unfortunately, the government has completely ignored this whole issue. Nowhere in any of these bills is there anything about that. It raises the question of whether the government is happy to preside over a system which is so wide open to fraud and abuse. All you have to do to get on the electoral roll is fill out a form and get it witnessed by another `elector', who could be anybody. That proves absolutely nothing.

I could easily enrol my 10-year-old son and no-one would know the difference. I am not going to do it—I am not going to break the law—but it would be so easy to do. All you have to do is send off a form in the mail. The Electoral Commission just checks to see if the name is on the roll already. If it is not, it is processed and you are on the roll. It is an absolutely hopeless system.

We are very concerned that the government has completely ignored this issue. It is negligent, in our view, in its determination to ignore increasing community concern about the integrity of our electoral system. This recent court case in Victoria exposes just how easy it is to rort the system.

We do not oppose this bill or bill No. 2—which, we presume, we will be debating next week, although that remains to be seen—however, there are some amendments that we propose. We will support the Australian Democrats' amendment in relation to truth in advertising. We are extremely disappointed that the bills do not go anywhere near far enough in dealing with the problems of the electoral system as identified in the joint standing committee inquiry into the last federal election.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also was expecting both the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1995 and the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 to be debated in this place today. After all, they both result from the inquiry into the conduct of the 1993 federal election and matters related to that election. As we have not had any formal response from the government, we presumed that those two bills together made up the bulk of the government's response.

PARA.TAB: I wish to draw the attention of the Senate to recommendation 9 of that inquiry, which relates to electoral funding and disclosure. Amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act to reflect that recommendation were passed in this place in June 1995. Senator McMullan acknowledged at the time that those amendments did not apply to the specific situation of the Australian Democrats, as we were a single registered party on a national basis, unlike other parties represented in federal parliament.

Assurances were given to us that situation would be rectified. However, despite continuing attempts from my office to address the deficiency and the problem, and several attempts by us to draw up our own amendments, we still have not had an undertaking from the government that they will support us on this issue. Hopefully, by the time we get through to the committee stage—which will now be around 5 o'clock today because we have a matter of public importance—we will have some firm undertakings in writing as to how we will proceed. I will still move the amendments we have had drafted—and they have been circulated—in the hope that we will have some concrete examples in writing of where the government believes we should be going.

I am concerned with some of the proposals, particularly those in the Liberal's foreshadowed amendments which would allow the gender of electors to be released for the purposes of medical research and health screening surveys. Our only concern with this is that the Privacy Commissioner needs to make it very clear that there would be no privacy implications. We have been led to understand that the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker) has written to the Privacy Commissioner asking for that advice, and I will be seeking clarification on that point during the committee stage. We would prefer it if a copy of that letter could be tabled before the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill is actually passed.

I would now like to deal specifically with the issue of truth in advertising, and I will begin by referring to an article in the Bulletin of 12 September 1995 which dealt with public attitudes to federal politicians. The article certainly does not make for very pleasant reading. It stated that 84 per cent of those surveyed believed that we lie at election time to win votes; 56 per cent claimed that they have lost faith in the federal political system; and 79 per cent said that they do not trust us to keep our election promises. I will not go into a debate now as to how much of that is a misinterpretation, how much is the media's fault, et cetera. It is a perception, and it is the perception that we now have to deal with. It is what the public believes, and it is certainly up to us to deal with what is a very alarming set of figures.

In 1983, the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform recommended a provision prohibiting misleading or deceptive advertising. A bill containing this provision was subsequently passed in December 1983, but this section was subsequently repealed, as has been already mentioned by Senator Minchin, in October 1984 before the federal election. So it was never tested and tried. The arguments that were later brought against it were very dubious, as it was never given the opportunity to be put into practice to see whether or not it actually worked.

The Australian Democrats have attempted on a number of occasions over the years to have that provision or a very similar one reinstated. I want to congratulate my former colleague Senator Michael Macklin, who attempted to do this by amendment in 1984, 1987 and 1989. In 1990, he introduced his own private member's bill, in frustration. Senator Cheryl Kernot similarly moved amendments in 1991.

As has already been said, in my home state of South Australia, the state Electoral Act does contain a very similar provision—one put in there by the Labor Party. After the 1993 state election, a successful prosecution was mounted under that particular provision. I am very pleased to say that for a range of reasons, as outlined by Senator Minchin, the opposition will now be supporting the Democrats' stance on this issue. We have changed our amendments slightly to take on board some, indeed all, of the Liberal Party's concerns. What our amendments now reflect is basically the South Australian legislation.

We have made a very careful assessment of the necessary changes and done all of that so that what we basically have almost verbatim is the South Australian legislation. Quite simply, the amendments that I will be moving in committee will make it an offence for an authorised person to print, publish or distribute any electoral advertisement which is untrue and is, or is likely to be, misleading or deceptive. The amendment allows a defence against prosecution if the person concerned can prove that he or she did not know that the material was untrue, misleading or deceptive. In addition, the provisions of this amendment will only be effective during the relevant period of an election.

Should the prosecution under the terms of this amendment succeed, as happened in South Australia, a person will be up for a penalty of only $1,000, and we have specifically excluded the possibility of a prison sentence from these amendments. If the offence is committed by a party or a corporate body, it is $5,000, and I have already had it put to me by people not in this place that that is nowhere near adequate.

We, however, believe that at least we need to take this first step and, if necessary, there may be some changes, some tightening or some alterations later down the track. But right now I believe what we should be looking at is the fact that the South Australian legislation has worked and that that legislation should be at least mirrored in Commonwealth legislation.

In the state parliaments now, and I think particularly after the Queensland election, there are also moves afoot to bring in these changes. As has been mentioned, both the Leader of the Opposition and the Queensland Premier have signalled that they will be supporting such measures and, I understand, are in the process of doing something about it. Recently, across my desk came a copy of a press release from a New South Wales state member, Michael Richardson. It was headed `Subject political advertising to the Trade Practices Act says MP'. So I think we have another state also moving along these lines.

One of the reasons for the removal of this provision that was given when it was taken out in 1984 was the fear that innocent people could be unwittingly charged with publishing misleading advertisements—for example, the printers of leaflets or perhaps some poor volunteer who is out letterboxing how-to-vote cards. In my amendment I have made it very clear that they cannot be affected. My proposed amendment is quite clear in that the only people who will be liable under the legislation are those who are authorising that material; in other words, the ones who authorise the publication or, in the case of television and radio ads, the broadcasting of such an advertisement.

I believe that we in this place should care about the cynicism, the indifference and the hostilities shown towards politicians by the electors. Unfortunately, that is very often evident as I address school groups. It is not so evident up front when addressing adult audiences, but it often comes out during questions. It is now over to the Labor Party to seriously consider—as this is going to pass through this house—their attitude to what Australians are telling us, and telling us very clearly; that is, that they believe we should take some concrete steps to clean up our act.

I believe we have an obligation to help restore people's faith and confidence in our system of government. I believe that a provision of this nature in the Commonwealth Electoral Act will send a clear signal to electors that politicians agree: lying, deceiving or misleading has got to stop. The electors demand it, and I believe they certainly deserve a better deal than they are getting at the moment. (Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill, which is before us. Before commencing my remarks, I congratulate Senator Nick Minchin on his contribution and recognise his expertise in this particular area, he having been involved with the Liberal Party at the administrative level for many years prior to his becoming a senator.

PARA.TAB: It might be trite to say but I think it is vitally important that we remind ourselves that our democracy is a very precious thing. Our democracy provides the structure for our laws and the way that our society operates. For democracy to work, people have to have faith in the system and they have to have faith in the legislative framework that underpins our democratic system and our democratic structure.

It is therefore essential that we be eternally vigilant in dealing with the legislation that governs our democracy and our democratic practices and continually finetune the legislation to ensure that people retain faith in our democratic system. So each time amendments are made to the Commonwealth Electoral Act it is vitally important that we seriously consider the consequences of those amendments and ask ourselves the question as to whether or not they support community feeling and attitudes towards our democratic system of government. I wanted to make those few initial comments before addressing matters of particular concern to me.

The first matter that I raise briefly is the issue of age discrimination, which has already been so ably mentioned by my colleague Senator Minchin. It seems to me quite inappropriate that the government, given that it is so strong on anti-discrimination, should discriminate against people on the basis of their age.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—I notice Senator Colston says, `Hear, hear!' It is nice to acknowledge some support from the other side of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: With my involvement in elections and having been at polling booths to cast my vote, I nearly always recognise a familiar face from the town in which I live. A lot of the polling clerks and people who assist at election time enjoy the extra bit of money it provides. However, those people also provide to the democratic system a wealth of knowledge and experience gleaned over many years as polling clerks. Just to say, `You've now reached the age of 65; you are therefore disqualified from providing that service to the community,' seems to me to be very short-sighted. Indeed, it reflects adversely on those people who have made a very considerable contribution to ensuring that the system does work on polling day. That, once again, is an important aspect of ensuring that our democratic system works—that, when people go to cast their vote, the system actually does work. The best way to make sure it works is to ensure that you have people who have a wealth of experience and knowledge. Usually those who are over the age of 65 have been within the community for some considerable period of time and are able to assist others whom they know through recognising them as coming from their own township.

Another matter I would raise is the issue of advertising in newspapers. Senator Minchin once again has made mention of the opposition's stance on that, and I simply would add my support to Senator Minchin's comments.

The question of prisoner voting is also a matter that I think needs to be addressed. Most people in this country, although they are very cynical about the democratic system and democratic structures, would join with Winston Churchill and others who have said, basically, that the democratic system is a bad system but it is the best. At the end of the day that is the sort of judgment we have to make. We have to ensure that people realise the importance of the democratic system and the role it plays within our societal structures. I therefore believe that if it is appropriate, because of criminal conviction, that you be disqualified from holding office within this parliament, it is equally appropriate that you be unable to vote until such time as you have served your sentence or your penalty. Once you have done that, of course, then you can seek to stand for office.

I understand the Australian Electoral Commission's concerns with the current legislation where it says that you are denied a vote if you are sentenced in relation to a crime or an offence which carries the potential of a five-year period of imprisonment. But, of course, just because that is the maximum penalty, the prison authorities do not necessarily know whether a person has been sentenced for a crime or an offence which carries such a potential tariff.

The Labor Party believes that all prisoners ought be allowed to vote. I think that undermines our democratic system, our democratic structure. If we as a community say, through the legal system, that somebody has misbehaved in such a gross way that their liberty should be taken away from them and they ought be locked up in gaol for a period of 12 months or more, then I think it also makes sense that we take away from them the liberty of the right to vote for that short period—more than 12 months or whatever it may be—they are incarcerated.

The Labor Party wanted to allow every prisoner to vote. We on this side raised a very effective community campaign, mainly through Senator Rod Kemp, the shadow minister for administrative services. As a result, the government said, `We will now amend to not allow prisoners to vote if they have been sentenced to a period of imprisonment of five years or more.' What that has done is relax the situation from the potential maximum of five years. We on this side believe that the more appropriate line would be to reduce it to a period of 12 months imprisonment. I believe that there is a lot of strength in that argument and it clearly gained widespread community support.

In my former life I often appeared in the courts looking after people who had fallen foul of the criminal laws of my home state of Tasmania. I think I am recognised within my party as somebody who is largely sympathetic to the cause of rehabilitating prisoners rather than trying to seek revenge on them. Indeed, at the last state council of my party, I received adverse publicity from certain elements in the community because they thought I was a bit too soft on the issue of law enforcement.

So it is with those credentials that I say that I still support the opposition proposal and approach to this matter on the basis that, if a community says your liberty is to be denied you, then during that time your liberty is denied for 12 months or more you should also be denied the right to vote. When you are released into the community after that 12 months or more of imprisonment, your right to vote will be returned to you.

The main topic I wanted to talk about was the importance of getting some credibility back into the system of our democratic structures. I refer, of course, to the issue of truth in advertising. The comments I made at the outset of my speech are very salient to the issue of truth in advertising. Senator Lees has set out the statistics on the cynicism towards politicians—that it is largely believed that politicians do not tell the truth and so on. Senator Lees has made out a very strong argument for the need of the amendments she proposes. It is interesting to note that the amendment being proposed is in fact legislation introduced by the Labor Party to amend the legislation. When they then realised it might impact on them, they quickly moved to amend it and strike it out of the legislation. I hope it is returned into the legislation.

As I said earlier, people have to have faith within our democratic system and its structures if we are to retain the excellent free lifestyle we enjoy in this country. We are indeed the envy of the world in relation to the freedoms we personally enjoy and enjoy as a country. So it is vitally important that people retain faith within our system. People can go around this country—and I cannot say `lying' because that is unparliamentary; and seeing that we are dealing with the issue of truth in advertising I suppose the negative of `truth' is usually `lying', but in this case I will say `untruths'—telling untruths, such as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) did during the last election. He said that if there were a Liberal government elected there would be a 15 per cent tax on everything. That was clearly untrue, clearly unsustainable, clearly not based on truth, clearly not based on fact, but it was hammered home time and time again.

It is very clear that the government had that sort of campaign in mind when it moved to amend the electoral legislation to ensure that the requirement of truth in advertising would be removed. They told many untruths about the opposition's policies on health and industrial relations, and we have many examples of that. Recently, in the state of Queensland, the Labor Party embarked on a most outrageous campaign, saying that hospitals would be sold off and that you would need to show a credit card before you could be admitted to the public hospital system. There was no statement of policy which supported that claim. It was just a bland assertion which was clearly untrue and which had no basis in fact. There was no document which would have enabled them to say, `Look, here is the proof positive of this assertion.' It was just a straight-out untruth.

In my home state of Tasmania, the people of Tasmania were assured two elections ago that the Labor leader, Michael Field, would do no deal with the Greens. A solemn promise was made that no deal would be made with the Greens. After the election result, Mr Field counted up the number of Labor and Green members and realised that the result would make a one-seat majority. So the promise that he writ in large letters was thrown out the window and he did his dirty little deal.

The people of Tasmania did not forgive Mr Field. When that deal collapsed 18 months later, the Liberal Party was elected by a landslide. Whilst Labor has Michael Field as leader—I hope they continue to have him as leader in Tasmania—I am sure the Liberal Party will be returned. But for 18 months the people of Tasmania had a government that they did not want and that they were promised by Mr Field they would not have. The state was thrown into economic confusion and political confusion. There was uncertainty everywhere, and our economy suffered badly because of that. Until people can have some degree of faith that the promises politicians make before elections are going to be adhered to, they will lose faith in the system and therefore undermine our democratic structures.

Another example of these broken promises is the Prime Minister's promises of tax cuts before the last election. Remember? He said, `These tax cuts are l-a-w, law.' After the election when he broke that promise, we on this side said, `That was an l-i-e.' The fact remains that the Australian Labor Party is the master of these sorts of campaigns. It promises one thing before the election and then it sneaks back into government and reneges on, or does the exact opposite of, that promise.

TALK.START.PARA: —No child shall live in poverty.

—Senator MacGibbon reminds us of Bob Hawke's promise that no child will live in poverty. The lies go on and on. The operatives within the Australian Labor Party are proud of the untruths they tell. Former Senator Graham Richardson, the powerbroker that got Paul Keating the prime ministership of this country, wrote a book bragging about the way he told untruths. He entitled his book Whatever it takes. It is not about morality, decency, integrity or honesty; it is about whatever it takes. If you have to do a bit of cheating on the side, if you have to do a bit of untruth telling on the side, if you have to do a bit of whatever it takes, it is okay because the ultimate goal is to win.

PARA.TAB: In winning at all costs, the Australian Labor Party has been undermining the very fabric and structure of our democratic system. We on this side of the house sincerely and genuinely believe in and support our democratic system. We do not want to see it continually undermined by operatives such as former Senator Richardson. We are more than willing to submit ourselves to the test of truth in advertising and of the truth of our promises because we have nothing to hide. We have nothing to be concerned about because we, as a matter of course, act on those sorts of principles.

It is a sad day when you have to actually write it into legislation to make sure that people tell the truth. But unfortunately that is required when you have operatives such as former Senator Richardson who ran his political life on the basis of `whatever it takes'. Senator Ray followed that up in recent times when he said that he was not concerned about fairness in politics; he was concerned about outcomes. I would like to think that we as leaders of the community are concerned about issues on a higher plane than simply winning at all costs. There are rules that ought to be abided by and there are appropriate standards of behaviour. The Australian Labor Party clearly shows that it cannot abide by them. Therefore, we join with the Democrats in supporting amendments which will require the Labor Party to be answerable to the people if it does not tell the truth in advertising.

I commenced my remarks by saying that it was absolutely important that we retain the confidence of the people in our democratic system and in our democratic structures. It is my submission to the Senate and to the Greens and Senator Harradine that the truth in advertising amendments will be a very big step in the right direction to show the people of Australia that at least we, as a combination of senators, see the importance of retaining standards and ensuring that people can have faith in our political system and our political structures. It will be interesting to see how the Australian Labor Party will vote on that proposed amendment.

I look forward to making further contributions during the committee stage. I trust that as a result of the amendments that this parliament passes, we will have a stronger Commonwealth Electoral Act and, as a result, people will have greater faith in our system of government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it two electoral amendment bills, including a bill for amendment of the referendum machinery provisions. The expectation on the opposition side was that both those bills would be debated cognately. That was the information we received in the months leading up to this debate. We learnt when the debate came on that we are going to deal only with the first of these bills. So I will confine my remarks to the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1995.

PARA.TAB: I use this opportunity to comment on the total inadequacy of the government to manage the program within the Senate. I have been here longer than anyone on this side of the chamber and I have never seen management worse than we have at present. We chronically run 40 or 50 bills behind schedule. There is no reason for it at all other than the inability of the government to run the program in the chamber. I say to the government that it is doing as good a job running the Senate as it is doing in the economy and with respect to employment in this country. They are all catastrophic. It is time it moved out and let someone in who can run this parliament and the country properly.

I want to touch on a few points because the technical part of the bill has been covered exceptionally well by my colleagues Senator Minchin and Senator Abetz. I would like to deal with the general proposition as to the need to amend the Electoral Act. There is an increasing concern in the Australian community about the electoral process. Is it fair and accurate? Increasingly, there is a concern that the longer the Labor Party stays in power, the process by which it attains power is not fair and accurate. It is very much binding on the government to make sure that, like Caesar's wife, with respect to the process by which it acquires government, it is beyond dispute and suspicion in any way at all.

The bill that is before us deals with amendments to the schedules to the Electoral Act. There are a series of amendments to schedule 1. The first one that I would like to comment on is the arrangements in the bill for the supply of goods and services by the Australian Electoral Commission to any person or body. I think that is worthwhile. I would like to propose that the Australian Electoral Commission be expanded and conduct all the elections for the states in the Commonwealth. I do so as a consequence of recent experience with the Electoral Commission in Queensland, which was as amateurish a performance as I have seen anywhere.

It takes a fair bit of capital to establish and maintain an electoral commission when we have elections every three or four years. I think we should try to amortise those costs by using the commission more, even if it means a small incremental expenditure in order to get value out of it for the taxpayer. I can remember when there was great resistance in Queensland to having a common electoral roll for the State and the Commonwealth. I remember arguing with members of the state parliament at the time—this is going back 15 or 20 years—who almost had the view that the electoral roll as it related to their own electorate was their personal fiefdom. They felt they could exercise control of that electoral roll by maintaining a state electoral register. Queensland was one of the last states to go on to the Commonwealth electoral roll.

While I agree very much with what Senator Minchin said about the integrity of the rolls—and I will have a considerable amount to say about that when the next bill comes before the Senate—clearly, the Commonwealth roll, with all its defects, was a big improvement on what we were faced with in Queensland.

A month or so ago, we had an election in Queensland. We saw the high farce which occurred with the Queensland Electoral Commission. There was very little security for the votes when they came in in their ballot boxes. A Liberal councillor who was acting as a scrutineer in one of the marginal electorates went to the counting place and found that the votes were unprotected and kept in the returning officer's garage. It was in the papers that many a vote was counted under the houses of the electorate returning officer. In one case in a marginal electorate the counting had to be held up for a day while a leaking hot water system which was under the house, presumably spraying water everywhere, was fixed. It meant that the count had to be suspended for 24 hours. This is comic opera stuff.

When a government is elected by a margin of 16 votes, as is the case with the present Queensland government, the electorate is entitled to know that the counting system has the maximum amount of integrity and professionalism. That is why I am in favour of one authority for the whole of the Commonwealth, if that can be brought about. I do not know if it can, but I would not think it was beyond the wit of the relevant state governments and the federal government to come to some agreement.

Quite obviously, any government that was using that facility would need to have effective representation on the management. It would be desirable, of course, if we had common electoral laws. For the life of me, I cannot see why we cannot have precisely the same law for a state election as we have for a federal election. It is only a degree of parochialism that stands in the way.

The rest of schedule 1 deals with deregistering voters, newspaper advertising, the printing of paper for ballot papers, getting rid of the watermark paper and using other secure printing, which they claim will provide some economic benefit for the taxpayer. It also deals with hospital polling, the counting of the Senate and the authorisation of posters. There is a proposition now that bumper stickers will carry the name and the authorisation of whoever authorises them in a party. I do not think that is a terribly important point because it is very hard to define that point. You get a whole range of bumper stickers in the community. Some of the more subtle political ones are often hard to identify as political advertising, but it is not a matter on which I am prepared to go to the barricades. The second schedule deals with the mechanics of the vote.

I would now like to turn to the amendment moved by the Democrats in relation to truth in advertising, because it is absolutely fundamental to the democratic electoral process that the parties do present themselves in an honest way to the electorate, otherwise there is simply no point in having a campaign. If the campaign is going to be an object of falsification by one or more parties, then there is no point in having that campaign. There are grounds for concern if we look at recent elections. It is, unfortunately, part of the ethos of the Labor Party that it has to win and win at any price and that the end justifies the means, and the end is the Lodge for the leader of the party.

Senator Abetz talked about the recent statement by Senator Robert Ray on that dreadful business where a candidate could not get preselection in Victoria for the Labor Party because he had a Greek name and another fellow from the trade union movement was selected in his place. While I have very great respect for Senator Robert Ray, he made the astonishing statement in public that he was not interested in fairness; it was outcomes that mattered. Outcomes are really what the Labor Party is all about.

On a different plane, we have a problem with the Australian community because expectations over the years have been raised to such a high level by promises of political parties at election campaigns. I think the front page of today's Australian has a quote from the author who received a book prize yesterday. This young man wrote a largely autobiographical book about his generation. He made the claim there that expectations have been raised to such a level that they are unfulfillable for the generation now entering the community and the work force and that there is a great deal of disappointment as a consequence of that. The political process has to accept part of the blame for that. When we hear claims made by Mr Hawke some years ago when he was Prime Minister that no child should live in poverty by 1990, that is a gross travesty of the truth and something we should not permit, as a responsible body.

In one sense I wonder why the ALP is opposing truth in advertising because it is a master of the whisper campaign. You only have to look at the last election where the three things that cost us the election were the GST, Medicare and the industrial relations policy. I know that in my own state, the union movement ran a violent and quite incorrect campaign with all the industrial employees in the state.

The unions went and demanded, as they can under the industrial relations law, the right to meet workers in all the industries, who were all brainwashed with a very false presentation of what our industrial relations policy was in the last election. That did not require any expenditure of funds on public advertising at all, but it was very effectively used against us.

The same for the Medicare debate through the hospitals and through the community: at all avenues, you had people spreading a great deal of misinformation by word of mouth saying that we are going to abandon Medicare and all sorts of other nonsensical things. But over and above everything else, we had the great campaign run against the GST. In that there was not an element or shred of truth in anything that the Labor Party came up with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on! You were just stupid.

—I am glad you interjected, Mr Secretary, because I am interested in the way the economic analysts are now saying and showing that the Australian community is paying more in indirect taxes today than they would have if we had introduced a 15 per cent GST. So we have all the negatives of the sneaky indirect taxation scheme coming out of the Labor Party and none of the benefits in stimulating the economy that would have come with a GST.

PARA.TAB: The other thing we have had from this government in support of this campaign of disinformation is to not only go beyond issues but to go to the very concept of truth itself. Anyone listening to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) or Mr Beazley or, least of all, this empty vessel over here, Senator Cook, talking about—
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we will now proceed to debate matters of public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I wish to make a brief contribution on the topic of Taiwan and its acceptance or otherwise in the international community. Taiwan, or the Republic of China, has a population of some 21 million people and is an island nation. In recent decades, Taiwan has transformed itself from a primarily agriculturally based economy to a technologically advanced economic powerhouse. Its stores of foreign reserves of over $100 billion are the second highest in the world and represent, in great contradistinction, about the same sum that we are in debt. Moreover, with over $160 billion in annual foreign trade, it is the world's 14th largest trading nation.

PARA.TAB: From 1952 to 1987, Taiwan's economy grew at the rate of over nine per cent. Over the last five years, real gross national product has increased at an annual rate of more than six per cent. Taiwanese per capita income is nearly $12,000 per annum. Clearly, Taiwan is an economic powerhouse.

Taiwan is becoming more involved in international trade and monetary negotiations. Its recognition in that area is very well earned. Indeed, it has 130 economic, trade or diplomatic offices around the world. Non-government organisations such as Rotary, Lions and other bodies hold international conferences in Taiwan. They seem to recognise the role Taiwan plays within the international community.

Taiwan has its own defence force, its own body politic and, of course, its own distinct economy, which I have just highlighted. It therefore seems appropriate that we as a world community provide such support to assist Taiwan in its integration into the mainstream world community. Having said that, I acknowledge that there are certain sensitivities and certain matters of pragmatism that need to be taken into account. However, I believe that it would be of assistance to the world community at large if avenues could be explored to integrate Taiwan further into the world community.

Although Taiwan currently is not a member of the United Nations, it ought be remembered that it was. It was expelled from the United Nations in 1971 not because it had done anything wrong or its activities were unacceptable to the world community, but because the United Nations was forced to make a decision between the People's Republic of China and Taiwan, or the Republic of China. Basically, they both had the proposition: `It's one or the other. You cannot have us both.' That intransigence on both sides, I think, unfortunately worked to the detriment of an international resolution between the People's Republic of China and the Republic of China and their general integration into the world community.

TALK.START.PARA: —It disenfranchises millions of Taiwanese.

—As Senator Baume says, the population of Taiwan is 21 million people, a population greater than Australia's. It has been expelled from the United Nations not because of any atrocities, not because of anything that you might say makes it unfit to be a member of the United Nations, but simply because the United Nations was given a choice: it is either the People's Republic of China or the Republic of China, more commonly known as Taiwan.

PARA.TAB: If you were to put the human rights records of the People's Republic of China and the Republic of China next to each other, if you were to put the level of democracy in those two countries, individual liberties and freedom, et cetera, next to each other, I think Taiwan would come out on top. I make the comment, just as an aside, that Taiwan has never engaged in testing nuclear bombs in our region.

It is unfortunate that Taiwan has not been fully integrated as it would like to have been. Part of the reason is that it has insisted that it was the government for all Chinese. That was difficult to maintain and sustain, given that the greater number of Chinese lived on the mainland of China in the People's Republic of China.

As I understand it, the Taiwanese people are now adopting a more pragmatic approach and acknowledge that there might be two distinct governments looking after two sets of Chinese people—such as North and South Korea, North and South Vietnam and East and West Germany. There is, in my view, a lot of merit in pursuing an avenue which explores the possibility of us seeing whether a similar approach could be taken to integrating Taiwan further within the world community.

I was allowed to speak prior to Senator Baume, who kindly gave way to me because I have another commitment. I will not speak for much longer other than to say I wish to draw to the attention of the Senate an article in the Free China Review published in May 1995 entitled `In search of fairness'. It is an interview with the Republic of China's Foreign Minister, Fredrick Chien. I must say the developments that have taken place in Taiwan in recent times—democratic elections for President for next year, things of that nature—are all steps in the right direction. As a result, I believe it is worthy to explore the possibilities of assisting an outcome which could satisfy both the People's Republic of China and the Republic of China to allow Taiwan to take its rightful and appropriate place in the world community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join Senator Abetz in hoping there may be some way of resolving this problem. Perhaps there is a role for Australia as an honest broker in this matter so that we end a situation where mainland China cannot apparently get on with Taiwan because the Republic of China still does, as I understand it, express some claims over mainland China.

PARA.TAB: I am glad to see that the Republic of China is now calling itself Taiwan in publications, which it would not do in the past. That seems to me to be the beginning of some kind of major concession. I find it dreadful that 21 million people should be disfranchised in front of the world forum of the United Nations, particularly, as Senator Abetz said, as they have not been guilty of doing anything and in fact are a significant and respected trading partner of Australia. I must say I hope this matter can be resolved.

However, I do not think we can sit by and hope that as mainland China becomes more and more democratised as it is and much more a member of the world trading scene, it will adopt a more relaxed approach to Taiwan.
