There may well be a risk that as China becomes more of a competitor with Taiwan in a free market sense there may be greater commercial pressures for it not to accept the existence of Taiwan. In any event, it is a matter of great importance.

The matter I wish to deal with relates to an incredible and discriminatory decision taken by this government by way of regulation in respect to Austudy that unfairly and appallingly ill-treats small business people, self-employed people, the battlers who have suffered so much under this government. In discriminatory and disgraceful regulations that are still capable of being put aside by this parliament—but only until tomorrow—this government has tried to solve the serious problem of the rorting of Austudy by many people by hammering, grossly unfairly, those people who are not rorting the system at all but who just happen to be self-employed people, small business people, the people that this government has become almost infamous for ill-treating.

What particularly disturbs me is that the government's justification for these atrocious and oppressive regulations does not reveal in any way the extent of the damage being done to self-employed people, small business people, throughout the country. In other words, what the government is setting out to do is right and proper and would have the total support of the opposition because it seeks to stop a lot of the rorting of Austudy. The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Mr Free, said earlier this year when he introduced these regulations that they:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . will focus the financial help provided by the taxpayer more sharply on those students most in need of assistance.
He goes on:

The purpose of AUSTUDY is to assist financially disadvantaged Australian students to complete secondary education and gain an initial tertiary qualification . . . Fine tuning of AUSTUDY not only shows the Government's commitment to helping those most in need of help, but also meets concerns in the community that benefits provided by the Australian taxpayer should go where they are intended.
Hear, hear! The release went on:
. . . the Government had listened and responded to concerns that AUSTUDY income tests based on taxable income did not always reflect the whole picture of a family's financial situation.
There is no doubt about that. I think it was a Senate committee in which Senator Tierney was involved that called for much better targeting of Austudy. Mr Free went on:
There are more than 500,000 students receiving benefits this year; overwhelmingly, those who receive help are those for whom it is intended.
Now, let's get that straight. The great bulk of Austudy payments are for those `for whom it is intended'. Mr Free goes on:
There are, however, wealthy families whose taxation arrangements do not reflect the strength of their real financial position. When they receive benefits, others in the community voice concern.

I must say I would be one of those who would voice concern that taxpayers are being ripped off by people who have arranged their finances simply to take advantage of this kind of benefit. Mr Free goes on:

Under tighter targeting measures additional information will be sought from some students, particularly those with access to complex company or other financial structures, when they apply for help from the taxpayer.

We have already found out that it is only at the margin that there are problems and that additional information is sought from `some students', particularly those with `complex company or other financial structures'. The words sound quite reasonable. It is fact that the actions bear no relation to the words that I am worried about. In any event, Mr Free says:
The new income-testing measures will come into effect on 1 January 1996 and the expected savings to the Budget will be $13.5 million in 1995-96, rising to around $29 million per year.
In other words, the object of this exercise is not to provide Austudy benefits to other people in financial difficulties or lower income earners but to reduce the payments overall.

PARA.TAB: I certainly have no complaint about that except that there are many people at the margin who would rather see that money directed to others on low incomes. If the government is seeking to try to do what the opposition has continually called upon it to do, and that is to make certain that there is no waste in its expenditure—Senator Calvert is an expert in the study of this government's waste—this is an approach that should be endorsed.

In particular, the object of this exercise is to stop many rich families, particularly those coming from overseas, from having assets and income overseas which is, in a sense, hidden from Australian authorities. So there are people with big houses, with multiple cars and so on, professing to be poor for income tax and Austudy purposes when, in fact, their assets are considerable. I commend one element of this tighter targeting. Mr Free says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . AUSTUDY will also be targeted to students who have a long term commitment to contribute to the Australian community.
that is, those who are non-Australians—

Under the new provisions AUSTUDY will not be available to permanent residents who choose not to take out citizenship by the third anniversary of their entry into Australia as a permanent resident, or the grant of permanent resident status, whichever is the later.
I agree with that. People who come here who have permanent resident status should take out citizenship if they want to get the benefit of this kind of assistance paid for by Australian taxpayers.

PARA.TAB: My concern is that what the government is doing is nothing of the sort in terms of limiting it only to people who are rich. In fact, it is revealed in regulation 12L that this hits almost every self-employed person, almost every small business, and it may well hit every employee who is involved in a superannuation fund. This is simply a mixture of pig-headedness, of a heavy-handed approach to small business and of monumental incompetence, because these are the people who no longer will be able just to have taxable income taken as the guide. They will have to put in great detail about their expenditure and savings in order to get entitlement to Austudy.

This regulation says that it will apply to anyone who has an interest in an asset located outside Australia. Now it does not say `a large asset'; it just says `an asset'—in other words, anyone who, for example, may have worked in the United Kingdom and had deductions for their retirement income taken out of their pay, which eventually they will become entitled to when they are 65. That is an asset located outside Australia even though they do not have access to it. So all people like that will now have to jump this new, additional, expensive hurdle.

It could be anyone who has an interest in a proprietary company which is a little family company. It does not say `big' company; it does not say that it is a complex arrangement. So while Mr Free says that it is aimed at stopping those people `with access to complex company or other financial structures', what the regulation says is that anyone who has an interest—no matter how small, how minute, how inconsequential—in a proprietary company or an unlisted public company is now forced into this new, expensive and difficult test. It is also anyone who has an interest in a trust, anyone who derives income—not large amounts of income, but any income whatsoever—from a source outside Australia. It is anyone who is self-employed. I must say I am glad to see that the authoritarian bureaucrat who phrased this—and I hope the minister was not aware of the consequences of it—did at least exclude primary producers from this factor, but it is anyone who is a self-employed person.

Now self-employed persons, in so many instances in Australia, are those people who lost their jobs in the recession and had the determination and will to set up their own little businesses. Sometimes they are domestic cleaning businesses or they could be simply a gardening business, but it is anyone who is self-employed—and, of course, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has said to them that this is as good as it gets. Anyone who is self-employed has to jump through this new hoop. Their taxable income is no longer to be available.

Anyone who is a partner in a partnership—a husband and wife partnership in, say, a domestic cleaning situation—is no longer entitled to the normal qualification arrangements for Austudy for their children. Have you ever heard of anything more oppressive, more nonsensical, more incompetent? I hope it is only incompetence. It would be very disappointing if it was malevolently aimed at the entrepreneurial spirit of small business. That is what it seems to be aimed at.

It seems to be aimed at hitting those people who are, if you like, off their backsides working to try to improve themselves. I agree that there must be better ways of determining Austudy entitlements than have taken place so far. But the fact is that the government has gone over the top in this matter. I do not know how much of the $13.5 million in the current financial year, or the $29 million to be saved next year, is to be saved at the expense of a husband and wife partnership or a self-employed person. Quite frankly, they seem to me to be the heart and soul of the spirit of individualism in Australia. They are the people this government is specifically targeting. The government is going to save money at the expense of these people.

In no instance does this say that there is any discretion to allow these people to have income regarded as the normal income test. There is no discretion. If you have an asset, or an investment in a proprietary company, or an interest of any kind, or you are self-employed, there are no exemptions. If you are a partner, there are no exemptions. And yet they say they are aimed at complex company or other financial structures. The gap between what we were told by the minister and the regulations presented to this parliament is an absolute disgrace!

There can be no justification for any minister in this government presenting a statement of explanation which is so dramatically different from reality when it is presented to the parliament. I hope that the minister will reconsider, particularly the fact that so many superannuation funds are clearly the equivalent of trusts of various kinds, which may well mean that the great bulk of Australian workers are no longer entitled to have the normal entitlement to Austudy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the moment there are customers of Telstra who, for many years, have also been casualties of Telstra. For years they have experienced problems with dead lines, lines dropping out, busy signals when it was not busy and many more. They complained, even to the point of not paying their bills and having their phones cut off, which they desperately needed for their business, all in a desperate plea to Telecom to fix their lines.

PARA.TAB: In one member's case, there was acknowledgment of lines being physically removed, with Telecom officers stating that there was a prima facie case existing for conviction if the offender could be found. These were all once successful business people, with the type of business that relied on a telephone service fit for their purpose: a service they did not receive. Eleven years after their first complaints to Telstra, where are they now? They are acknowledged as the motivators of Telecom's customer complaints reforms. As a direct result, a telecommunications industry ombudsman has been set up and a complaints resolution process established. But, as individuals, they have been beaten both emotionally and financially through an 11-year battle with Telstra. Now their bankers have lost patience with their lengthy dispute settlement and they are going down fast.

Following an investigation of the initial settlement, accepted under duress, Austel, the industry watchdog, came out with a highly critical report of Telecom and the settlement was re-opened. The Austel report concluded that Telecom was less than a model corporate citizen—damning words for our nation's monopoly telecommunications provider which, at that stage, was entering a new period of competition. It recognised Telecom's failure to undertake preventative rather than corrective maintenance on its older analog equipment, some dating back 30 years, as a significant cause of persistent, intermittent faults and that Telecom had clearly put supply side efficiencies ahead of customer concerns.
There is the admission by Telecom to Austel:

SPEECH.PARA: It is of little or no bearing on the case that some of the testing has been purged from the system because we do not require these records to be convinced that this customer has serious concerns with her telephone service.

Backing up the Austel inquiry were critical reports by Coopers and Lybrand, describing Telecom complaints handling as not meeting the minimum requirements of `adequacy, reasonableness and fairness', and a technical review by Bell (Canada) of Telecom's testing and fault-finding techniques for network faults. Then followed the Federal Police investigation into Telecom's monitoring of COT case services. The Federal Police also found there was a prima facie case to institute proceedings against Telecom but the DPP, in a terse advice, recommended against proceeding.

PARA.TAB: To this day the parties of the parliament have been denied any access to the Federal Police inquiry or advice from the DPP on the matter—despite persistent demands not only from the coalition but from the Democrats—or matters of the DPP wrongly advising the Federal Police that Telecom was protected by the shield of the Crown and that they could not execute a search warrant against Telecom in their investigations of alleged phone monitoring and tapping.

Once again, the only relief COT members received was to become the catalyst for Telecom to introduce a revised privacy and protection policy. Despite the strong evidence against Telecom, they still received no justice at all. Meanwhile, COT members were still experiencing poor telephone services, their businesses were continuing to suffer and they had been forced to enter the exhausting and expensive process of involvement in all these major inquiries into Telecom.

A Senate inquiry began to be mentioned by senators on this side and the Democrats. In late 1993, Senator Alston and I, at a meeting in Senator Alston's Parliament House offices, were given an assurance by senior Telecom officers that a Senate inquiry would not be necessary—that a fast track, non-legalistic process could be set up, that it would facilitate FOI access to Telecom's documents and that it would be all over by April 1994. That process was to be overseen by the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman. FOI documents from Telecom show that Telecom certainly did not want a Senate inquiry when they refer to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . walking away, but I do not believe this option would suit Telecom's wider strategy in that it would appear to lead directly to a Senate inquiry.

PARA.TAB: My course therefore is to force Gordon Hughes—

SPEECH.PARA: the arbitrator—
to rule on our preferred rules of arbitration.

A fast track settlement proposal was signed by the four COT members in November 1993 and the fast track arbitration procedure on 24 April 1994, involving a confidentiality clause forbidding COT members any further public comment on Telecom. Even during this period of negotiations on the arbitration rules, FOI was being held up by Telecom. One Commonwealth Ombudsman's report on delays in FOI information condemns Telecom's denial of documents in the following words:

It was unreasonable for Telecom to require the participants to make further assurances while Telecom was considering the arbitration agreement and thereby denying participants the opportunity to consider the rules that Telecom wished to have included in the agreement.
I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator McMullan): is this fair play on the part of Telecom? The report goes on:
There is no provision in the FOI Act which would permit Telecom to impose such conditions on applicants prior to granting access to documents—access under the FOI Act is public access.

These COT members have been forced to go to the Commonwealth Ombudsman to force Telecom to comply with the law. Not only were they being denied all necessary documents to mount their case against Telecom, causing much delay, but they were denied access to documents that could have influenced them when negotiating the arbitration rules, and even in whether to enter arbitration at all.

PARA.TAB: This is an arbitration process not only far exceeding the four-month period, but one which has become so legalistic that it has forced members to borrow hundreds of thousands just to take part in it. It has become a process far beyond the one represented when they agreed to enter into it, and one which professionals involved in the arbitration agree can never deliver as intended and never give them justice.

Firstly, it was represented to members that it would be fast. It was called a `fast track arbitration process'. There were many documented assurances given to the COT members on timing and a quick resolution. The assurance was given by Telecom to the deputy Liberal Party Senate leader, Senator Alston, and to me, the leader of the National Party in the Senate, late in 1993 that it would be fast track and non-legalistic and would facilitate FOI documents.
There is the letter from Peter Bartlett, special counsel to the TIO, on 25 February 1994 saying:

SPEECH.PARA: The emphasis is on "fast track" resolution of these claims.
It stated also:
With this in mind the arbitration is likely to commence this week and will be completed at the shortest possible time frame.

There is the detailed timetable from the TIO scheduling the final report after four months. Then there have been the delays caused by Telecom's FOI documents. The Commonwealth Ombudsman has twice reviewed Telecom FOI delays and has been very critical of, in her words, `Telecom's defective administration'.

PARA.TAB: There have been further delays, referred to by the ombudsman as `unreasonable', because Telecom sent FOI documents to be vetted by their lawyers before release to members, and delays caused by the destruction of documentation—in the case of the Tivoli Restaurant, all Telecom's raw data on testing from 1989 to July 1993. What this has meant is that the COT members, as Telecom has drip-fed their FOI, have had to resubmit their statements to the arbitrator to include the delayed information.

To give an example of the experience of COT member Ann Garms with FOI documents, she applied to Telecom for FOI in December 1993. In February she received approximately 10,000 documents. In April the arbitration procedure was signed; then in May 20,000 more documents turned up. From May to December 10,000 more documents were drip-fed, continuing till June this year—all for a process promised to be completed within four months.

This is a situation of the might of a monopoly like Telecom, with all the resources behind it—said to add up already to millions of dollars—which has to be countered by four struggling business people. And now, despite assurances of fast track, which bankers and other supporters were reassured was the guiding principle of the arbitration, 18 months later the four suffering COT members are left with only one COT case settled and Telecom has made the non-legalistic arbitration process so legalistic that it has cost one COT member nearly $300,000 to answer Telecom's protracted process.

There have been many scathing reports of Telecom's defective behaviour by Austel, Coopers and Lybrand, the TIO and the Commonwealth Ombudsman. A second Commonwealth Ombudsman report is due out any day—with the first going so far as recommending compensation from Telecom for any costs unnecessarily incurred because of the defective administration by Telecom, which ironically now involves another costly mediation process for the COT members involved. The TIO, in his annual report, described the whole process as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . clearly the low water mark of effective customer relations, regulatory agency response and questionable direction from past management.
He continues:

Regrettable reliance on excessive legalism and failure to meet freedom of information requirements in a timely fashion has led in my view to an unnecessary prolongation of a process which was intended to be speedy.
The expense these COT members have been put to, arising from the so-called fast track arbitration process, has seen several go to the wall.

PARA.TAB: I regard it as a grave matter that a government instrumentality like Telstra can give assurances to Senate leaders that it will fast track a process and then turn it into an expensive legalistic process, making a farce of the promise given to COT members and the inducement to go into arbitration. The process has failed these people and can never give them justice—a point confirmed by professionals deeply involved in the arbitration process itself and by the TIO's annual report, where conclusion is described as `if that is ever achievable'.

The COT members would never have opted for arbitration had they known it would go on so long at a cost of hundreds of thousands of dollars in legal and other expenses. Here are people who Telecom knows are on their knees, and the system becomes so legalistic that, to answer two Telecom requests for further particulars, it requires an additional $45,000. These people have had their lives ruined by the process that has followed from daring to take on Telecom. It does not stop there. Many people have lent COT members funds to see them through the process based on assurances given by Telecom to Senator Alston and I and written assurances from the TIO that disputes would be settled within months, also risking their houses and businesses because of the outrageous delays.

Telecom has treated the Parliament with contempt. No government monopoly should be allowed to trample over the rights of individual Australians, such as has happened here. It brings me no joy to bring this matter before the Senate. I would rather be here praising Telstra, an Australian icon. But they are not bigger than the Australian people and, through them, the parliament. Telecom has been highly criticised by many government watchdogs all through the process, yet sadly, it is the poor struggling Telstra customers who are having to bear the ultimate burden of financial ruin.
Motion (by Senator Sherry)—by leave—agreed to:
That the sitting of the Senate be suspended till 2.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Cook, the Minister representing the Treasurer. It follows the revelation after all the bluster and hypocrisy of recent times that Labor has a secret policy agenda. I ask: Minister, when will you do what you demand of us and put that policy agenda on the table? As all new Labor policies cost money, how do you intend to pay for these new policies? Where is the money coming from? Do you intend to blow out the deficit again? Are you preparing the Australian people for further tax increases, or will Mr Keating just lie to the Australian people as he did on the last occasion?

—The answer to this question is none of the above—none of the things that were contained in the question, none of the speculation that was contained in the question. It is extraordinary that the opposition parties, who have absolutely no policies at all other than policies in industrial relations, who today at the MTIA conference told a major employers body in this country that they actually endorse a lot of the things that the government is doing and who also told a major employers body which held a conference to find out what the coalition would do in government that they could not tell them what they would do in government, should come in here and ask us about our policies.

PARA.TAB: Our policies are out there and working. They are out there and working because we have strong and sustainable economic growth in this country, anticipated to be 3.7 per cent this year. We are creating about 1,000 jobs a day in this country. We have continuing low inflation in this country as a consequence of—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a lie.
—It is not a lie. You're the liar.
—Senator Short, withdraw that comment, please.
—I said what he said was a lie.
—I thought you referred to him as a liar.
—No.
—I still think that is improper use.
—Mr President, I presume your hearing did not enable you to hear Senator Cook say, `You're a liar.'
—Oh, sit down!
—The boot is squarely on that side of the chamber. I presume you will deal with that.
—Order! If Senator Cook said that, I would ask him to withdraw.
—I withdraw it, Mr President. Let us just pause for a minute, because the interjection related to in fact—

—Mr President, on a point of order: the issue is relevance. The question related to Mr Keating's statement yesterday that the government was going to make some major new policy announcements. That is what the question was about. Could you address the question and tell us when these policies are going to be announced and how much it will cost the taxpayer? That is the question.
—There is no point of order for the reasons that I have stated many times before.
—Mr President, on the point of order—
—There is no point of order. I just ruled on it.

—Mr President, can I seek from you an explanation. The question related to the new policy commitments by the government. Senator Cook is talking about what he alleges to be the coalition's policies. Could you kindly explain to the Senate and to the Australian people how that answer is relevant to the question that Senator Hill raised?
—As I have stated many times before, and I do not think I should have to state it again, when a question—
—Yes, you should.

—Order! When a question is asked in such a broad fashion, it almost asks for a broad answer. In any case, Senator Cook had only commenced his answer, and I am not in a position to judge how relevant or irrelevant it is.

—The interjection from Senator Short was about inflation. I was talking about our policies because our policies are about low inflation and maintaining in Australia a low inflation environment—something that we have achieved for the last three years; something that you could never achieve when you were in government. Let me just ask this question: what was the level of inflation when John Howard was last Treasurer? About 11.3 per cent. What is it now? The underlying rate is 1.9 per cent.

—Mr President, could you explain how that could possibly be relevant to the question that was raised by Senator Hill? Could you give us some guidance on how you interpret relevance and whether you plan to take this Senate down the Leo McLeay road or whether you propose to enforce proper standards of relevance?

—On the point of order: as I remember Senator Hill's question, he did challenge that any new policies by this government may well lead to an increase in costs. I would have thought that Senator Cook, in explaining low inflation, makes that point very relevant to his answer.

—My point of order goes to the senators who, since the commencement of this question time and Senator Cook's answer, have risen to their feet and addressed you but without taking a point of order and by just shouting across the chamber. I do not believe that these senators—that is, Senator Alston and on two occasions Senator Kemp—should be recognised by you. There is no entitlement for a senator, not even under the guise of a point of order, to take his feet and address the chamber. I ask you to rule out of order in future any senator who attempts to do that.
—Yes, Faulkner.
—Order! There is an increasing tendency for people to yell out quite rudely and to reflect on the chair. Such reflections on the chair in the future will be taken much more seriously.

—I apologise for bringing in this debate, but I was interjected upon by Senator Short and I replied to the interjection by quoting the coalition's record on inflation against ours—and I will argue that anywhere. Since the interjection went to my honesty, I say to Senator Short that the honesty is all on this side of the chamber—not on that side of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: The opposition has asked me what our new policies are. Our policies will continue the spectacular high levels of job creation that we have enjoyed under this government compared with that under the previous government. When John Howard was last Treasurer the average new number of jobs per year was 51,300. Under us, it has risen by 163,600. We will continue to do that. We will do it because the Accord stipulates 600,000 in the new term of office. We have created 670,000 jobs so far in this term of office, given that our promise was 500,000.

We are a government of energy; we are a government of vision; we are a government of renewal. We will be bringing down policies which will show a vision for the future of this country at an appropriate time. When we do it, we tell you about it. But I tell you one thing for sure: our budget will be balanced and in surplus. Our budget will continue to move into greater surplus—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! On my left.
—We will have a national savings strategy. We will continue with our superannuation strategy so that people of Australia can enjoy dignity in their retirement. (Time expired)

—That was very confusing. I think the minister could have said it is a government of 750,000 unemployed. This morning's article apparently picks up the Prime Minister advising caucus of a new policy on communications; energy, which sounds to me like a new tax; housing and regional infrastructure, which sounds like big money; innovation, which is the matter that the Prime Minister has taken out of your hands, Senator Cook, after a year of waiting for your innovation statement; and forests, where there certainly is a policy vacuum at the moment. I ask: why will you not reveal the detail of these policies now, or is it that, as was said in this morning's paper, you want to release them at a time in order to maximise the political impact?

—Our policies will be released so that the people of Australia can see what we are proposing for the next term of government, be able to analyse the detail of what we are proposing for the next term of government and decide about the efficacy of our policies.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections. I remind you once again that this is the national parliament.

—The people of Australia will not be ambushed at the last minute on the eve of an election, like the opposition intends, so that the details of its policies are kept secret and the people of Australia do not know what it stands for. In our case they will have a clear, well thought out presentation of the detail, and they will have it well enough in advance to make a judgment. It will be policy that shows renewal, energy and vision, and that shows drive for reform and change and improvement in living standards in Australia.

PARA.TAB: In short, our policy package, which will come down later on, will in fact be a blueprint for Australia in the post-2000 era. It will not be the shallow, superficial—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also directed to the Minister, this time in his capacity as Minister for Industry Science and Technology.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! We cannot hear the person who is asking the question.

—Minister, the Australian economy is now in the fifth consecutive year of economic growth. This long period of growth has been marked by low inflation and high employment creation. Can you, Minister, advise the Senate of how investment has been affected by these economic conditions? In particular, can you inform the Senate of two major investment decisions which were given some prominence in the media last week—namely, Cathay Pacific's investments, and the Hokushin Medium Density FibreBoard Plant in Tasmania?

—It is important to look at investment performance in the Australian economy, because the performance of the investment indicator does indicate the underlying strength of the economy—and certainly a strength that those in the coalition would try to deny. For the year 1994-95, business investment in Australia rose by 16 per cent. Those of you in this chamber might recall that, on the eve of the budget that year, the shadow spokesman for the Treasury, Peter Costello, said that Labor's estimates would be dead in the water. Those estimates were 14.5 per cent in that budget; in that year we achieved 16 per cent, just to prove once again that the opposition is into trying to peddle bad news and undermining the strong economic performance of this government.

PARA.TAB: This level of investment reflected exceptionally strong growth of 21 per cent in plant and equipment investment last financial year—growth which was, I believe, significantly above the highest rates of growth previously recorded in the national accounts. That solid investment performance is set to continue. This financial year we anticipate a total of $54 billion of investment for all businesses across all sectors—that is $54 billion of new and upgraded productive capacity for the Australian economy.

That is a serious vote of confidence in our economic settings, and it means the creation of real and ongoing jobs for Australians. For example, Australia currently has $10.7 billion of major new resource projects in the pipeline—that is projects with a capital cost of over $200 million or more each, and they are either committed or under construction. Previously I have reported to this chamber the $200 billion of investment in the last year that the automotive industry has made in Australia and investment coming to other areas of manufacturing industry here as well.

About a fortnight ago another manufacturing investment was approved by the federal government. That was a decision by the Japanese company Hokushin Limited to establish a medium density fibreboard project at George Town, Tasmania. It is a particularly welcome investment for Tasmania because it is about adding value to our forest resources. One tonne of export woodchips earns about $80, but one tonne of export fibreboard will earn $600. That is an indication of a seven-fold increase because of the value adding chain that this investment will bring.

The project will involve a capital investment of $90 million, will result in the direct employment of 120 people and will produce export earnings of $70 million a year. This investment is a direct result of the federal government's investment attraction efforts in Japan.

In addition to that, in the services sector last week I was very pleased to announce that Cathay Pacific has decided to relocate its flight training centre to Australia from Hong Kong. That is an investment by Cathay in Australia of $110 million. It will employ 65 highly skilled staff. It will have a centre training 90 people a day. It follows Cathay's earlier decision to invest $250 million for a data centre and telecommunications hub in Sydney. It is a very impressive high technology centre. I opened that centre last week.

Both these investments are current examples of the confidence the international investment community has in the Australian economy and its propensity to choose Australia as a regional headquarter in the Asia Pacific area for its operations. They do show that the investment forecasts in the budget are realistic and that we are set to achieve those outcomes as we look forward to completing the budget year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Senate for giving me the opportunity of listening to that piece of very good news in silence. I also thank the minister for his answer. Is the minister aware of the following public comment that was made recently on Australia's attractiveness as an investment location: `Any potential overseas investor couldn't do better than look upon Australia as a place where continuing long-term foreign investment remains extremely attractive'?

—According to the AAP wire, those words were said by John Howard today. I repeat his comment: `Any potential overseas investor couldn't do better than look upon Australia as a place where continuing long-term foreign investment remains extremely attractive.' That point is right. John Howard, out of his own mouth, praises the Australian economy—something he must have done by accident. But it is right. The economic fundamentals are sound. Our competitiveness has gone up 40 per cent since 1983. Foreigners invest here because of this Labor government's economic record. Mr Howard should tell Mr Costello about that so we can get some truth in politics on the record in terms of the economy.

PARA.TAB: The other thing is that, in the same speech, Mr Howard again reasserted his industrial relations policy. If there were ever a Howard government in this country with the industrial relations policies that he proposes, this level of investment would dry up. I remind the Senate that a few weeks back I reported that the Western Australian government's second tier of industrial relations legislation is opposed by business, because of the damaging impact it has on the—(Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Resources and Health

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. Your government has continually justified the payment of Dr Lawrence's legal expenses on the basis that they are directed to her carrying out her functions as a minister and are therefore supported by section 4(4)(b) of the Parliamentary Entitlements Act. Yet, when we asked for the amount of the four bills so far rendered to the Commonwealth, Senator Evans refused, saying that they are subject to legal professional privilege which belongs to Dr Lawrence personally and can be waived only by her. If the payments are made to her for carrying out her functions as a minister, then the privilege is the Commonwealth's, since Dr Lawrence is acting as agent for the Commonwealth when carrying out her functions as a minister. You simply cannot have it both ways. Will you either inform the Senate of the amounts of Dr Lawrence's legal accounts or concede that the payments are not for a Commonwealth purpose and would therefore be unlawful?

—I raise a point of order. Mr President, I seek your indulgence in addressing the point of order. The matter that Senator Vanstone has addressed in her question was contained in a submission by the Premier of Western Australia to the Senate Legal and Constitutional References Committee, which is currently sitting on a reference from this chamber into the matter that is contained in the question. I ask your advice as to whether it is proper that this matter, which is under consideration by the committee, can be or should be addressed in question time, or would it not be better if it were referred directly to the committee.

—The standing orders do preclude questions referring to matters that are currently before the Senate, and I guess that also refers to the committees. But that is a ruling that has been very loosely applied in the past, and I would allow the question on that basis.

—Once again, we see Senator Vanstone's bush lawyer skills coming into play and, once again, we see her dissembling the legal situation. She knows very well that the position put by the government with respect to Carmen Lawrence's bills is quite compatible; she knows that privilege attaches to the actual individual involved; and she knows that that is not incompatible with the Commonwealth paying the bills in this particular instance or any other instance like this. She is dissembling the facts with respect to this matter. She is playing with the ignorance of people whom she is trying to persuade that she has a particular legal point here. The reality is that she has not. Once again, what she is saying here is totally wrong. The client in this particular instance is Carmen Lawrence. Privilege obviously attaches to her. It is her decision.

PARA.TAB: The other thing to say about this—I will very much repeat what Senator Evans said before the committee which is currently in existence and which is currently inquiring into this matter—is that the bills will be subject to the normal scrutiny of government, as bills normally are in these particular circumstances. In essence, the criteria to be judged is not just what is fair and reasonable in terms of the costs but also whether the actual process itself was justifiable. That is something that has always been placed on the record.

Senator Vanstone, what we have here is more evidence of collaboration between your side of parliament and the Western Australian government. You conspired to put this little process together; you conspired to get this little sting together; you are the ones who are conspiring as it continues—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The rules of debate under standing order 193(3) make it very clear that senators are not allowed to cast imputations of improper motives and that all personal reflections on members are highly disorderly. What you have had in this answer from start to finish are suggestions that Senator Vanstone well knows that she is acting dishonestly, that she is dissembling and that she has conspired. In other words, he cannot play the game. He cannot give us an answer to the question. He constantly attacks the questioner. You ought to enforce that standing order and make sure this sort of thing cannot keep happening.

—On the point of order: it is quite apparent that, if we took Senator Alston's advice, we would all go home. It is also quite apparent that, if you took Senator Alston's advice, you would not allow this question, because what the question itself does is impute improper motives on the part of the government and on the part of the minister for health. You cannot it have both ways, Senator Alston. Mr President, I put it to you that that sort of restricted ruling not only reeks of hypocrisy but also would make this place unmanageable. We might as well all toss it in.
—Order! I would not have thought that the answer so far was imputing improper motive to anybody.
—Oh, oh!

—Order! But it would also be, as Senator Bolkus has pointed out, impossible in this chamber because such a ruling would cut out all the normal cut and thrust of attack from one side to the other. I think that is an impossible position to put me in.

—This is more evidence of collaboration. As Senator McKiernan quite rightly put on the record, this is part of the submission that was put forward by the Western Australian government. Once again we have this tag team match going on between the Liberals here and the Liberals in the other place in order to hound and, in a vindictive way, pursue the Minister for Human Services and Health. That is all this is about.

PARA.TAB: What are you doing here, Senator Vanstone? You are creating a legal fiction, a legal fantasy. You are propagating it through the gallery, hoping some poor sucker up there will cop the line. But the reality is that there is no legal substance to your argument. You know it very well and, if you do not, you should not have got your law degree.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, you assert that the privilege belongs to Dr Lawrence. What you are being asked is: is she acting in a private capacity or is she acting as minister? Is she carrying out her function as minister in challenging the WA royal commission? If you so wish to claim that she is, which you do, then is it not true that you must say that she is acting as an agent for the Commonwealth and that the privilege belongs to the Commonwealth? She just happens to be the person giving the instructions. It is not her personal privilege; it is that of the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth has the right to waive that privilege. If you disagree with that, will you kindly explain why someone can possibly act as a minister and purport to withhold the Commonwealth's privilege in these matters? Perhaps you could explain your answer; it might help us all a bit.

—Mr President, I will tell you what I will explain. It was Senator Vanstone who, out of her own mouth, said that, if Carmen Lawrence was not the federal Minister for Human Services and Health, this thing would not have proceeded. I can remember; maybe her colleagues cannot. She is the one who pinned the tail on this particular process. She said that, if Carmen Lawrence had not been the federal Minister for Human Services and Health, this would not have happened.
—I did not say that. That is a blatant untruth.

—You confirmed that in a radio interview, and you know very well that you did. Starting from that position, it is quite defensible for the federal government to be involved in defending the position of a federal minister. The question of privilege is something quite separate, and Senator Vanstone knows that as well. The question of privilege always attaches to the client, and that client has a particular role.

PARA.TAB: But in this particular instance let us also go to the bottom line. The bottom line here is that there will be scrutiny as to the fairness and reasonableness of the cost as well as the justification of the particular process. Senator Vanstone, you know that. You are dissembling once again. You got your leader into trouble the last time you said this in the bushfire debate; you might do it again.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. The minister has been pursuing a number of measures designed to enhance the administration of Australian sporting organisations.
—Is that what the question says?

—Thank you, Senator Hill, for that interjection. I understand that today the minister announced a new sports traineeship program. Can he inform us about the new scheme and, specifically, how these traineeships will enhance the career opportunities in Australian sport?

—Yes, I can. The sport and recreation industry is one of Australia's fastest growing industries. It provides a rapidly developing range of employment opportunities and it can offer a career path for athletes and non-athletes alike. The sports traineeship program is just one of the ways that the government is helping Australian sport become more professionally administered while at the same time creating rewarding career opportunities for Australians.

PARA.TAB: The new $1 million sports traineeship program is part of the government's Working Nation program. It will be administered by the Australian Sports Commission and it will be directed to amateur and small sports of a non-commercial nature. I am writing to almost 1,600 national and state sporting bodies to inform them of the program and to encourage them to participate in this new program. The funding is in addition to the $1 million that has already been allocated to the administration through the Australian Rugby League and the Australian Football League group training companies whose programs are already up and running. These two schemes are further examples of the success of the government's Working Nation partnerships with industry.

The new program is designed to encourage sporting organisations to employ people to undertake an accredited program of structured training in the sports industry. The Sports Commission has been working closely with the recreation training advisory board in the development of appropriate course programs. The scheme is directed at anyone aged 15 or over, particularly long-term unemployed people, and will provide them with the opportunity to gain the knowledge, skills and confidence to perform a wide range of tasks. Courses will be available in areas such as sports administration, management, sales, marketing, ground maintenance and also fitness instruction.

Organisations taking on a trainee will receive a subsidy of up to $3,000 per trainee to assist with their salary and employment costs. In addition to the cash subsidy, training courses will be offered through the technical and further education system as well as the Australian College of Sports Education located in the Australian Institute of Sport in Canberra. I would expect that training and work experience will better equip everyone who is entering employment in sports organisations around the country. It is the case that in the lead-up to the Sydney Olympic Games it will be increasingly important that sports are able to respond professionally to the increased pressures of sporting and sponsorship competition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. Given the comments from the other side while I was asking that question, minister, can you point to anything that you have done so far in this area, particularly for the great sport of Australian rules, and for that other sport, rugby league, wherever that is played?

—I inform the Senate that the existing traineeship programs with the two great sports of rugby league and Australian rules have been operating for most of this year and they have also been very successful. Sports group training companies were formed earlier this year by the Australian Rugby League and the AFL, with a company formed by the Queensland Rugby Union coming on stream later in the year. These companies are formed to service the traineeship needs of the professional sporting organisations.

PARA.TAB: The two existing training companies have experienced very good results to date, with the AFL having placed approximately 120 people in trainee positions and the Australian Rugby League having placed 26. I think the recent announcement by the Australian Soccer Federation that it would be working in partnership with the ARL to provide more professional opportunities for its athletes will also see the taking up of somewhere between 35 and 50 new traineeship opportunities.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer the minister to yesterday's judgment in the Victorian Supreme Court which found BHP in contempt of court over its role in helping to prepare draft legislation designed to stop compensation claims by Papua New Guinea land owners for environmental damage caused by BHP's Ok Tedi mine. Does the minister agree that any Australian company, let alone the `big Australian', should be involved in drafting legislation which prohibits the making of compensation claims, giving evidence in court, providing legal representation or other assistance, all backed by criminal sanctions? Has the minister approached the PNG government on this issue, bearing in mind the prime minister's stated concern about the rapid degradation of the natural environment in the region? Finally, would the minister support such activities by corporations in Australia? If not, does he now agree to initiate a code of conduct for Australian companies operating overseas?

—Too many people in this chamber forget that Papua New Guinea is a sovereign nation. The way in which it conducts its affairs and interrelates with companies, be they Australian or otherwise, is the business of the Papua New Guinea government. I do not intend to lecture it or moralise to it on the way it behaves.

PARA.TAB: Senator Spindler goes to the broader question of whether this government would encourage any company to draw up legislation or in other ways carry on other activities. I do not think, in the terms in which you have put it, we would encourage that, but we always encourage broad consultation on legislation. Every senator in this chamber has been through the process of being lobbied on these issues by companies. That is not unusual. But, in the terms in which you put it, I would not encourage it; if it were confined to those narrow areas that you have put, I would not encourage it to occur in Australia.

As to the question of a code of conduct for companies on the way they behave overseas, that is a matter to which the government may give some consideration. But it is not really within the ambit of the people whom I represent here to make a decision on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer. He really did not take a very strong stance on the behaviour of an Australian company. I would suggest to the minister that if an Australian company acted in this particular way in Australia—stopping access to the legal system for its own financial gains—the shareholders, the institutional investors and the community would ask the directors to resign. What is so different if the operations are in an overseas country?

—It is always up to the shareholders in these circumstance to ask the board and management to resign. The point I am making is: it is up to the Papua New Guinean government to determine the law in its own way. I am not saying you are falling for this, senator, but too often people believe that we are still the colonial masters, that we just have to march up to Port Moresby and say, `Look, you should behave in the following way.' It is a sovereign country. It is entitled to make its decisions—right or wrong. It is up to it to say what is lawful in PNG and what is not lawful.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner. Can the minister confirm that the Western Australian state Department of Conservation and Land Management, CALM, has vetoed the proposed Commonwealth appointment of Dr Denis Saunders to the crucial assessment panel who will advise on whether road, river and stream reserves will form a part of the `comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system'? Can the minister also confirm that Dr Saunders' replacement, Dr David Bell, was chosen from a list of scientists acceptable to CALM? If this is the case, how does the minister justify the appointment of a CALM imposed scientist over a senior and respected CSIRO scientist originally chosen by the Commonwealth?
—I am not able to confirm that. I will seek advice and advise you when I have that advice made available.

—My question is addressed to Senator Collins, the former minister for communications. I refer to the lengthy dispute between Telstra and the Casualties of Telecom and Telecom's assurance in late November to Senator Alston and myself that a Senate inquiry was not necessary as an arbitration assessment process would be fast-tracked and non-legalistic, would efficiently deliver FOI and would be finished by April 1994. I ask the minister: what has Telstra spent before and after arbitration, including reports from Bell (Canada) and Coopers and Lybrand; arbitration fees; legal counsel for the TIO; Telecom's outside lawyers; the technical and accounting resource unit; costs associated with the Federal Police investigation and the DPP follow-up; mediator fees following the ombudsman's report; and all other related costs?

—I cannot provide the detail that Senator Boswell has requested in respect of costs in respect of each one of these individual matters, but I will refer the detail of that question to the minister on notice to get a response.

PARA.TAB: In relation to costs, I did note that Telstra advised the Senate legislation committee—the estimates committee—in June this year that there were 18 Telstra staff working in either a full- or part-time capacity directly on what Telstra referred to as the difficult network fault cases, commonly referred to as the COT cases. Telstra estimated at that time that some 13.85 person years had been devoted to the task in 1994-95.

Telstra further advised that the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman, in his capacity as administrator of the arbitration process, incurred costs associated with legal accounting and expert advice amounting to over $800,000 over the last two financial years. Those costs were also met by Telstra.

That information I can give to Senator Boswell now. I will take the rest of that part of the question on notice. The COT cases, as they are called, have not been an admirable part of Telstra's history, unfortunately. The matter that Senator Boswell just referred to has been before Senate estimates committees and has been raised in questions here over a period of time. It has been a very prolonged case as well.

In conclusion, it might be useful to Senator Boswell, in terms of the comments I heard him make earlier today in the public interest debate in the chamber about the fact that there had been only one case settled, if I informed him of the situation currently. This is advice that the minister has received, I think, from the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman. Of the 16 cases, one has been completed, as Senator Boswell said in the Senate earlier today, and the award delivered. One case has been settled. Nine further cases are well advanced. Four have yet to lodge claims, and one claim has been withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct this supplementary question to Senator Bob Collins as the minister that did tell Telecom seven years ago to get this fixed. Minister, assuming that it already amounts to millions of dollars, do you consider Telstra has spent well for a process that only settled one case, required the Commonwealth Ombudsman's intervention on FOI documents, cost COT members hundreds of thousands of dollars to take part in the arbitration, with several going broke, while the four-month process became a seven-year nightmare?

—I think I have just said fairly forthrightly that I consider that this whole affair has a very sorry history indeed, and the way it has been handled does not reflect very well on Telstra at all. I also consider that it is particularly unfortunate that the FOI applications had to be the subject of an investigation by the Commonwealth Ombudsman. But I note that all of the ombudsman's recommendations as a result of that investigation were accepted by Telstra, and the ombudsman is monitoring Telstra's compliance with its undertakings.

—My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Bob Collins. Earlier today the Prime Minister gave a major speech to the Agribusiness Association of Australia and New Zealand, laying out a vision for a sustainable and prosperous agricultural sector. In that speech, Mr Keating mentioned the company Sakata Rice Snacks as an example of the sort of food industry development that this government is promoting.
—Is this another new policy?

—This is another good news policy that is working—not like yours, which is still to be found. Can the minister inform the Senate about this company's plans and about the support this government is providing to that company and others like it?
—I can, and I am in the happy position of being able to advise the Senate that the government's rural policies are working very effectively for the benefit of rural Australia.
—You haven't stopped the drought yet.
—The real drought, Senator, is in respect of your policies as far as rural Australia is concerned. Farmers in Australia have asked a lot of questions and are still waiting for answers.

PARA.TAB: All of the food markets in Asia add up to around $900 billion worth of consumption a year. Western-style foods are becoming increasingly popular in Asia, but Asian tastes continue, of course, to dominate these markets and always will. Asian tastes also have an increasing presence in the Australian community. As I myself advised the Senate on previous occasions, a huge industry that has been sitting under our noses until quite recent years here in Australia has been to supply from within Australia the Asian tastes that are now part of our society here.

I am pleased to say that Australian companies with the assistance of this government are now taking advantage of that opportunity. Western foods, as I said, are popular, but Asian foods are now extremely popular in Australia. As the Prime Minister mentioned in Orange this morning, net imports of Asian food into Australia currently amount to $800 million a year. It is around a billion dollars a year. We currently import $6 million worth of rice crackers alone into Australia a year. Most of this particular food comes from one company, the Sakata baker company, which has been operating in Japan for 40 years.

Australia produces all of the necessary materials to produce this product. Our rice is one-third the cost of rice in Japan. Sakata has recognised the opportunity to produce supplies for the Australian market and at the same time create a more viable base for exports into other Asian markets, such as Malaysia and Indonesia. The company is investing $6 million in a new plant in Laverton, Victoria, creating 24 jobs. When fully operational, this facility will improve our balance of merchandise trade by $7 million a year. That is in import replacement and exports themselves.

The company has sought assistance under the innovative agricultural marketing program, which is administered by Austrade and DPIE, to purchase capital equipment and undertake travel and other marketing activities, to be repaid on a royalty basis. I am pleased to advise the Senate that the company will receive $450,000 over three years as part of an allocation of $2 1/4 million of IAMP funds to eight innovative companies throughout Australia. Other export products that have received marketing assistance and capital funding under this allocation include: nursery plants, equipment and services from Brisbane; emu oil based cosmetics from Western Australia; fresh broccoli from the Darling Downs; and North Queensland capsicums.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to his canvassing in question time on 29 August of the streamlined visitor visa system, which utilises established travel agents and electronically transmitted information to automatically issue visas to people overseas who wish to travel to Australia. Why does the front for the Australian government office in Taiwan, the Australian Commerce and Industry Office, charge a fee of $A50 for a visitor visa when the government has an official policy of not charging tourists on short-term visits? Is it a fact that agents in Japan charge $A80 for a visa under your system? What will the charges in the other 15 countries to which you referred on 29 August be when they are brought into this streamlined system?
—I think Senator Parer misses the fundamental point in this process.
—That's always the case, isn't it!

—That is always the case; you are right. That, Senator Hill, is not unlike you. Like you, he doesn't do his homework. That is the common denominator on the other side of the parliament. You can come in here with a degree of information, but unless you really research the area you do not know what you are talking about. And here we have it again.

PARA.TAB: People in countries to which Senator Parer refers—whether it is Taiwan, Japan or any other place where an agency agreement is in place—will obviously still be able to get their visas from Australian government agencies. In respect of Taiwan, I will take that aspect of it on notice and come back to you as to whether that $A50 is in fact being charged. My history with questions like this is that, quite often, they are based on a degree of misinformation.

The reality is that, whether it is Japan or anywhere elsewhere else where the government has an official presence and migration has a presence, people still have direct access to the migration department. If they want to go elsewhere for convenience, if they want to use the agency arrangements—let us face it, those arrangements are in place for the convenience of people in areas, for instance, outside capital cities or in capital cities areas remote and removed from our migration facilities—then we obviously cannot impose limitations on charges in a country over which we do not have jurisdictions. We can control our own operations—and we do so—but we cannot control the operations of other countries or dictate the laws of other countries or agents.

To that extent, even within Australia we have problems with migration agents, people who try to facilitate entry into this country. As a consequence, we have migration agent registration legislation. That legislation has been part of a process in this parliament, a process which is leading to amendments to it.

Take into account that we are talking about agency arrangements which will bring the services closer to the people. Just a few weeks ago I announced, for instance, the implementation of agency arrangements in Italy which will mean that people now can get visas to Australia through agents in Milan and also agents in the south, in Messina—not having now to access our immigration offices in Rome. I have also, by the way, instructed our officers in the migration department there to travel up and down Italy to make sure they are more accessible to people in the regions. It is part of a program in government and immigration to make sure that access to our visa system is enhanced for particularly people who are removed and remote from migration facilities.

As I said at the start, I will take the Taiwan aspect of the question on notice. When it comes to other countries, as I said to you, Senator Parer, we can dictate the charges of the migration officials, and we do so through regulations in this place, but when it comes to the private sector—the sector you are great supporters of unbridled deregulation thereof—it is much harder, particularly if those people are outside Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When the minister does verify that there is a $50 charge by the Australian government office in Taiwan, would he also find out, if the charges are based on cost recovery, how come there has been no reduction in the charges despite the fact that the number of visas issued has almost doubled over the last year? I also ask him, in respect of the agency agreements he has negotiated in Italy, what the charges will be for tourists coming here. It is all very well for him to say this is a private sector matter. When the government gives these licences to particular travel agents, it is giving them a benefit that is not available to other travel agents. Surely, if you have any commercial attributes whatsoever, you would negotiate an agreement.

—The fundamental question here is whether Australia continues to have a visa system. Both sides of parliament agree that we should. What we need to do is find out, with that in place, how best to make it accessible to as wide a range of people as possible. That is why the visa agency arrangements are in place. When we fix on visa agency arrangements we do try to focus on those agents who have at the moment the largest share of the market so that we can, for instance, reach a larger proportion of people coming into Australia.

PARA.TAB: Under those arrangements, as I say, we can control our prices. They are the prices that are regulated by this parliament. When it comes to outside, officially or unofficially, we find enough trouble being able to control that within Australia, Senator Parer. You know that. To be able to dictate that outside Australia is even more difficult. What can be an agreement quite often may not be what is reflected by the final processing cost. We can never underestimate the creativity of the private sector to increase fees and charges. I will take your questions on notice. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories and concerns the Sydney Olympics. I am sure, minister, you, as did many people, saw the front page of last Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald which suggests that people known as the Olympic family will hog tickets for the next Olympic games, leaving the normal Australian public largely squeezed out. This seems to be confirmed by the New South Wales state government minister for the Olympics, Mr Knight. I ask: will the federal government act to make sure that Olympic events are accessible for ordinary Australians? I note here that over 60 per cent of the tickets are already spoken for. Is that correct? Will you also take an interest in whether or not tickets are affordable for average Australians? Does the Olympic family—and I am not including the athletes here—have to pay for their tickets? Finally, will the government specifically act to ensure members of this Olympic family cannot make huge windfall profits by scalping their tickets at way above the actual price value?

—I thank Senator Lees for her question. I have seen the newspaper reports that she refers to in her question. I must say this matter is entirely one for SOCOG, the Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games. Obviously, the federal government, while wishing to see as many Australians as possible attend the events at the games, is really not in a position to direct SOCOG on what is essentially a commercial decision by that body. The organising committee is a statutory authority established by the New South Wales parliament.

PARA.TAB: I have been in contact with the New South Wales government and have been assured that, while no decisions have been made on ticketing and pricing policies—and SOCOG does not have to submit its ticket plans to the IOC until 1988—there will be many tickets available for the Sydney games and the majority of these will go to Australians at all events.

I understand that the bid documents proposed a total of 5.5 million tickets for the Sydney games. To this must also be added those events which will not require entry tickets, such as the marathon and the triathlon, which, I would expect, will attract a very great number of local spectators along the respective routes.

I am advised that the nature of the weekend's media reports is somewhat affected by the fact that the seating capacity for many of the venues has not yet been determined. For example, the Olympic stadium could contain up to 110,000 seats. So it is really impossible at this time to be able to calculate accurately any division of tickets for any of the events that will be taking place at a venue like that.

As for the scalping element of the question that was asked, I am sure that Senator Lees would be aware that the broad issue of regulation of ticket scalping is one for state government. In this case, I think it is more appropriately directed to the New South Wales government.

I can say to you, and I am sure you would join with me in saying this, Senator Lees, that all Australians are hoping that these Sydney games will be an outstanding success and that our team and its performance at the games really will engender a great deal of national pride. The federal government, for its part, has made a very significant contribution to the successful staging of the games through the provision of funding of facilities at Homebush Bay. There is also the significant contribution we have made in the preparation of Olympic athletes for the games. They are the role and the responsibility that the Australian government has taken very seriously indeed.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health: Health Statistics

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, Senator Crowley. Given Dr Lawrence's new found capacity to count words and how often she suffered from memory loss at the Marks Royal Commission, I ask: will she instead count the numbers of Australians on waiting lists at our public hospitals, the numbers who can no longer afford private health insurance as a result of Labor policies, and the numbers of our indigenous people who do not have access to even the most basic of health services? If the minister has counted the numbers, can she advise the Senate of the number in each of the three categories?

—Mr President, I will ignore the totally stupid introduction to this question and say that, as to the question of waiting lists—the first point that you raised, Senator—that is a matter of very important consideration by this government. That is why there has been a special allocation of funding to assist the state governments to reduce the waiting lists.
—Give us the numbers.

—Somebody over there, Senator, shouted vulgarly, `Give us the numbers.' The numbers I cannot give you, Senator. I will get the latest figures on those. What we do know is that there is always some concern about the accuracy of that data. It depends on what the states provide. There is still a very big lag in accuracy between what states provide by way of data in all of those areas and what the actual number might be. In fact, the more important thing, as has often been discussed in this place, is not so much the numbers on the waiting lists but the time any one person has to wait.
—Order! Senator Ray and Senator Faulkner, there is one person answering this question.

—Thank you, Mr President. I was making the point that the numbers on waiting lists are not so much an important consideration as the time any one person on a list has to wait. I know that the figures for New South Wales a few years ago showed that of about a million people who came through the public hospital system, 50 per cent were dealt with in less than 12 hours—certainly on day one—as matters of accident and emergency admissions. Another 49.5 per cent or so were dealt with as elective surgery within two or three weeks or up to six weeks, which nobody regards as any lengthy time.

PARA.TAB: So if you take people on waiting lists but do not put in the factor of how long they have been on the waiting lists you can get some false figures in that area. If there is anything in detail I will certainly try to provide that for you. Again, I urge caution about that data.

I also have to say that, with the introduction of casemix and other factors of that sort between the Commonwealth and the states, there is a significant difference in the number of people waiting. In Victoria, the Minister for Health certainly claims that there has been a significant reduction in the number of people on waiting lists in that state. Certainly the Medicare funding has, as I said, provided extra funding over and above the agreements to assist state governments to reduce those waiting times for people on waiting lists.

It is also important to know that in the past when we have tried to arrange for public patients to be treated in private hospitals surgeons have refused to cooperate under that arrangement to assist with reducing waiting lists. There are some examples where surgeons have assisted in that way. There are examples where surgeons have actively opposed any opportunity for public patients to be operated on in private hospitals. Again, I think those factors also need to be taken into account here.

It is interesting to know that if no beds were available in the veterans' affairs hospitals—previously they were separate; they are now a large part of the state systems around the country—any of those people had immediate access to private hospital operation, paid for by the government. So we have a different scale of public patient care in the area of waiting lists.

I think you asked about the private health insurance figures, Senator, and whether they were still declining. The latest figures do show a continuing decline. I do not think I can put my hand on those at the moment, but I think we would be down to about 35 per cent or so on the private health insurance figures. I will see whether there is anything more accurate I can provide with that, but we have not had the opportunity for the changes to the private health insurance legislation to bite. We do have contracts between hospitals and the health insurance funds. We have not seen too many contracts between doctors. Some of those—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the minister did not deem it appropriate to comment about the indigenous people who are still requiring basic health services. I am sure that the people who are actually on the waiting lists around this country would consider the numbers to be important. I ask the minister: given that you have not been able to provide the Senate with the numbers requested, can you advise whether that is because, one, you are not aware of them; two, they have not been counted; or, three, you are suffering from memory loss?

—I think we had some points of order before about attributing motive or nastiness in this chamber. I think gratuitous insults of that sort do not help this place at all. As to the point about Aboriginal health, Senator, I have not ignored those figures. You asked me three points, and I was answering those seriatim.

PARA.TAB: On the Aboriginal health figures, I would say to you that this government is committed to Aboriginal health and to the recognition that the morbidity and mortality figures for Aboriginal people are quite unacceptably high, particularly compared with non-Aboriginal people. We have in place a specific program to deal with Aboriginal health and to try to reduce those figures. We are here talking, Senator, I understand you to mean, about Aboriginal health services for Aboriginal communities, as apart from Aboriginal people who might reside in cities. I could not, I am sure, give you that disaggregated data. If there are some figures, Senator, I will certainly see what I can provide for you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Kernot asked Senator Gareth Evans a question on unpaid work and he promised to provide further information, which is now available. I seek leave to have the following reply incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The reply read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Ray—In Question Time on 19 September, Senator Kernot asked Senator Evans, as Leader of the Government in the Senate, a question about the Government's response to the proposal embodied in the Beijing Platform for Action about measuring the value of women's unpaid work. Senator Kernot related this to the Government's efforts to promote the Beijing Conference as a conference of commitments.
I seek leave to have the following reply incorporated in Hansard:
The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women has provided the following answer to Senator Kernot's question:

The report of the House of Representatives Inquiry into the Equal Opportunity and Equal Status for Women in Australia in 1992 found that a major frustration for Australian women was that much of what they did, as unpaid work, was perceived to have little or no financial value and was therefore "invisible" or "not real work".

Estimates for the value of unpaid work are excluded from the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in all developed countries in line with international standards for measuring GDP.
