A revised version of these international standards was published, the System of National Accounts 1993, which recommended that estimates of unpaid work be developed within the context of "satellite accounts" which provide supplementary information which can be used in conjunction with data in national accounts.

In 1994, the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) published a range of estimates of the value of unpaid household work based on data from the 1992 ABS Time Use Survey. The estimated value of unpaid, voluntary and community work by women and men is $227.8 billion, representing a figure equivalent to 58 per cent of GDP. Of this, women undertake 65 per cent of unpaid work, worth $139.4 billion.

The publication of the ABS's estimates was a milestone in acknowledging unpaid work as a significant element of the Australian economy. The ABS advises that its publication in 1993 of these estimates is a form of satellite accounts.

This is a step in national accounting which few other countries have taken. Further steps in accounting for the value of unpaid work in the national accounts will depend on international developments to which Australia is an active contributor.
The next set of ABS estimates are expected to be released following the 1997 National Time Use survey.

In terms of how this tallies with Australia's efforts to promote the Beijing Conference as a conference of commitments, it is important to understand what our proposal meant. The conference of commitments proposal asked countries to identify three or four key areas which impede women's path to equality and to identify specific and concrete domestic measures to address these areas. The Prime Minister announced Australia's commitments on 29 August in the following areas:

PARA.TAB: work and family responsibilities;
violence against women;
indigenous women's health;
women in decision-making; and
overseas aid.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's commitments to the Beijing Conference were well founded, based as they were, on extensive national consultations. The Government will honour these commitments.

These commitments are complementary to the Platform for Action. The Platform for Action is not likely to have far reaching implications for Australia which is one of the most advanced countries in the world when it comes to policies and programs for women. However, the Government, through the Office of the Status of Women, will examine the document carefully, once a formal version has been received, to determine its implications for future policy in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 June, I put a question from Senator Kernot concerning competition in the banking industry on notice. The Treasurer (Mr Willis) has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question.

PARA.TAB: Subject to constitutional limitations on the coverage of state banking, banks are currently subject to the competitive conduct rules in the Trade Practices Act 1974. Banks which are outside the coverage of that act, due to constitutional limitations, will become subject to the competitive conduct rules from 21 July 1996 by reason of the competition reforms agreed between the Commonwealth and states at the Council of Australian Governments meeting of 11 April this year.

The competitive conduct rules are designed to foster competition in Australian markets by prohibiting anti-competitive conduct such as price fixing agreements, misuse of market power, exclusive dealing and resale price maintenance, and acquisitions which substantially lessen competition in a market. Enforcement of those rules will be the responsibility of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission, the ACCC.

In addition, the ACCC will have a price monitoring role incorporating the current functions of the Prices Surveillance Authority. Following the recent PSA report into financial institution fees and charges, the ACCC will be directed to formally monitor and regularly report on the financial services industry in relation to retail transaction accounts for a period of three years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill this day, relating to an alleged secret policy agenda.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we have to say that Senator Cook showed today remarkable frankness and confirmed the story which we read in this morning's newspapers that the government has a secret policy agenda and that a new range of major policies is going to be announced.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Senator West may groan but, according to the front page of the Financial Review, those opposite were told by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, in caucus yesterday about eight to 10 new major policy documents are coming down. This was confirmed by Senator Cook today. I quote his words. This is what he said—
—At least we've got policies.
—No, that is not what Senator Cook said. He said this:

SPEECH.PARA: We will be bringing down policies which will show a vision for the future of this country at an appropriate time. When we do it, we will tell you about it.
That is what Senator Cook said today—bless him. He confirmed the story in today's Financial Review. He went further and said this:
In our case they will have a clear, well thought out presentation of the detail, and they will have it well enough in advance . . .

A very important statement has been made today by Senator Cook confirming the comments by the Prime Minister to the caucus yesterday. We are going to have another avalanche of Labor policies, but Labor will not tell us when these policies will be brought down. Given the chance today to indicate how these will be financed—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are pathetic!
—Oh!

—Those opposite may groan, but it is in the Financial Review and Senator Cook said it today. That is what he said today. The backbench are a bit horrified, and rightly so. Senator Neal does not say much in this chamber but she has worked out this problem: `Hey, we have been attacking the coalition for not releasing policies, so why is Senator Cook today saying that we are not going to release policies until a time of our choosing?' Frankly, it has to be said that Mr Keating refers to a number of you as boneheads, but you were bright enough to note that there is a real problem here for the Labor Party—and Senator Cook walked you straight into it.

PARA.TAB: The issue here for the Australian public is: when will Labor release this avalanche of policies? And this is the question—wait for it—how will they be paid for? There are some very big ticket items in this new Labor policy secret agenda. The housing policy—big ticket item. Regional infrastructure—Senator Ian Macdonald will note, a big ticket item. An energy policy—

TALK.START.PARA: —We've got a policy.

—Senator Collins comes in and says, `We've got a policy.' But you have not. Senator Cook said today that your policies are coming down later. I put it to you: one of the most important answers to a question in the current session of the parliament was given by Senator Cook today. What we are seeing is a deliberate strategy by the government to hold its policies back—
—You are trying but you are not doing very well.
—Senator West, that is what he said—to hold these policies back, but—
—Our policies are in place and are working.
—Senator Collins says, `Our policies are in place.' Senator Collins also says, `We're bringing out a whole avalanche of new policies.' Get your lines right, Senator Collins.

PARA.TAB: Today we have seen the secret policy agenda of the Labor Party being revealed. We can thank Senator Cook for this. He has caused the backbench senators some embarrassment because they have all been writing letters complaining about the lack of election promises and complaining about us, and they recognise the embarrassment of this. We have to say that we are not the greatest fans of Senator Cook over here, but when we look through his answer today, when we look at some of his lines, we have to say that Senator Cook has revealed the truth. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President—
—This will be good.
—Quite frankly, I thought that Senator Hill's question was silly enough, but I did not think the would-be minister for the environment sitting over there—
—Minister!

—would be so stupid as to stand up and try to add further to the stupidity that has already occurred. I know you people have not been in government for a long time—and I do not know whether Senator Kemp has ever been in government—but I'll tell you what, that question and the fact that you got up to take note of the answer just demonstrates your lack of capacity to understand what government is really all about. We, as the party in government, are implementing our policies all the time. That is the role of government. I thought you would understand that.

PARA.TAB: I know that you, Senator Kemp, as shadow spokesman for the environment, have never once come in here and asked a relevant question about the environment. Instead we have to wait to see the Greens or the Democrats pursue environmental questions. But just for your information, Senator Kemp, this government has a proud record of policy implementation, of all of the issues that we have, over time, introduced as a government for change in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I raise a point of order. This debate is wide ranging, and we all accept that. However, senators have to be relevant. The issue was the new policy agenda of the Labor Party. So, Shayne, could you address that, please?
—Senator Kemp, do not address senators by their Christian names across the chamber.
—I apologise.
—Senator Murphy, I think you have only had one minute, and I am sure you will become relevant, but we are interested to see.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. Yes, it is true, I must address our policies. I just go to the changes that we, as a government of this country, have made in this country. In terms of the social changes that we have brought about, we have achieved things that you people never could and never would—things such as Mabo, and the rebuilding of this country into one unit; and industrial relations, which I know are so important to you people over there. Look at the industrial record and the disputation record under this government versus what it was under your government. You would never have the capacity to strike up an accord delivering so much stability in industrial relations in this country. You never have and you never will have.

PARA.TAB: But there are other matters. Look at wage justice and the social justice in terms of pensions that we have brought about in this country. Under you, when were you last in government, people on pensions were suffering cutbacks—cutbacks to a significant degree. And you talk about social justice! Well, you deliver some.

You talk about policies. We are working our policies by way of government. What we and the public of this country want to know is what your policies are, what you would do for them if you were in government. We are telling them what we are doing because it is working for them. In terms of structural change, we have changed the industries of this country around—

TALK.START.PARA: —You sure have!
—Yes, and much for the better, Senator Parer.
—You've decimated them.

—We have turned this nation into an outward-looking nation—one that now exports about 70 or 80 per cent of its primary production. What did you do? Nothing. You were inward looking: grow it—wheat, wool—shear it, chop it down, do whatever you like, but basically do nothing. We have introduced significant landcare programs as part of our policies.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp has now disappeared from the chamber. The one who reckons policies are so important has gone. He has gone on a policy hunt; that is where he has gone. Let me tell you: there would be a big prize for the first person to find your policies. It would be a really big prize. We should turn it into a national competition. In fact, I will suggest that to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). All the things we have done are there for all to see, yet we still have to put up with the stupid questions—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Madam Deputy President, there was a point of order on relevance earlier on. You told us that Senator Murphy's comments would be more relevant as he moved through his speech; but he has made no attempt. We will excuse him if he sits down and we will give him the rest of his time later, if he cares to read Senator Cook's answer and address the Senate later. Obviously he never listened to Senator Cook's answer.
—There is no point of order.
—In closing, I would like to say what I have said throughout: our policies are working.
—Tell us your policies? What are they?

—There is primary production, which is so important to you, Senator Panizza. Let me quote some figures in relation to the fishing industry. In 1991-92 the tuna industry was worth about $1.8 million. Today it is worth $50 million. Why? Because we have implemented the policies to bring that about. If you look at the Asian food market—and I think the Prime Minister mentioned this today—you will see that it is worth something like $900 billion. We are the government that has been putting in place the policies to enable our primary producers to actually tap into that market. What did you do when you were in government? Nothing. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address two matters in relation to Senator Cook's answer. Firstly, there is this whole issue of the policy development processes of the two major parties. The great thing about the revelations in the Australian Financial Review this morning and Senator Cook's confirmation of it here today—and he said

SPEECH.PARA: We will be bringing down policies which will show a vision for the future for this country at an appropriate time. When we do it, we will tell you about it.
—is that it overturns—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's an ongoing process, you goose!
—Order! Senator Murphy, you will withdraw that remark. You have had your turn.
—I withdraw.

—The great change that today heralds is in fact a reversal of Labor electoral strategy and policy strategy that has been in place for 13 years. The Keating doctrine and the Hawke doctrine was generally to make a whole bunch of promises during the campaign and then work up the policies after the election. In other words, tell the people something before the election and then announce the policies after the election. We saw a slight change to that strategy last time. Mr Keating brought in a tax policy which, because he was so concerned about his credibility on keeping promises, he put into l-a-w, law. But, of course, he reverted to type straight after the election and changed the l-a-w, law, and broke the promise.

PARA.TAB: The important thing to note is that the coalition has stuck to a policy over the last 13 years—and, of course, it has not been very successful electorally—of launching its policies in ample time for the Australian people to read those policies, to understand them and to see how they would affect them. At the last election they did so. Based on the information provided to them—and some of it may have been misinformation, but we will not go into that debate because I do not want to cry over spilt milk—they decided that they would return the Keating Labor government. At the next election they will be given that opportunity again. So, quite honestly, I welcome the fact that the Labor Party will announce some policies before the next election.

Senator Murphy was quite right: this government does have policies in place. The people of Australia I have spoken to—and I have spoken to an incredible number over the last few weeks—know about the policies of the Labor Party. They know that many of those policies are failing. It was very good of Senator Murphy to remind the Senate that the policy in relation to tuna fishing is working. People will be pleased about that. Many people involved in that industry will be very pleased that the tuna fishing industry has succeeded under the Keating Labor government, and I give you full marks for that. That will impress many people. It is an important industry.

There are so many other policies that are failing. There are three-quarters of a million people who are officially unemployed. There are hundreds of thousands more underemployed people who seek full-time work but cannot get it. Australia has achieved the highest youth suicide rate in the world. That is a national disgrace; it is an international disgrace. We have the highest levels of youth unemployment in the world. We have the highest real prime interest rates in the world. That ensures that our small businesses cannot expand and create jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a load of nonsense!
—We have the highest real prime interest rates in the world. The minister says that is not true. If he would like me to table the latest edition of the Economist magazine—
—In the world?

—That is right. We have the highest real prime bank interest rates in the world. In June we had them; we were in the top two or three. Today's issue of the Economist magazine—I will make the point so that the senator from the Northern Territory understands—says that prime bank interest rates in Australia at 12 September are 11.5 per cent. The only other nation that comes close to that is Spain at 11.5 per cent. We are equal top in terms of notional inflation rates but, in terms of the highest rate, Australia is either the top or the second or third top, and it has been for the last few months.

PARA.TAB: During Senator Cook's response to Senator Hill's question, he said that one of this government's great policy achievements has been getting inflation down to a sustainable and low level. Sure, inflation is lower than what we have been used to during most of the period of the Hawke and Keating governments but, in international comparative terms, which is all that counts, for this last quarter we have the equal highest inflation rate in the OECD and, on an annualised basis, we have the second highest inflation rate in the OECD.

If you guys want to go to the next election and stand on your economic record, then you should do so because the Australian people will decide. I congratulate you if you are going to bring out some new policies because you sure as hell need them. Yesterday, Senator Collins said that we have a file stuffed full of policies. I would rather have a file stuffed full of policies ready to launch than a pile of stuffed policies. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to respond to the conclusion of Senator Campbell's address. I will be very brief. I did not make those comments, Senator Campbell; your leader here in the Senate did. In the Australian Financial Review of 17 July this year, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) made an interesting statement, considering the assertions made by other members of your frontbench that the opposition has not completed its policies and that they will be announced at the next election. The Australian Financial Review of 17 July said:

SPEECH.PARA: The chairman of the federal Opposition's policy review committee—
not me, Senator Campbell—

Senator Robert Hill, has been briefing coalition candidates around Australia on the contents of the three fat folders he says are stuffed with detailed portfolio policies, all finished and submitted by the strict Howard imposed deadline of June 30.

As I have said to Senator Hill before, a great many people in the Australian community would like to know where those policies are and what they are. Senator Hill says you have got them. I can only speak—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where are yours? Where are your new policies?

—I will certainly speak for my area. If you pick up any issue of the regional rural press over the last couple of weeks, Senator Campbell, you will see the coverage of the opposition's approach to what has been unarguably the worst crisis Australian primary industry has ever faced—certainly in the recorded history of this country—and that is the drought that we have had for the last five years in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Your pretend Prime Minister turned up with the pretend minister for primary industries at a number of meetings where people were not unreasonably expecting from a coalition that constantly says that it is a rural coalition and that it represents rural Australia at least some indication of what the opposition would do. What did they get instead? An endorsement of our policies. As I said, when the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the pretend Prime Minister, went to Roma, he did by accident discover a good drought policy—ours—and he said so. But, to quote the rural press at the time, `despite many questions asked, Mr Howard was tight lipped about policy'. Just to correct the record in here, I did not make those remarks, Senator Campbell; your leader in the Senate said that you had three fat folders stuffed with detailed policies. Well, Senator Campbell, where are they?

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been a very interesting debate because both sides of the chamber have spoken about the importance of policy. Senator Campbell raised some very serious matters which he put forward as problems ongoing in Australia. I would have thought, given those problems that he put forward, that it would be proper for both sides of the chamber to put forward policies. If these problems are so serious, it is a matter of concern that if policies are available and have been put together, they are not delivered now in an attempt to solve those problems.
—So you can misrepresent them like you did last time.

—Senator Panizza said that we will misrepresent them. It follows from that that it is more important, according to that logic, to hide your policies than to solve the present problems that are before us.
—That's what Ross Free reckons. Ross Free isn't coming out with his policy until Christmas time. You ask Ross Free about it.

—Whether Ross Free believes that or not, Senator Campbell, your fellow senator from Western Australia has made it clear that even though the opposition has brought forward the terrible problems that you have mentioned as serious problems, it is not willing in the light of those serious problems to put forward policies that might solve them.
—Oh yes we are; just like Senator Cook, and we will tell you about them.
—If you are, let us hear them.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment, Sports and Territories (Senator Faulkner), to a question without notice asked by Senator Chamarette this day, relating to the appointment of a scientific assessment panel.

SPEECH.PARA: I was asking Senator Faulkner to confirm whether the Western Australian state Department of Conservation and Land Management had vetoed an appointment to a crucial scientific assessment panel and substituted their own scientist that was on a list that was amenable to them. The response that Senator Faulkner gave me was that he could not confirm it. I was uncertain as to whether that meant that he was not able to confirm or verify the matter of an appointment or whether he did not know about it.

PARA.TAB: Subsequently, Senator Faulkner came over to me and told me that essentially he was not able to confirm or verify the matter because it was a matter for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet and that he would try to get an answer for me as soon as possible. Both were true: he did not know the answer and he was going to have to get that answer from Prime Minister and Cabinet. I find that very disturbing.

Why doesn't the environment minister know about this crucial transaction? It is not very comforting to know that he has to ask Prime Minister and Cabinet to get that answer because he has staff on Prime Minister and Cabinet's forest task force. They should have consulted him or at least kept him advised of the significance of this matter. I appreciate that ministers cannot know everything; neither can senators. But it is extremely worrying that what is happening is out of his hands because of his role as environment minister. He obviously has no comprehension of how this particular transaction will impact on Western Australia.

The impact will be of this kind: the brief of the panel is to assess whether or not the non-statutory zones, such as road, river and stream reserves in the Western Australian forests, fit the Commonwealth government's agreed criteria for comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve systems as outlined in the national forest policy, with the aim of gauging their appropriateness for inclusion in the reserve system. The problem with that is that those road, river and stream zones, aside from other non-statutory reserves of the forest estate, comprise some four per cent or 100,000 hectares of the forest estate and they will have a very big impact on any areas that are set aside by CALM.

If the panel were to decide, as CALM is arguing, that these reserves have sufficient integrity to fulfil the Commonwealth criteria and hence be included in the government's arbitrary 15 per cent protection goal once the RFA process is complete, this will drastically reduce the amount of additional forest of more substantial reserve integrity that is unprotected under the current DFA process. So thousands of hectares of Western Australian old growth forest, and the bio-diversity and beauty of it which would otherwise be protected, will be left to the woodchippers, in order to comprise up to the 85 per cent to which they will have access.

These matters are of great importance. It is of great concern that the minister was not aware that what has occurred in this panel that makes the decision is that CALM, which has a vested interest in the inclusion of those non-statutory reserves within the 15 per cent that the government has set aside to protect, has had the important role of vetoing a scientist who was the Commonwealth's choice and who was senior and respected in the CSIRO, and substituting an appointment of their own. This really poses the crucial question as to what sort of fairness there will be in any decision that that body is able to make.

I am very disappointed that the minister could not provide the answer. I certainly expect—and I am grateful that he has indicated he will give it—an answer that tells us what his plan is in response to that transaction. I also ask whether he has received notification of whether the forest task force has received a recommendation on this matter from the scientific advisory panel.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Minister for Human Services and Health: Health Statistics

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Abetz this day, relating to health statistics.

SPEECH.PARA: Health in this country is clearly in crisis. Today, in the Adelaide Advertiser, there is an article headed, `Hospitals' cash crisis'. Allow me to read one short paragraph:
The Queen Elizabeth Hospital's chief executive officer, Mr Greg Bussell, warned it would have to turn away about 5000 patients in the next financial year.

What was Senator Crowley's response? `Numbers don't count.' I can assure Senator Crowley that each and every one of those 5,000 South Australians, from her home state, will believe that the numbers are important. Indeed, she deigned to call my question a stupid question. I can tell Senator Crowley that immediately after she gave her answer a general practitioner rang my office to tell my staff that his urgent cardiac patients have a waiting period of six to nine months. That is how stupid the proposition I put to her is.

PARA.TAB: I tried to highlight to Senator Crowley the very real, perilous state of the health system in this country. Whilst this is going on, the Minister for Human Services and Health, Carmen Lawrence, is fiddling around with other matters, rather than devoting herself to the important tasks which her portfolio requires of her.

The numbers of Australians on waiting lists for our public hospitals ought to be something of everyday concern to the minister. She ought to have those figures at her fingertips, be working on them and showing us the strategy of how they have decreased during the 13 years of Labor. Of course, the numbers have increased during the 13 years of Labor. So it is convenient not to be able to tell us about the numbers.

I say to Senator Crowley that the numbers are important. If she thinks that waiting for a period of six to nine months with important cardiac complaints is appropriate, let her say that time and time again, because the people of Australia will then come to realise exactly how woefully she is administering the health portfolio.

Let us move on to the second question I asked, about the numbers who can no longer afford private health insurance. Allow me to show the Senate this graph. When Labor came into government 13 or so years ago, in 1983, over 60 per cent of Australians had private health insurance. Today, the figure is well below 40 per cent—a great record. Of course, it is no wonder the minister did not quite remember what the numbers were—temporary memory loss, like her senior colleague.

That is the record of the Labor government in health. As the number of people with private health insurance decreases, the demand on public resources increases. As a result, more and more people are unable to avail themselves of the public hospital system. But, once again, that issue was simply dismissed by the minister and seen as something of no concern.

The minister said that the high mortality rate amongst the indigenous people was unacceptable. I fully agree with that. This government has had 13 years to address that problem. Senator Richardson tried to address it. Immediately after he made all of his promises, the policies were thrown away and he was told that he could not implement them.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite clear that this government has not been addressing the fundamental issues of health policy in relation to waiting lists, private health insurance and the indigenous people of this country. The minister ought to get back to the real issues confronting this country. She and her predecessors have had 13 years to fix this problem. She has failed and failed dismally. All I can say is that I look forward to the time when a Howard government is able to address all those problems. (Time expired)

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Campbell proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The failure of the government to address the pressing needs of many thousands of young Australians and the fundamental lack of understanding shown towards those needs as demonstrated by the Prime Minister's callous "get a job" jibe.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank my colleagues for their support. The issue for discussion today in this matter of public importance focuses on the pressing needs of many thousands of young Australians and the fundamental lack of understanding shown towards those needs as demonstrated by the recent `get a job' gibe that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) made to a number of demonstrating students at a university.

PARA.TAB: You may be aware, Madam Deputy President, that during the past fortnight's recess in the parliamentary sittings I got myself a bus and, along with a few other younger members of the parliamentary Liberal Party, undertook a trip from Bondi Beach to Cairns to listen to the views of young people. In this age when young people in particular are entirely cynical about politicians from both sides of the chamber, as Farah Farouque from the Age said, `It took some guts to do that.' I do not pat myself on the back for having the guts to do it, but it could have been seen as a cynical exercise.

Today's edition of the South-East Advertiser has an article where Garrie Gibson, the member for Moreton, is quoted as saying that the Brisbane leg of the tour was a monumental disaster and that the two functions held in Brisbane were attended by only half a dozen people. It is a shame that Mr Gibson is seeking to mislead the readers of the South-East Advertiser or that he has been misinformed.

In Brisbane, we had the pleasure of meeting with different groups of people—in Beenleigh, we met with something like 50 young people; in Bracken Ridge, we met with more than 10 people; and, in Caboolture, we met with more than 30 people. In Yeronga—which is in Garrie Gibson's seat—we went to the TAFE college, which is something I would encourage Mr Gibson to do. He should go to the Yeronga TAFE and walk around the refectory as we did. Those of us on the bus were able to walk around and speak not only to people in the library—which was a disturbance to some of their studies—but also to people in the refectory, where we spoke to well in excess of 100 people. We have survey forms—
Senator Bell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Robert Bell interjects. I congratulate the Democrats because they have quite often conducted youth surveys to find out their views. It is something they have done that the government has chosen not to do. I say to Garrie Gibson in that seat, `Go down to the Yeronga TAFE. Walk through the refectory at lunchtime. Speak to a hundred of the students there and hear what they say.'

PARA.TAB: I vividly remember sitting down and having conversations with apprentices who are there doing training programs in building courses. They were saying, `All of these training programs are just a lot of bull. What we need is a building industry that can give us a job.' They said, `Mr Keating's high interest rates have destroyed the building industry in Queensland.' So these guys are really worried that they will not be able to go into the bricklaying, carpentry and plastering trades that their dads have been in because there are no houses being built, the whole industry has come to a standstill, because Mr Keating has again given Australia the highest real prime bank interest rates in the world.
The other important issues that came up on that trip—and I do not necessarily want to spend my whole 10 minutes talking about that trip—

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about your policy while you are there.

—You give us your new policy, Senator Carr. We have heard from your Prime Minister, at your caucus meeting yesterday to keep people like you happy, that he is going to come up with some new policies. We have heard from Senator Cook today that we will hear about them when they come up with them.
—You were in the refectory with 150 students. What did you tell them you were going to do?

—Senator Carr, we look forward to seeing your new policies, because I am explaining to you right now how your policies at the moment are a dismal failure. You have the highest youth unemployment rate in the Western world under this Prime Minister and under this bunch of failed ministers. You have a youth homelessness crisis that is becoming an international disgrace and a disaster. You have the latest response from Ross Free, the minister who is coordinating a response to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs June report on youth homelessness. His latest response to that was to write a letter dated 18 August to the committee saying that the committee has done some good work, raised a whole load of new problems and they will get a response from him towards the end of the year.

PARA.TAB: So that is how good your policies are at the moment, Senator Carr. The policy on youth homelessness is such a disaster that virtually every agency in the country that has anything to do with it knows it is a disaster, knows that your government is out of touch and knows that your government will not listen to the concerns of youth. The best Ross Free can do is to come up with a response to the chairman of that committee saying, `Wait till Christmas.' Let us wait till Christmas and see what your government can come with there.

I genuinely hope for those people in places like Townsville, Cairns and the outer suburbs of Melbourne and Sydney—like the two boys aged 11 and 13 who were found sleeping in a park in western Sydney on 23 August this year—that the policies are better than the stuff that has been dealt up to the Australian people in the past 13 years. Those two children, aged 11 and 13, were found in August, in the middle of a Sydney winter, sleeping in a park in western Sydney. As I said to a media person on that day: Australian children should play in parks; they should not be sleeping in them. The response from Ross Free is inadequate, but we do look forward to a more substantial response when Mr Free gets around to responding to that report.

The one overwhelming thing that young people really want is a job. They want an economic environment where they can have a choice as to whether they go to TAFE, whether they go into some other form of training or whether they go to university. They want that to be affordable, but at the end of it all they want the opportunity of a job. I have to say, from speaking to the hundreds of young people I have spoken to right around this nation now—and it has been a privilege to do so and an absolute privilege to be the shadow minister for youth affairs—that the overwhelming feeling from the youth workers and the young people themselves is that the Working Nation programs, even though some of the schemes are doing some good because they are giving young people some opportunities, are designed to get people off the unemployment statistics.

That is obviously a very cynical response. I am sure Simon Crean's ultimate motivation is not simply to wangle the unemployment figures, but the reality is that that is how it is perceived. That is obviously the political motivation for spending millions of dollars on having Bill Hunter on television every night telling Australia that it is all okay. The fact is that Australia's unemployment crisis stays there, and the biggest impact is indeed on the youngest members of our community.

The homeless crisis is something that impacts particularly hard on unemployed youth and, of course, youth who are in training schemes, attending a TAFE or attending a university. I have done some research to find out what the cost of housing is for young people and the impact of that on accommodation for young people. If you compare rental costs in 1983 with rental costs now for Sydney, in real terms, you will find the cost of renting a three-bedroom property in the metropolitan area has gone from an average of $182 a week to $240 a week. That is in real dollar terms; the figures have been adjusted for inflation. So there has been a 31 per cent increase in the price of rental accommodation in Sydney. For young people that is an enormous hike.

What you then need to do, to see how affordable accommodation for young people is, is to ask what has happened to their wages in that time. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, on the best information they and the library can give me, there has been an effective five per cent decrease in youth wages in this country under Labor. So housing affordability has got to crisis point.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to go down to three bucks an hour.

—You tell the people on some of your programs how much they are earning an hour. If that is the best you can come up with, you go out and tell them that. This nation does have a crisis which does affect our youth. I look forward to the contribution of Senator Ian Macdonald on the impact on youth in rural areas and of Senator Kay Patterson on the youth suicide crisis that afflicts so many families in Australia. There is a need for massive policy change at the federal government level in this area. I am very pleased to see that during the bus trip the Prime Minister announced that a new youth policy would be announced before the election.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is now quite clear that the reason we are having this matter of public importance is that we want a travelogue from Senator Campbell about his bus trip from Sydney to Cairns. From all the evidence I have seen and been briefed about, you might well see that it was a tour of relevant marginal electorates that the coalition hopes to win. That seems to be where the so-called consultations took place. He went to Maitland, Grafton, Lismore and the marginal seat areas of Brisbane, then to Bundaberg, Rockhampton, Townsville and Cairns.

PARA.TAB: Talk about a blast to the past, back to the 1960s and the magical mystery tour of the Beatles. We have just had the Liberal version. In fact, Senator Campbell could well be Priscilla, Queen of the Marginal Electorates, in this bus tour starting in Sydney.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Wentworth—a very marginal seat!

—I suppose Wentworth is the only place you could round up a couple of Libs from the Young Liberal branch because you know they would not disagree with anything you say, including such things as $3 an hour for youth wages. Of course, Senator Campbell did have some problems. In one interview on his magical mystery tour he was asked whether the Liberals' youth policies would embrace, for instance, the safe sex guide which was published in Cleo. This was pretty embarrassing because he had set up a youth hotline in Queensland based in the office of Senator Herron, who has made a great issue of trying to have censorship imposed in this country and such an insert in Cleo banned.

PARA.TAB: Senator Campbell had to admit during the trip that he does not have much input into Liberal policy. In one of his interviews, on Sydney radio, he said he would have to draw on his party's education policy, industrial relations policy and so on—even its health policy, which would, of course, be determined by other shadow ministers.

All of this listening to young people will amount to nothing in terms of drug and alcohol awareness campaigns, safe sex campaigns, labour market programs, university funding, TAFE funding, vocational training, Austudy, HECS—all the areas in which we have relevant policies out there in the marketplace helping young people. In all of this consultation we have not heard one idea, not one idea. All we can go on is the $3 an hour for youth wages policy from the last election campaign. Is that still on the agenda?

The next thing we find in one of your interviews on this magical mystery tour, Senator Campbell, is that you said you have been working on the coalition's youth policy for the past 14 or 15 months. After working on it for 14 or 15 months you then go through a consultation period but you still cannot tell them what you are working on. In any of the material I have seen published—radio interviews on 2KY with Mike Bailey, the Caboolture News—there is no indication of what your youth policy is or what you would be doing in terms of youth.

Until you come up with some actual policies, the only thing you have left standing is the policies you had during the last election campaign, which is $3 an hour for youth wages and a campaign by Senator Herron trying to ban relevant information on issues such as safe sex, which a lot of young people in this country are quite pleased to have made available to them. In some of the information I have read, one of the members of your magical mystery tour got stuck into Triple J radio—the youth station that has 10 per cent of the radio market of Australia on average right across Australia. You have one of your dopey Liberal backbenchers bagging, attacking, Triple J, which provides relevant information. Go and stand up in any TAFE canteen or university canteen and say, `We're going to get rid of Triple J.' Stand up and say, `We are opposed to putting out information on safe sex or drug and alcohol rehabilitation.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said that on Triple J.

—No, you do not say that. You rely on the backwoodsmen like Senator Herron, who has a nineteenth or eighteenth century view on censorship—that this material actually affects the social fabric of society if young people are allowed to read it. You are running a youth hotline out of his office. That would be a pretty intimidating process—ringing Senator Herron, who basically wants to ban all of this information.
—I'll tell you what—the kids out there do not read Cleo magazine, mate.

—That is just where you are wrong. A lot of young people, particularly young women, do read Cleo. I know misogynists in the Liberal Party do not recognise women. A lot of young people do read it in one form or another. That is why we thought it relevant to put that information in.

PARA.TAB: This is an extraordinary reason to have the Senate's hour taken up: so that Senator Campbell can expound on his magical mystery tour—as I say, the Priscilla of the marginal electorates. Did you use the pink bus? Did you go and get that out of the lot from the making of the movie? That might have got you a bit more attention. I do not know how you thought up this idea of wandering around, driving up the coast trying to find audiences, going into TAFE colleges. Any of us can walk into a TAFE college and walk through a canteen at lunchtime with a captive audience and then claim we are having meaningful consultation. It is a joke.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you go out and do it? They have not seen you there and they have not seen Garrie Gibson there.

—It is one of the old and tried hackneyed methods of political campaigning. There is nothing innovative about it, Senator Campbell—nothing whatsoever. If you went back to the 1920s you would probably find it was being done then and people would have been saying it was a pretty old idea. If you went back to the nineteenth century they were probably doing it. You run round using this idea to say you are now a guru of youth policy.

PARA.TAB: Let me get a couple of facts straight on the record. Somewhere or other you have quoted—I do not know where you get the figure—that Australia's youth unemployment is 40 per cent. That is wrong. From the beginning of this year to August, the number of young people seeking full-time employment has fallen by over 15 per cent. Over the same period we have increased full-time employment for young people by 2.6 per cent or nearly 26,000 more jobs.

There are currently 91,400 teenagers unemployed. When the opposition left government in 1983 there were 158,000 teenagers unemployed. The population was much smaller then and so was the economy. We had a lot more unemployed teenagers when you were last in government when the population and the economy were smaller. The unemployment rate for under-25-year-olds is not 40 per cent, as Senator Campbell reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I never said that. Tell the truth. You couldn't lie straight in bed.

—You said that in the West Australian last Tuesday, apparently. The unemployment rate for under-25-year-olds is 14.4 per cent. Working Nation has reduced by a third the number of long-term unemployed 15- to 24-year-olds since August 1994, greater than the 23 per cent decrease for all long-term unemployed over the same period.

PARA.TAB: We have also increased the number and range of education and training places for young people. The evidence shows that education and training significantly increases the chances of young people getting and holding a job. Recent analysis by DEET shows that 80 per cent of teenage trainees are still in work at least a year after completing their traineeship.

We are committed, as a government, to a target that will see 95 per cent of 19-year-olds completing year 12 or participating in post-school education or training by the year 2000. Today, 80 per cent of 19-year-olds meet this requirement. That is a very substantial, successful policy outcome.

We have here a joke MPI; that is all it could be called. I know that senators have the right to put their names forward to the President each day for an urgency motion, a matter of public importance and so on, but the opposition has taken up an hour of the Senate's time today just to say that its bus tour from Sydney to Cairns is reason for a Senate discussion.

Nowhere in what Senator Campbell said for 10 minutes did we hear what the opposition will do to help young people as a result of what they heard on that tour. The reason is that most young people missed it completely. Most young people did not know it was happening. The opposition could not find them because it is not in their interests to hear what a lot of young people want. Most of it goes against the natural prejudices of the Liberal Party. You do not want to hear—

TALK.START.PARA: —You're a dinosaur.

—You are the dinosaurs. You are the ones who, at the last election, promised young people $3 an hour minimum wage. That was going back to the 19th century. That was your policy. I have not heard any policy from your side to replace it. I have not heard you say that this policy is now dead. Until you come up with something, it is fair for us to ask, `Is that still how you are going to treat young people?'
—What's your employment target for young people?

—If you had been listening you would have heard because I just read it out. I just gave the information. With the Working Nation statement we have a $9 billion commitment over four to five years, overwhelmingly directed at getting long-term unemployed people, with special emphasis on the young, back into the work force with proper training.

PARA.TAB: From the day we announced Working Nation I have not heard any Liberal senator stand up here and say, `This is a good program.' All I have heard is carping, that we have not delivered as quickly as we said we would, that there is too much money, that they are not real jobs, that traineeships are not being used properly, or that the program is too bureaucratic. Some of that criticism may be fair, although I do not think it is. However, the credibility of the opposition's criticism would be much more substantial if they would say what they would do with a $9 billion program over four years to help the long-term unemployed, particularly young unemployed. We are yet to hear one word in substance of what they would do.

In another area of policy, that of infrastructure—Senator Ian Macdonald spilt the beans, or should I say milk, all over the place on this—the opposition is promising everything. Their tactic is to hint that they will build all sorts of things, but in a way that means that if they should win an election they are not firmly committed and can withdraw from their commitment to the Alice Springs to Darwin railway line and other major infrastructure projects. That is what Senator Macdonald's discussion paper says.

Now we are getting this same tactic in the area of youth unemployment. Instead of a policy paper, we have a magical mystery tour of a bus trip—with four or five coalition members of parliament driving from Sydney to Cairns saying, `This is what we want to do. This is how we show our sympathy.' But in all of that trip, in all the reporting of the press, there is not one suggestion of policy. There is not one suggestion of what you would put in place of, if you did not like our policy, Working Nation.

What would you do with the $9 billion? I think I know what you would do with the $9 billion. You would cut it. You would cut the expenditure and abolish these programs absolutely, because you cannot fund in other areas some of the talk you are making about tax cuts unless you make these sorts of cuts to expenditure.

I have seen another discussion paper in my own area of small business, which was mysteriously leaked a couple of weeks ago, showing that for small business there would be changes to the provisional uplift factor, to capital gains tax, to depreciation allowances and to fringe benefits tax. Any of those changes would probably cost well in excess of $1 billion of revenue forgone. Again, the tactic is, `Let it seep out there as though we are going to do all of those things. When we get down to the election, if we are able to win it, afterwards we will not do any of those things at all because we want to maintain the fiscal structure of the budget.' You are being absolutely dishonest.

This is one of the great sham MPIs put before the Senate. All it can be called is `Senator Campbell, the magical mystery tour' or `Priscilla of the marginal electorate', wandering around trying to find some people who he can misguidedly suggest ought to vote for the Liberal Party or the coalition. He did not offer one policy of any substance of what the coalition would do in place of what we are doing. It is a sham and a shame, and you should be ashamed of yourself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that before I contribute to this debate I should declare an interest. I, like a number of other senators in this place, am a parent. My two children are Sally, who is 18 tomorrow, and Christopher, who is almost 15. I suppose if I rang up Sally and asked for a bit of advice about what I might say in this debate, she probably would have said something like, `Dad, you're a dag. You're just like all the rest of them. You really aren't young enough to comment.'

PARA.TAB: What I know about young people and their attitude to those of us in the generation ahead of them is that I suppose all dads have been classified as dags—and they always will be—or some other word, some other way of expressing that you are not part of our way of thinking. You wear clothes that we think are strange. You say things in a strange way, and we would like to make a challenge to your view of the world.

That is really where the problem starts because, if we take that all too seriously and get particularly hurt about it and respond with a jibe which categorises young people in some way as separate from the rest of society, we are not only being overly sensitive, but we are perpetuating the argument and truly separating ourselves from the capacity of understanding what it is that young people are about. Of course, that is precisely what the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) did with his silly throwaway line of `get a job'. He made implications and he categorised young people in a way which excluded them from the rest of our privileged society.

I really should say that I am pleased to see that Senator Campbell's recent fact and policy finding youth bus tour seems to have given the coalition a different, albeit belated, understanding of at least some of the attitudes of youth in this country. You would have to say, unlike Senator Schacht, that there has to be some value in attempting to find out what it is that young people are thinking. By making jibes, as the Prime Minister did, by adopting a stance which is sensitive to being criticised—which we all are in the business of being—by being over sensitive to criticism and by not being sensitive to the suggestions which young people are making, it perpetuates the problem rather than brings any sort of redress to it.

I think we should, instead of dismissing this opportunity to comment on the matter, recognise that there are very serious issues which are facing young Australians. As Senator Campbell found out, many young Australians are cynical about the future. They want to dream; they want to create; and they want to succeed. They want to participate in Australia's future. By cutting them out of it, by categorising young people, by suggesting that they are not part of this reality is certainly exacerbating the problem and doing nothing towards resolving it. Young people are desperately seeking—and I mean desperately seeking—a vision under what are seemingly `directionless decision makers'.

The vision for Australia, which is beyond the Olympics and into the next millennium, the Australia which these very young Australians will inherit, is a destination that we do not know and we cannot know. Could this be because the vision for Australia comes from the minds and mouths of people who are seen as being tired and boring? What sense of ownership can young people have in the future that is expressed in such a way? It is the social analysts and the hard-core economic rationalists of both sides of this chamber who have given weight, meaning and substance to the phrase `the lost generation'. These people have been treated like a supermarket bar code for far too long, and now we reap what successive governments have sown.

I refer Senator Campbell, after having given some sort of acknowledgment of the efforts that he is making, to a front-page story in the Northern Star on Mr John Howard's trip to Ballina High School last Wednesday, 13 September. One disgusted 17-year-old economics student summed up youth attitudes in Australia to politicians by saying this:

SPEECH.PARA: Politicians are gross. They're just a bunch of actors—there's no difference between Labor and the Opposition.
I am pleased to note that he did not include the Australian Democrats in that—

TALK.START.PARA: —They didn't know about you.

—He might well have included all the politicians he knows, and I acknowledge that. I am not supersensitive to these things, Senator Patterson. I have already expressed the danger of getting too excited about jibes such as that.

PARA.TAB: Does this government really believe that young Australians want a future that is created by those who emphasise self-interest and market driven decisions—a future which ignores equity, social justice and human responsibilities? That sort of a future will not serve our next generation.

If ever we, as political parents of this very precious but confused generation, are to communicate effectively with young Australians, we have to put party politics aside for the sake of a sustainable, socially and economically just, and environmentally secure, future for young Australians. While we continue with the party politicking, we cannot succeed in that. The cut and thrust of this is that young Australians see us as working against them and, in turn, they are working against us. If we have to change this block, we have to change the attitudes. By that, I mean our attitudes before the attitudes of young Australians.

We really have to acknowledge that even last Monday in this place we spent some time considering the identification by the World Bank that Australians are the world's richest people per capita. Their analysis suggested that, regardless of how well we are served by our natural resources, countries which invest well in human resources, by spending wisely on education and health care, are likely to be wealthier. Australia's danger is that, because we are so well served by natural resources, we could be complacent about this and about what needs to be done to maintain our prosperity. We will squander our human resources and our tremendous human capital unless we invest, as the World Bank suggests, in education. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —When I listened to Senator Campbell's tragically sad story about young people living in the parks, it reminded me of that gross promise by former Prime Minister Hawke that no child will live in poverty by 1990. It emphasises the Labor Party's absolute lack of any real understanding or interest when the interests of young people are considered. The Labor Party were quite keen to use young people and children to further their election campaigns all those years ago but did absolutely nothing about it. That promise sounded good; the rhetoric was tremendous. I am sure it won them a lot of votes but, when it came down to doing something about it, they did nothing and children still live in abject poverty in Australia.

PARA.TAB: That Labor lie is just typical of the Labor lies that we get. The l-a-w tax cuts have gone down in history as one of the biggest Labor lies. It was almost topped by the Queensland Labor Party's lie about the coalition selling public hospitals. That was even topped by the New South Wales Labor leader's promise to do away with tollways in New South Wales—all lies that they say before election campaigns and immediately after them just ignore completely.

Senator Schacht spoke for 15 minutes without any argument. The attitude of a scoundrel is that when you have no arguments to make you revert to personal abuse. Of course, he did that with Senator Campbell, talking about the magical mystery tour. He did it to Senator Herron—who is, I might say, well regarded everywhere in Australia as a great person, a great Queenslander, a great Australian and a great father—by abusing him in a very personal way.

Senator Campbell's recent trip in the bus was one of the most exciting and beneficial things I have seen any politician do in my time in parliament. What Senator Campbell did was something that Mr Keating, Senator Schacht and all of his cohorts just cannot understand needs to be done. He went out and he listened to people. He did not get out and tell them to get a job, he did not get out and tell them that they have never had it so good, and he did not get out and tell them a few more lies about tax cuts, public hospital sales and tollways. Senator Campbell got out and listened to people on the ground, to get an understanding from young people of what they were all about, what their concerns were all about.

Senator Schacht rubbishes that by saying that is tired, hackneyed and old-fashioned. If it is tired, hackneyed and old-fashioned, let us have a bit more of it. Let us have a bit more of Mr Keating, Senator Schacht and everybody else in the Labor Party going out and listening to what people really want, particularly young people. They would get a real shock because they are obviously so remote from young people these days that they simply do not understand.

I had the good fortune to be an interloper on the bus for a little time as it passed through Brisbane. Regrettably, I did not fit the category of `young politician', but I went along with my colleagues on the bus to listen to what young people had to say. I did not make any speeches. Senator Campbell made no speeches, or none that I heard. We asked questions and we listened to people to get some idea of what their thoughts were. We also handed out a few survey forms.

Obviously, the government simply would not know the results of those surveys. Twenty-eight per cent of youth in my state of Queensland are unemployed. Getting a job when they finish their TAFE or university courses or their schooling is one of the great concerns that young people have—yet the Labor Party have no concern for that and have done nothing to address that. The number of unemployed has increased dramatically over the years. There are now 95,000 fewer under-25s in employment than there were in 1990. How is that for an indictment of the policies of this government.

In regional areas of Australia youth unemployment is tragically high. It really should not be. With the tourism industry up my way in the north and its potential to employ a lot of young people, you would think there would be very little unemployment. But unemployment in the north is tragically high. One of the reasons for that is that the tourism industry, which wants to expand to create new activities, simply cannot do it because of the activities of this government and the Queensland Labor government in stopping any sort of tourist activity or development in the north. Hundreds of jobs could be created for young people, but what does Labor do? They stop these activities as soon as they are proposed, relying on any number of fairly suspect grounds and a lot of confusion between the Commonwealth and the Queensland government over them.

Small business in the north, I know, would like to employ more young people, but do you know what they are frightened of? Senator Schacht would not understand this. He thinks it is old-fashioned, tired and hackneyed to go out and talk to people. Obviously, he does not get out and talk to small businessmen, but I do. Small businessmen will tell you they would love to put on more people but they are frightened stiff that if they happen to make a mistake in the person they employ and want to get rid of them—because they have stolen some money, they just do not happen to be suitable or for some other reason—they cannot get rid of them or, if they do, it costs them a lot of money in either compensation or usually legal fees, time lost and that sort of thing. So there are opportunities there for small businesses to employ young people but they do not.

Youth suicide in regional areas is tragically high. Senator Patterson is going to talk about that. In the transport area this government acts against the interests of young people by putting up fuel prices all the time. What is worse, young people who can afford an old car to get to university have to pay 2c a litre more than others for their fuel as a result of this government's actions. And who buys the old bombs, the older cars? The students going to university and to TAFE college. This government penalises them an extra 2c for it. There is no public transport, no buses, in regional areas of Queensland. Senator Campbell and those on his trip learned all about this when they spoke to people. The bus trip was a tremendous exercise. It will be very useful to the coalition in finalising the policies that it will have for young people in the next campaign. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw Sen M.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I read in the Age of last Saturday that Senator Campbell conceived his idea for a bus trip while he was taking a shower. I have got news for Senator Campbell: it is quite clear from the reports that have come back on this bus trip that the young people of Australia certainly did not come down in the last shower. It is reported that apparently when the bus got to Maitland the people there were not sure whether this tour was a genuine article or whether it was an exercise in political opportunism.

PARA.TAB: Senator Campbell confirmed that in Grafton when he said, `There is going to be cynicism about virtually anything that politicians do, particularly as we are getting over to an election.' Of course, this was nothing more than a `lead up to an election' stunt—a tour of some marginals, as the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) has said. The reporter also noted that in Grafton the reception from the audience, made up of local people, was nothing but considerable cynicism. What did the reporter covering this trip say? `People want to see the actual policy on the table.' And of course they got none.

When we look at employment and education, it is clear that there are two facts we need to bear in mind about the needs of young Australians. Firstly, the federal government has the policies in place that guarantee young people opportunities to receive the highest standards in education and to have employment opportunities. Secondly, the fact is that the opposition has no real policies on how to provide young Australians with decent and appropriate education and with job opportunities. The minister referred to the success of Working Nation. He referred to the substantial improvement in job figures and apprenticeships, and to the significant reduction in long-term unemployment for young people. It is down by one-third since Working Nation.

In the last couple of months I, myself, have been out in parts of rural and regional New South Wales. I have been talking to people in industry, educational institutions, the CES, Social Security and local government; I have been talking to young people. I know that there is a positive feeling out there about the labour market programs that this government has brought about. It is clear that Working Nation is working. It is clear that we have turned the corner.

Just two weeks ago I was up in the mid north coast region of New South Wales. It is an area, Senator Macdonald, which depends very much on its tourism and hospitality industries. In that region unemployment has halved in recent times and jobs growth has gone up by 16 per cent. In that region, as in 62 other regions around Australia, under this government's initiative, consultative committees have been established to greatly assist the development of employment and training opportunities for young people. What we are about is tackling unemployment by bringing together business; governments, including local government; educational institutions; unions; and community organisations—bringing them together to develop the ideas and programs which will increase our skills base and, hence, employment opportunities, particularly for young people.

This is not a government that depends simply upon stunts, upon bus trips up the north coast—like some re-creation of the Endless Summer for Senator Campbell. This is a government that is about real consultation, about talking to young people to address these very important issues.

But what do we get from the opposition? What we get from the opposition is, firstly, no policies. But then we also get from John Howard an admission that, in respect of youth and youth wages, we will get the reimplementation of jobsback. In the Advertiser in October, it was stated:

SPEECH.PARA: John Howard said while Jobsback might be reworded it would not be "substantially altered. The words may be a little different—I am not wedded to the same words—but the substance will be as I have decided."

So we will get jobsback. It really should have been called `jobssack'. And if John Howard wants to rename it, he should probably call it `throwback'—because that is really what it is. It is about taking youth wages and youth employment opportunities as far back into the past as you can—taking them back to the great era of the 1950s that John Howard loved and when, he said, there were a lot of good dead-end jobs around for young people. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find Senator Forshaw's contribution absolutely amazing. He stands up there saying that we have no policies. Yet his own Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—when the youth bus was on its tour, it frightened the hell out of him—got up and he had to say, `We've got to have a youth policy; we've got to do better with young people.' So where is your policy?

PARA.TAB: This morning in the Age there was an article about the Australian/Vogel literary award which was awarded yesterday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us how you are going to abolish the Youth Bureau. That's your policy.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I sat quietly while Senator Forshaw spoke; I hope that you will allow me to speak without having him interrupt me.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —When Richard King, a young writer, was awarded the Australian/Vogel literary award, what did he say? This 27-year-old said:

SPEECH.PARA: My generation was brought up being promised so much. Advertising promised so much. The lucky country promised so much. We reach adulthood and we found it wasn't there.

That is the voice of a young Australian. He says, `We were promised so much; we reached adulthood and it was not there.' What he is saying is, `I have grown up under a Labor government. I have been promised so much, and I reached adulthood and it was not there.' That is a young person, writing about young people's relationships—I have not had the opportunity of reading the book, but I hope I get to very soon—and speaking on behalf of young people. That is what he is saying: we have reached adulthood, and the things we were promised are not there.

PARA.TAB: The situation that many young Australians are finding themselves in is what could only be described as a crisis. They are facing major barriers and problems in relation to unemployment and, as other colleagues of mine have said, homelessness, poverty, education and crime.

What is even more alarming is that Australia has one of the highest youth suicide rates in the world. I note that none of the speakers on the Labor side has referred to that. It is one of the greatest crises facing young people in Australia today—and not one of the Labor members has even dared approach it or mention it. In this situation youth need our understanding and support—and, more importantly, government's understanding and support.

The coalition is committed to this support but it seems that the same cannot be said for the current Labor government and the current Prime Minister. What does he say to young people? What is his response to young people? A response of Mr Hawke's was to call a pensioner a `silly old bugger'. The equivalent statement from Mr Keating to a group of young people at a student rally in Adelaide was to go and `get a job'. No wonder we see the disillusionment that young Richard King expresses today on the award of that Australian/Vogel literary award. Only someone completely out of touch with the Australian public and Australia's youth would make such an outrageous statement.

I was just amazed that people sat over there on the other side saying, `The coalition hasn't done anything with youth; they don't know anything about youth.' That is absolute bunkum. I have been involved in youth affairs since I was a teenager. I have been on the Youth Affairs Council of Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —And you are on the back bench. They sacked you.

—I did not interrupt you, Senator Schacht. There are many of us here who have been involved in youth activities and youth affairs. We go out and talk to young people. We went out and talked to the young people in Shepparton—and what did they talk about? Their fear of not being employed. With the youth organisation that I am involved in, that would have to be the No. 1 priority for young people.

PARA.TAB: Madam Acting Deputy President, I was reading a novel the other day—and I cannot recall its name—but do you know how sometimes somebody can capture something in one sentence that would take others a paragraph or page? The novelist said: children are born to bury their parents; the reverse is the extremity of grief. I repeat: children are born to bury their parents; the reverse is the extremity of grief. What is regrettable—and I think perhaps that word is not strong enough; what is deplorable is that more and more Australian parents are experiencing the extremity of grief, especially the parents of young males in Australia. Children are born to bury their parents; the reverse is the extremity of grief. As I have said, more and more Australian parents, Australian families are experiencing that extremity of grief.

In the 1990s there have been more deaths from suicides than from road accidents—and particularly for young males. It is probable that we have underestimated the number of suicides because it is argued that some of the deaths from those road accidents are, in fact, themselves suicides. Suicide in Australia is estimated to have increased by 10 per cent over each decade. This has been largely accounted for by the increase in youth suicides—in particular, young men between the ages of 15 and 24 years. We know that that is worse in rural Australia. A recent study found that in the 1960s the suicide rate for young males was 10 per 100,000 overall, and it was only five per 100,000 in small country towns. And what have we seen? We have seen a complete reversal of those figures. In 1991 the suicide rate for young males was 29 per 100,000 overall; in towns under 4,000 it was 60; and in towns of 4,000 to 25,000 it was 35. The WHO figures show that suicide rates for Australians aged between 15 and 24 have Australia as fifth among 27 industrialised countries for males and as seventh among industrialised countries for females. That is not a record that we ought to be proud of.

There is considerable evidence to suggest that young people commit suicide because of psychiatric or depressive illnesses, and that many of them have been treated for that beforehand. Burdekin outlined for the government the need for increased awareness of and increased treatment for young people with mental illnesses.

We have seen the government not addressing the issue of stress which has resulted from parents without jobs, not addressing the stress resulting from parents caring for older people, not addressing the stress which has resulted from family breakdown and not addressing the stress associated with the frustration of the bureaucratic tangles of the Child Support Agency. We have seen young people watching their families in stress. This record that the government has left Australia with—this devastating youth suicide figure—leaves the government condemned. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this matter. Senator Campbell says that the coalition will create a federal youth ministry. In fact, I understand that is the only element of policy the liberals have announced to date on this issue. However, at the last election the liberals promised to abolish the youth bureau within the Department of Employment, Education and Training. In the last election the young Australians were not worth a bureau; now they are worth a ministry.

PARA.TAB: Many great sympathetic remarks were made by the coalition in this discussion. But not once did we hear any real commitment. Not once did we hear any real discussion of the very important commitment that is required in terms of what would a future liberal government do in the role of government responsibility. As I see it, that role essentially is to ensure that each individual in our society is able to fulfil their full potential. The liberal philosophy is somewhat different: that the free market should prevail and that all the impediments that face young Australians essentially should be ignored to the extent that they cannot really interfere with market forces, which should be the real distributor of resources within this country.

As far as I am concerned, the government's role is to intervene wherever necessary to ensure that there is breadth of opportunity and to ensure that the market does not leave people behind. Liberal Party policy, on the other hand, is for small government, the reliance on market forces and for the survival of the fittest. Again and again we have heard coalition spokesmen talk about the need for small government. As far as I am concerned, the approach that has been taken so far is to rely upon grand sentiment, but without the backing of that grand sentiment with any resources.
