To suggest that the state can stay out of these issues, to suggest that the small government mentality should dominate, is effectively to say that the sons and the daughters of the wealthy and the privileged should get a much better go than the rest of the people in our society. To say to do nothing is in fact to discriminate in favour of the privileged. As far as I am concerned, youth policy should require an integration of good social policy against a range of social issues in terms of education, industrial relations, health and housing to ensure that there is a fairer distribution of resources and power.

This government has a very good record in terms of Working Nation. We have seen youth unemployment decline since Working Nation has been introduced—a fall of some 14 per cent. The figure for long-term unemployed 15- to 19-year-olds has fallen by more than 20 per cent. The number of long-term unemployed in the 20 to 24 age group has fallen by more than 30 per cent.

What do we see from the liberals? Constant attacks upon that approach. A constant attack upon the notion that government should intervene and that government should spend money in this area in terms of labour market programs. In education we have seen governments radically increase the rate of retention rates. It has moved from three in 10 to eight in 10 over the term of this government. We have seen increases in terms of Commonwealth expenditure in education by some 63 per cent for schools. We have seen the same sorts of figures in terms of vocational education.

What do we see from the coalition? Nothing, other than constant attacks that the government is spending too much, that the government is doing too much, that the government ought not be involved in these areas which would rightfully be left to the states, as they put it. What do we see from the states? Constant attacks. In Victoria, my state, some 8,000 teachers have been removed. We have seen 15,000 students removed from the education system. There has been the closure of 300 schools. We have seen in the last state budget papers a further 32 schools targeted for closure. We have seen in vocational education in Victoria a further cut of $7 million, despite the commitments to the maintenance of effort.

We see a high level of hypocrisy. We see a massive dose of double standards—on the one hand, to express fine sentiment; on the other, to be committed to a policy of small government, to attack people who are in a defenceless position and to not be able to provide the resources to actually redress the social problems that you feel so strongly about. I think it is inappropriate to run that sort of double standard, that sort of hypocrisy. I look forward to the Liberal Party's formal policy announcement. I look forward to the election process whereby that sort of hypocrisy and double standard can be exposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —To students protesting against full fees, declining education funding and Austudy at below poverty line levels, the remark of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of `get a job' earlier this year was a sign of the government's true commitment to higher education. It was an ignorant remark because universities are more and more focused on employment outcomes for students and they are targeting their courses and curricula towards the job market. Much of the emphasis on humanities and social service has been lost to universities now in this last decade of economic rationalism. The social objectives of universities have been rendered subservient to the dominant values of the free market. Instead, universities are becoming centres for research, development and training for technocrats for multinational companies.

PARA.TAB: The majority of students are at university with the intention of becoming more skilled and knowledgeable so that they can be more employable and get a job. However, it is getting increasingly difficult for students to gain access to university and to maintain themselves financially to stay there. Each year thousands of students miss out on places to university; yet the government is not interested in creating any new places unless industry funds them from tax subsidies, which only serves to provide more workers for narrow industry based courses. It is not about educating students in a broad range of subjects that will help them lead fulfilling lives.

If a student is lucky to acquire a place at university, there is a myriad of obstacles to overcome in order to stay there and complete a degree. There is no parity between Austudy conditions and rates and DSS rates and conditions. Austudy has always been below the poverty line, but the rate is dropping compared with inflation and wages over the last 20 years. Prior to 1974, 55 per cent of full-time students received financial support. The level of support was 117 per cent of the unemployment benefits and 75 per cent of the poverty line. Today only 48 per cent of full-time students receive benefits, but they only receive 81 per cent of unemployment benefits set at only 57 per cent of the poverty line.

Once they graduate or finish studying, graduates are saddled with a debt for many years. Graduates no longer have a guaranteed level of income or employment. Age and gender markedly influence how much a graduate gets paid. The ability of students to repay HECS and/or supplementary loans is contingent on their income. On top of the financial burdens outlined is the threat of full fees for post-graduates, and this is a backward step. The fees are unchecked, as is the course quality, and this is a testing ground for the government to bring in fees for the undergraduate sector.

This will have massive consequences for access and equity in tertiary education and will result in education for the privileged. The Prime Minister should think very carefully about devaluing education by calling on students to stop protesting and to `get a job'. There are crucial issues at hand in the trends towards corporatising and deregulating the university sector. Those who suffer will be the ordinary Australians who want decent, broad education. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation, as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—The honourable senator may proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. There were a number of matters that were specifically raised by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht, who led the government side of this debate, that certainly do, under standing orders 191, require me to explain material that has been misquoted and clearly misunderstood, if not deliberately misrepresented. Senator Schacht, during his whole speech, built a straw man and then knocked it over. He said, `Senator Campbell somewhere said that youth unemployment was 40 per cent.' He could not, of course, say where I had said that when I challenged him by way of interjection to do so, because I have never said that. I have never said that youth unemployment was 40 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The fact that is important for young people to know—and I notice there is a hell of a lot of young people in the galleries today, and I am glad to see them all here—is that youth unemployment, as a factor of total unemployment, that is, the number of young people in Australia's horrendous unemployment queues, has been hovering around 40 per cent for most of the last five years. The reality is that the Working Nation policy, which has been brought in by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Simon Crean, has done almost nothing to affect that rate. In other words, the proportion of unemployed young people is around the 39 to 40 per cent mark and it fluctuates up and down in a month. That was the statistic I quoted. So I was misunderstood and certainly misquoted in relation to that.

In his contribution, Senator Schacht said that someone on the bus had criticised Triple J. Of course, when I challenged him by interjection he could not point to the person on the bus who had criticised Triple J. Senator Schacht could not answer that because he did not know the truth or he showed arrant disregard for it. The reality is that no-one on the bus criticised Triple J. If you read the article in the Age, you will find, as Senator Forshaw would have found, that we were very keen to ensure that we were very closely in contact with Triple J. We were very pleased at the run that Triple J gave this youth bus tour. I have been a great supporter of Triple J throughout my parliamentary career and enjoy listening to Triple J, as did just about everyone on the bus. Wherever the Triple J network could be heard on the bus—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I draw your attention to the fact that you are starting to debate the issue. Could you return to your original point.

—I appreciate your guidance, Madam Acting Deputy President. The point I want to make is that I was misquoted and misunderstood. No-one on the bus ever criticised Triple J. The National Union of Students put out a press release after we had been to a forum in Caboolture saying that the candidate for the new seat of Longman, Mal Brough, had criticised Triple J. I immediately rang Mr Brough and said, `Have you criticised Triple J or have you ever criticised Triple J?' He said, `No, I haven't. I enjoy listening to Triple J. I'm a fan of Triple J. I have not criticised them.'
—Senator Campbell, this is a matter for debate at another time. You are really debating the issue. Could you wind up with the points that you were making about being misquoted.

—With absolute respect, I was saying that the minister said that someone on the bus had said that we were going to abolish or criticise Triple J. It is quite crucial that the Senate knows that that claim has absolutely no substance. The only place in which it could have had any substance was a spurious press release put out by the National Union of Students.
—Is this part of your misrepresentation? If not, Senator—

—No, it is. You were not here for the debate, Minister. I think you would appreciate that what I am doing is in order under standing order 191. But I appreciate your guidance. I made the point about Triple J. If that is the best the minister can do, then he is misleading the Australian people. The minister also made misguided comments about the Cleo sex guide. He said that I would not go on Triple J radio and defend Senator Herron's attack on the Cleo sex guide. The reality is that I did go on Triple J and I did defend Senator Herron's actions.

—Senator, I understand that we are going to hear more about this from Senator Herron in a moment. You are entitled to defend what you said but not to launch into an issue relating to Senator Herron. Is there anything further you wanted to say?
—No. I accept your guidance. The other two points are debating points regarding utterly misleading points made by the minister. I will obviously get up on the adjournment and get stuck into him then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was misrepresented by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) when he said that I was against sex education. I have given sex education lectures at the school attended by my daughters. I am very much in favour of sex education, and it is well known that I am. I wonder about the value of such sex education when the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) said on 28 February 1995 that, by the age of 21, one in five adolescents have acquired a sexually transmitted disease. I wonder of what value that sex education has been over the last 20 years when that is occurring now.

PARA.TAB: I believe in factual sex education. I was concerned about the government funded sex guide—which claims to be `the only safe sex guide you'll ever need'—which was published last year in Cleo magazine with the imprimatur of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). As a result of the material that came out of that guide, I wanted to check its factual nature. I wrote to the editor of Cleo magazine. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: I am intrigued as to the motivation of your promotion of sodomy as acceptable heterosexual behaviour, as evidenced by the editions of December and April—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—Senator, I think we are being extremely tolerant of the point you are making. I would ask you to return to your personal explanation.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, I am explaining why I have been misrepresented. Senator Schacht said that I was against sex education. That is completely untrue. I am basing my personal explanation on the factual aspects of that material of which the minister has completely missed the point. I am drawing that out to explain to you why I was misrepresented.

—On the point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: I understand your concern, but quite simply what Senator Herron is doing is attempting to first of all show that there was a misrepresentation. Then he is illustrating why it was a misrepresentation by demonstrating his bona fides in relation to this matter. It would be rather sad if senators were not able to demonstrate their bona fides when a slur or an accusation has been made against them. It is not a debating point. Senator Herron is not attacking Senator Schacht; he is merely demonstrating for the Senate the veracity of his statement that he has been misrepresented. He is pointing out to the Senate his track record in relation to these matters, which in any other matter would be acceptable.
—I have listened carefully to the comments of both Senator Herron and Senator O'Chee on the point of order. I will be listening carefully to Senator Herron's comments from now on.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I also thank Senator O'Chee for his assistance. The so-called factual sex guide says that studies suggest that anywhere between 40 and 60 per cent of women have tried anal sex. That is the government's sex guide. So I wrote to the editor of—

—I raise a point of order. You know as well as I do, Senator Herron, that that is outside what you are entitled to say under a personal explanation. You may say that you have written to the editor. I would have taken Madam Acting Deputy President's ruling that it is perfectly reasonable for you to say that you are committed, but I do not think you have to convince us all, Senator Herron; we know it. But, if what you want to argue is that Senator Schacht misrepresented you, then I think you need to stick to that. We do not need to trawl through the substance of what is in that document. That does seem to me to be straining the tolerance of the chair and it is certainly straining my tolerance.

—On the point of order: I think a very important principle is being debated here in relation to standing order 190. If what the minister argues is to be the case from an interpretation of that standing order, it means that a minister or any other person can get up and totally misrepresent—the minister was not here when Senator Schacht did that—what Senator Herron did or does in relation to the anal sex guide and misrepresent and impugn Senator Herron's integrity not only as a person but as a professional. The minister referred to him as someone with the behavioural codes of the 1800s. So he has attacked Senator Herron's entire personal integrity. If it is okay for the minister to do that, I am sure standing order 190 ensures that senators who have been so attacked and had their position misrepresented can make a proper explanation of that misrepresentation and not simply be limited to saying, `He was wrong and I'm right; he misrepresented me,' and then be required to sit down.

PARA.TAB: I think this deserves fairness and decency. It should ensure that under standing order 190 Senator Herron can make a detailed explanation of why the minister was so wrong and misleading. In this sort of case there almost needs to be a fine or a penalty imposed upon someone in this place who seeks to do that. Part of that penalty for the Senate is to endure from Senator Herron the truth about those matters on this occasion. It may be painful for you, Senator Crowley, but I know you are a fair person because I have had the pleasure of knowing you for five years. In fairness, if you had heard what minister Schacht said about Senator Herron, you would feel that under standing order 190 he should make a quite detailed explanation about why that minister so misled the Senate and misrepresented Senator Herron.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to all the points of view that have been expressed. I did not hear the statement, but I would ask Senator Herron to try not to debate the issue. While I accept that he does need to cover certain detail, we do want to ensure that the issue is not being debated.

—I am sorry that it has gone on like this. If I had been given the opportunity to explain, in reading that correspondence, senators would realise that it is not debating the issue at all but it is explaining why I am upset about Senator Schacht's attack on me. If you allow, Madam Acting Deputy President, I will read a letter that I wrote to the editor of Cleo magazine, which is not involving the issue, as it does explain my position. I appreciate the opportunity of doing that because it explains what my position is, which refutes Senator Schacht's attack upon me.

PARA.TAB: I might mention as well that I happily go on Triple J and have been on Triple J in relation to this matter in the past. So Senator Schacht was factually wrong in that regard. Triple J did quite an extensive interview with me, so perhaps I will refute that particular item. I shall be brief. I will read a letter to the editor of the magazine that published the government guide. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: I have a genuine interest in ascertaining the facts in relation to the occurrence of anal sexual activity in heterosexual females.

Having qualified in medicine and completing my surgical training (Fellowship of the Royal College of Surgeons of England, Edinburgh and Australasia) I was the first research fellow of the Queensland Cancer Fund in the epidemiology of melanoma and spent 5 years on this project. Subsequently my specialties encompassed colo-rectal surgery and breast cancer. My epidemiological training taught me to question the scientific basis for broad assertions, particularly in relation to disease patterns.

The AIDS epidemic is an excellent case study in this regard and it has been alleged, for example, that H.I.V. in non-haemophiliacs, non I.V. drug using females may be associated with anal rather than vaginal intercourse.
This may well explain why the incidence of AIDS in females in Australia is so low—for example, in Queensland in 1994 there was only one new case of AIDS reported.
In fact, there have been two; there was one subsequently. The letter continued:
My questioning of the statistical basis of the assertions in your Sex Guide is an attempt to shed some light on this paradox.
I have received an answer from the Department (enclosed) and I have checked the references given (also enclosed).
As you will see they do not support the assertions made in the guide.

It would be extremely helpful if your journalist could reply to my queries as it may answer the seemly inexplicable behaviour of the HIV virus in Australian women. I agree that "addressing the whole AIDS issue is a matter of life and death".

That is the basis of my interest in this regard. It refutes the absolutely appalling attack on me by Senator Schacht. I am not interested in other aspects of it because when I checked the references that were given—and I have them here—from the department I found that there has been no survey done in Australia, despite the statement by the minister in the other chamber where she said it was between 10 and 15 per cent. She quoted literature reviews of Bruce Voller, Masters, Johnson, Cosmopolitan and Rosenthal, which was done among 35 homeless children in Melbourne. In reviewing the literature, there is no basis for that statement.

PARA.TAB: I appreciate that I am getting on to that actual basis, but there are two points that I want to refute: firstly, that I am taking an entirely moral stand on it. Wearing another hat, I am happy to take a moral stand on it. Lawrie Kavanagh, in his column in the Courier Mail, said:

Anyway, I'd like to know and I know other Queenslanders are just as curious: do you really recommend young people kiss bums, pee on each other and sodomise their way towards a happier, healthier Australia?

SPEECH.PARA: There is an argument in this regard about the basis of this so-called guide, which I am happy to attack, but that was only part of the basis on which Senator Schacht attacked me. I do oppose it in two regards. But the reality of the matter is that there is no factual basis for the statements in this guide, which was funded by the government with $250,000 and another $20,000 was spent on evaluating it, which we are yet to see. I will have pleasure in questioning that in the estimates committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not many homeless people can afford to buy Cleo.

—As Senator Campbell pointed out, not many homeless children can afford to buy this guide anyway. This is at a time when, as the minister said—again, I quote—`by the age of 21, one in five adolescents have acquired a sexually transmitted disease.' I will be happy to enlarge on this in the process of an adjournment debate, but I think it is important that I place on record my distaste or—
—Disdain.
—Thank you, Senator O'Chee. I will place on record my disdain for an attack made on me by Senator Schacht. I will certainly get back into attacking him on another occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fourteenth report of 1995 of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the committee, I lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 13 dated 20 September 1995.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing with the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill. We seem to be also canvassing the issues in the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2), which was until recently to have been debated cognately. Therefore, I would like to comment on a few of the matters raised both in that bill and by honourable senators in this second reading stage.

PARA.TAB: When the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) was introduced in the House of Representatives, I had high hopes for it as, along with a raft of fairly straightforward, non-contentious changes, it was to allow prisoners sentenced to a term of five years or more to vote in federal elections. The right of prisoners to vote has been consistent government policy in recent years and has been recommended by successive joint standing committees on electoral matters. The government has since backflipped on this stance for reasons which are unclear and which show a total disregard for the civil liberties of prisoners.

Before I go into this issue further, I would like to affirm this bill for the many positive changes it will make. These changes include more flexible arrangements for the Electoral Commission to conduct reviews of the roll, positive changes to voting arrangements for carers and other provisions for overseas voters, enrolment by fax and postal votes.

In the bill which we are debating at the moment there are also a number of straightforward changes to the act, such as the powers of delegation to the commission, objections to electoral enrolment, silent enrolment, the right to vote of divisional returning officers, security marks on ballot papers, canvassing at hospitals, the authorisation of campaign posters, and the important introduction of computerised scrutiny of the Senate vote.

I am exceedingly puzzled as to why we are not debating the two bills cognately. I think it also surprised most of the previous speakers in this debate. In particular, Senator Minchin raised the issue of prisoners' entitlement to vote. That is a very substantive issue which I would like to comment on. The Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters of this parliament, and also of the 34th parliament, supported the right of prisoners to vote regardless of their sentence. It is a stance I have taken, coming from 10 years as a prison psychologist.

There are very good reasons for this. The stripping of citizenship rights is a way of providing an additional penalty on somebody who goes to prison. Admittedly, some or maybe many prisoners would not be at all concerned about this, as they do not hold the political system in high regard, and for many of them that is quite understandable. However, for those who do care that their citizenship right, their franchise, has been stripped, while it would not necessarily be classified as a cruel and unusual punishment, it does represent an additional penalty to the punishment they are undergoing and, to their minds, could be regarded as a cruel political tactic to deprive them even further of any voice in the decision making of their country.

When Senator Minchin was commenting on this I believe he was quite blatant in his disregard for the human rights of people who are within our prison system. As he said, they are serving sentences. They are paying the penalty that has been set down by courts for the offences they have committed. In many cases, the penalties imposed on them are not even intended to be prison sentences. The statistics in Western Australia show that in any one year 45 per cent of all prisoners are in prison for fine default alone.

It is quite true that people who are serving very short sentences, usually of under 12 months, will not be penalised by the particular changes that are being proposed in the government's bill. Nevertheless, we do see a system that is operating in a punitive way on people. Encouragement is now being given to keeping a situation under which those who are in the prison system for longer than 12-months are totally unable to express a voice in terms of their own vote.

I cannot understand, really, the reason for the change of heart of the government. This was supported by the majority of the electoral matters committee. It was opposed by the coalition, but it was supported by a majority of committee members. I was delighted to see it included in the original bill introduced into the House of Representatives.

As I mentioned before, the current Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters recommended the enfranchisement of prisoners and was acting in a similar manner to its predecessor. I was a strong supporter of that move on the committee. Until August this year, it seemed the government shared this belief.

In 1988, the government introduced the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill. This bill recognised the voting rights of prisoners. Senator Robert Ray, the then minister for home affairs, said when introducing the bill in the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators would be aware, a principal aim of modern criminal law is to rehabilitate offenders and orient them positively towards the society they will re-enter on their release. This process is assisted by a policy of encouraging prisoners to observe their civil and political responsibilities.

When the bill came to a vote in the Senate in 1989, this move was opposed by the Liberal Party and prisoners' right to vote was lost. Consistent with its previous stand, the government introduced the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) on 28 June this year, which again removed the exclusion of prisoners from enrolment and voting. Two and a half months later, the bill that we were to be debating today, which has been postponed, no longer has that provision. What has happened in the meantime? The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker), when withdrawing the amendment in the other place, said:
We had reached agreement on this particular issue with the opposition and other parties. Unfortunately, that agreement has been reneged upon . . .

I ask: what agreement had been reached? The Greens (WA) were certainly not approached to reconfirm our stance on prisoners. If we had, I certainly would have provided it. It would be interesting to know whether the coalition or the Australian Democrats were approached by the government and whether they made any agreement over prisoner voting or, indeed, any other issues.

PARA.TAB: The government obviously has the numbers in the House of Representatives to pass the amendment. Unless the government received a commitment from the Australian Democrats that they would oppose this amendment, I cannot see how the government would think it would fail in the Senate. Anyway, the government has rarely been shy in forwarding in this chamber legislation which it knows a majority opposes. So what can it mean?

I believe that the government is showing that its commitment to the prisoners' right to vote is so weak that it is easily reneged upon or that its actions are some kind of payback for a lost agreement that the government believed it had with the other parties. During the committee stage of this bill, I would like to ask the minister what exactly lay at the bottom of this sudden change. No substantive reason for such a major backflip in government policy has been given by the Minister for Administrative Services.

SPEECH.PARA: This week's Bulletin has an article which says why it is very important to recognise what is happening here. There is a grave danger that the stance on prisoners is being influenced by the fact that we are nearing an election. It is despicable—and I know that various people have named it as such—that the law and order auction is utilised by a political party prior to an election. There is an understanding that a popular way of arousing voter support is to come out with harder and harder stances in relation to the law and order issue. That is accompanied quite often by scare campaigns, on the part of major parties, on the prevalence of crime within communities.

PARA.TAB: Page 28 of the Bulletin has a poll which I would like to draw the Senate's attention to. The `Bulletin Morgan Poll' section—which I know is avidly looked at by all members of political parties each week—tackled the topic that `Judges are not tough enough on criminals'. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: Judges are too lenient when it comes to sentencing criminals, according to the majority of Australians surveyed in a special Bulletin Morgan poll.

PARA.TAB: The 69% of Australians who say that judges are too lenient also claim that the offenders "just get a smack on the wrist", that "the sentence does not fit the crime", that "the sentences are not a deterrent" and that judges are "not tough enough, especially in rape and violent murder cases".

SPEECH.PARA: Other issues were canvassed. There was an analysis of the subject by voting intention, and that was very interesting. I will not draw that out at this time because it may be hard to visualise. The reality is that a large percentage of people who would vote for the ALP or the coalition expressed the view that judges are too lenient—the view was shared by 69 per cent of ALP voters; 75 per cent of coalition voters; 67 per cent of `other party' voters; and 60 per cent of `can't say' voters.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that the younger people are, the less likely they are to share that view. Similarly, the question of whether judges are reasonably fair was supported by 23 per cent of ALP voters, 20 per cent of coalition voters, 24 per cent of `other party' voters and 29 per cent of `can't say' voters. Again, looking at the age ranges, we find that the older people are, the more likely they are to have a tough view on judges. Younger people are more likely to admit that judges are reasonably fair.

Very good research on this matter has been done by the Australian Institute of Criminology. It pointed out that the way in which people answer these polls is directly influenced by the degree of information and facts that they are given. In actuality, when people in the Australian community are questioned about appropriate penalties for particular crimes, they invariably express the view that the penalty is too harsh for the crime.

Dr David Indermaur, from the Australian Institute of Criminology, published research Australia wide on this. That was far more representative of community views than a poll could ever be. He demonstrated quite forcefully that, when people come in contact with our criminal justice system, they are appalled by its harshness, by its lack of understanding of human values and human situations and by the totally inappropriate severity of penalties. If what we are concerned about is restoring the community and making the community crime free, it is actually counterproductive to work in that way. That is the point I am making.

Values that the community perceives as being electorally important are being allowed to interfere, in my view, with the legitimate course of decision making in this parliament. It is quite outrageous that six months ago we were saying that we will be progressive and allow the legitimacy of franchise for people in prison, except—and there was one exception—if they are in prison on the grounds of treachery. I think there is a good argument to say that people who are convicted of treachery may, as an appropriate component of their penalty, deserve disenfranchisement. However, we cannot argue that other people deserve disenfranchisement as a double jeopardy penalty for any crime they have committed.

Twelve months ago we said that we were going to be progressive and now, as we are approaching an election, we are suddenly reneging on that—and that is not acceptable. I was asked whether prisoner action groups and councils for civil liberties knew that there was to be a marked step forward on the part of the government and the parliament by allowing voting rights for prisoners—were they aware that that was proposed, and are they aware that they have now lost it? My understanding is that they were not aware that they were about to gain that and neither presumably will they be aware that they are about to lose it. I assure people that I have every intention of letting councils for civil liberties, prisoner action groups and people who really want a just and fair society in Australia know that this is occurring.

I challenge my colleagues in this place to reconsider what we are doing at this point. As Senator Minchin pointed out, prior to the Labor Party changing the policy so that anyone who had a potential sentence of more than five years was disqualified from voting, it actually had a policy that anyone with an actual sentence of 12 months should be disqualified from the right to vote.

In Senator Minchin's view, we are reverting to the Liberal Party standard, which is that anybody who has an actual sentence of 12 months should be disqualified from the right to vote. If what Senator Minchin also recommends is that we change the legislation so that a person with a potential sentence of 12 months should be disqualified from voting, we are really getting into a more regressive system than the Liberal Party was prepared to see in the past.

I would like the opposition to be aware that they will be taking a step back in time—even further back than their own party's position when they were prepared to disqualify people who had an actual sentence of 12 months. The Labor Party was not being all that progressive when it changed the legislation so that a potential sentence of five years disqualified people from voting. In that way, the Labor Party was allowing people who may have had an actual sentence of over 12 months to vote.

There is a problem here in relation to justice and fairness, and it deserves the consideration of everybody in the Senate. Even if the issue does not come up in this bill—and it does not—I am letting my colleagues know that the problem will occur so they have a chance to think through their positions before the paired bill is debated.

It is very important that what we do is seen to be just and fair, because there is an additional problem which does not carry all that much weight with me but it may carry some weight with people who have economic considerations. To actually find out who has a potential sentence of more than five years or who has an actual sentence of over 12 months is a bureaucratic nightmare. There need to be routine reports to the Electoral Commission from all the prisons around Australia to actually have people disqualified or allowed to vote. If we did what was the progressive and enlightened thing to do, it would not be a bureaucratic nightmare.

I conclude my remarks with a serious call for people to address this problem and come to the debate on the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) with fresh thoughts and put to rest some of the concerns that may have been aroused in the community about this regressive stance that has been taken.
