TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its indulgence, for the right to carry on for the final seven minutes of the 20 minutes that I was accorded and was speaking to earlier in the day. I was talking about—and this probably will not help the state of mind and the weight of the iron on the soul of the minister at the table, the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley—the truth in advertising amendment which will be moved by the Democrats to this bill and which will be supported by the opposition. I was saying that we had many examples over the years of a lack of fidelity with respect to the truth in what the ALP had put up in the way of electoral policies.

PARA.TAB: I was on the point of saying before we broke for lunch that the argument was even being taken further than that by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) at the present time, because he was now attacking the concept of truth itself. He was saying that he was going beyond truth in advertising or anything like that and saying, in effect, that there was no such thing as absolute truth. He was using this in defence of one of his ministers in the other place. He was using the argument that everything really was a matter of memory, everyone had a different memory and a different recall, and by inference there was no such thing as accuracy in statements or in the recording of events.

I find that a revolutionary concept and quite untenable. It is really defending the indefensible in relation to one of his ministers. It is an incredible piece of obfuscation, but it is an example of how the Labor Party have come so adrift with respect to the facts of a situation that they are now attacking the very fundamental concept of truth itself. I suppose that, if you have that point of view, it explains why the Prime Minister has just a bizarre view of history. Particularly, his views of Australian military history are quite at variance with the historical records.

But I want to return to the importance of this truth in advertising amendment that we are going to put into this bill, despite the protests of the Labor Party. We saw in the last election all the misinformation fed out about the goods and services tax that the Liberal Party was proposing. The Labor Party convinced the electorate that this would send them broke, that it would be an incredible impost. But, as I pointed out earlier in my speech, the facts of life are now that the Australian public is paying more in indirect taxes than it would have paid if the 15 per cent GST had been imposed and, at the same time, none of the stimulus and the benefits in reducing costs to industry have been passed on. In fact, the taxes that are imposed by this government are very much negative in their effect on business.

We had the great statement of the Prime Minister, the l-a-w tax cuts, which have now disappeared like the Canberra fogs. So we have a long history of the Labor Party not coping with the truth very well at election time. The classical case and the case that is really motivating me to speak on this today was the Queensland state election where the Labor Party went far too far. They went so far in distorting the truth that they almost lost the election, because they neglected the old Churchillian dictum of `trust the electorate'. They tried to fob the electorate off with gross falsehoods with respect to what the opposition policy was and they almost lost the election as a consequence.

The campaign was run by the member for Lilley, Mr Wayne Swan, who is a former state secretary of the Labor Party in Queensland, and Kevin Rudd, who is an ALP apparatchik in the state government and is now the candidate for Griffith. These people are known as the boys in suits by the Labor Party in Queensland and known as Ludwig's office boys to the community in general.

The boys in suits came up with the idea that they would frighten the electorate by saying that the Liberal and National parties would sell all the hospitals. They printed postcards and sent them around the electorates. On the postcards they had a picture of the local hospital with a slogan across it—`The Liberals are going to sell this hospital' or `The National Party is going to sell this hospital'. It was absolutely without foundation. It was really one of the significant reasons why the Labor Party did so badly in that campaign.

It was very interesting, when the election was over, to see Premier Goss, in the great traditions of mateship of the Labor Party, apologise for this gross error in judgment—he said nothing about the morality of it, of course; and all the Labor Party walked away and left Mr Swan and Mr Kevin Rudd holding the baby and blamed them for the gross act of immorality that went on in the campaign.

Not only did we have that; we had stories that the Liberal and National parties were going to log the national forest and that there was friction between the Liberal Party and the National Party. Most interestingly, many of the Labor candidates in Queensland never had the word `Labor' on their corflutes and their advertising material. They stood as `Bill Smith, your candidate for so and so' and ran away completely from any attribution or association with the Labor Party.

There is not much time left this afternoon to talk about the amendment that we will move to the bill, but it is absolutely fundamental for democracy in this country that there is a truth in advertising clause in the Commonwealth Electoral Act applying to campaign material. We can no longer tolerate the situation of the l-a-w tax cuts, of the distortion of our policies and all the other things that the Labor Party have gone on with for generations. If we could see the slightest sign that they were growing up and maturing and not being dishonest with our policies and with their own, then we might take a gentler view. But all we see is an increase in what is, quite simply, political immorality and, for that reason, we will be supporting the amendment to put truth into electoral material.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised at Senator Crowley's comments to Senator Chamarette and to my colleague from Tasmania earlier. I thought we were being very reasonable on this bill. We have pulled four people off the list. I thought you could have been a little more gracious.

PARA.TAB: We are speaking about the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1995. It amends the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984. This bill, like the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill that we debated in May, will affect the conduct of the next federal election. The speedy passage of the bill is important, we believe, because it will allow the AEC to prepare more fully for the conduct of the next election.

I indicate my support for this bill and note the coalition will be moving a number of amendments in the committee stage. I point out that, even though most of these reforms that are proposed in the bill are most welcome, they are really tinkering at the edges. What is needed in this country is fundamental electoral reform that will overhaul the whole system.

This came to my attention particularly last year when I served on the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters during its inquiry into the 1993 election. The committee produced a report. The coalition produced a minority report that recommended 40 fundamental changes to the whole system. We based this on evidence that we received right around Australia on some of the things that happened during that election and on some of the ways in which the Electoral Act clearly was not working.

During the hearings with the AEC people they actually produced a little paper which had a look at 40 possible electoral reforms and all the reasons why they could not implement any of them. The Electoral Commission obviously wants to defend the system it has been administering for the last few years. There are glaring problems, obviously, with the integrity of the roll, but they seem very reluctant to undertake any major reforms. That is certainly what is needed in this country. Nevertheless, the reforms that are proposed in the bill are most welcome, even though they are not the root and branch reforms that have to follow on and will follow on once the coalition is elected to government.

The electoral system that we have in this country and the whole Electoral Act which we are proposing to make minor reforms to today are based on two fundamental principles. One is access to the roll. The other is the integrity of the roll. What became clear during our hearings was the government's emphasis on access to the roll. I do not dispute that that is important. What has happened is that the integrity of the roll has been ignored in many ways in this process. I will go into a number of those as I develop my argument today. For the last 13 years the government has gradually reformed the act to make sure that it is much easier for people to get access to the roll.

Let us look at a number of the glaring problems that were raised in evidence to the joint standing committee. I would like to go through a number of those. For example, there is no check on your ID at the two crucial points. The first is when you do enrol in a new electorate. The second is when you actually front up to vote. My daughter moved to a new electorate. It was a marginal electorate. I suggested that she enrol. I was absolutely amazed by her story. At no point did she have to produce her ID to prove who she was.

What can happen with this process is that people can enrol in multiple seats. If we look at the seat of Macquarie in the Blue Mountains, there was obvious evidence of that. There were people who were enrolled there and whose address was a vacant block of land. They had enrolled right at the end, before the rolls closed. The electorate people did a check of these people. They actually checked over 2,000 sites in the Blue Mountains and they discovered 46 of them were vacant blocks of land. It is a bit cold in the Blue Mountains to live on a vacant block of land. Obviously, no-one lived there, but people were registered at these addresses so that they could vote.

The problem is the way in which the AEC confirms enrolment. They just send out a letter to an address to check whether a person is there. If the letter does not come back, they assume that the address is correct. If there is no `return to sender', the person is put on the roll. What happens is that people in the know have friends enrol at their addresses. When that letter comes, they just throw it in the bin. It does not come back to the AEC; so it is assumed that the person is there. The person is enrolled. The person might live in an adjoining electorate and could live 100 kilometres away. They turn up on the day and vote in that marginal seat.

That is a bit of a problem, particularly in seats like Macquarie, which I mentioned, which was won by a majority of 167 votes. Page was won by 100 votes. Bass was won by 30 votes. It doesn't take many people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Forty.
—The revised figure was 30. The initial figure was 40, but then it dropped to 30.
—You have got to get the maths right if you want to win an election.
—I have got it right, Minister, you haven't got it right.
—I am not a minister, either. You haven't got anything right.
—I have promoted you, have I? I'm sorry. I retract.
—I wish it were true.

—We will put you back to a humble parliamentary secretary. When people turn up to vote they are not challenged to prove who they are or to produce any ID at all. You are only asked the question: `Have you voted today?' What a stupid question! One of our people thought it was such a stupid question that they said, `Yes, I've voted 10 times.' They were handed the form to vote. What sort of a check is that?

PARA.TAB: A person could vote throughout the electorate. If there are 90 booths, as is the case in the seat of Page, which was won by 100 votes, someone could vote 90 times. There are no checks on voting day. You don't have to prove who you are. You are on the roll at 90 booths, and you get crossed off at 90 booths. It may not be you. You do not have to prove who you are. I could go around booths in Tasmania and say I was Nick Sherry. How are they going to prove I am not?

TALK.START.PARA: —They know me down there.
—I am sure you are notorious in most parts of Tasmania.
—There were 40,000 more votes cast at the election before last than there were people on the roll.

—Thank you for that bit of information, Senator Calvert. He has just pointed out that there were 40,000 more voters than people actually on the roll. There are some other interesting stories about that as well. I have indicated that people have double voted. Certainly that occurs. The Electoral Commission admits that 6,000 people were identified as double voters in the last election. Let me put that in some sort of perspective. You had 1,500 votes decide the whole election, across 13 seats; yet 6,000 were unexplained double votes. How many were prosecuted? How many went to gaol for this? In the previous election, in 1990, about three went to gaol. There is this massive abuse.

PARA.TAB: The government accentuates this problem by not providing the Electoral Commission with sufficient staff to do things like roll cleanses that might produce some improvements. They have actually cut the staff back, on average, from three to 2.1 per electorate.

We have this widespread rorting. We have problems with the integrity of the roll in Australia. When our committee suggested to the Electoral Commission that they undertake a major reform of the act, they refused to accept any of those arguments. We will have to wait for a Liberal government to do that.

Meanwhile, the minor changes that are proposed to the act, as I mentioned earlier, are most welcome. There are 86. That sounds impressive, but most of them are non-controversial. They remove hyphens or they remove gender specific language. There are a number of other minor provisions. For example, personal details of silent electors are not to be disclosed to persons inspecting postal vote applications. Disallowing canvassing in and around hospitals that are polling places on election day is a welcome change. The bill also standardises the method of resolving ties in vote counts and allows changes to exempt from full authorisation requirements all letters to the editor items.

It allows the AEC to use an up to date, secure method of security printing of ballot papers, to replace the more costly water mark method. I have some concerns about that. I would be really keen to see that the new system is more secure than the old system. Water marks, although costly, seem a very good way to go. As the whole thrust of what I have been saying is about what is wrong with the Electoral Act and is related to the integrity of the roll and the right votes being cast, I think that is something that should be looked at much more closely.

We are going to put forward our amendments to the bill because we still have a number of concerns. We believe the need to have full authorisation—stickers for cars seems impractical as they cannot be read. The provision to abolish the obligation of the AEC to advertise in two newspapers in states and territories is something we would question. There are in most states two papers that are widely read. Certainly that is the case in New South Wales. In the smaller states, the Australian is obviously a second paper you could use if you wanted consistency. We really believe the former provision there should stay in.

As I have mentioned, we basically support this bill with foreshadowed amendments, as I have indicated. After we get into government, we intend to implement many of the findings of the minority report. We believe it is only through that we will get true electoral reform in Australia. We, and the Australian people, need to have confidence in the integrity of the system and have confidence that the result is fair dinkum and that the government we vote for is in the end the government that is elected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My concern about the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill is that it fails to address many electoral issues that the coalition members of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters recommended in their dissenting report on the 1993 election. There is no doubt there is still the capacity for electoral fraud. The government appears to be totally lacking in concern about that. I suppose one can impute motives, if one wishes to, and say a lack of enthusiasm about fixing up a situation where there is potential for fraud might well indicate that one may believe one benefits from that potential. The fact is the government has completely ignored the issue of electoral fraud and the system is wide open to abuse.

PARA.TAB: The big question is: to what extent have we been able to establish that that abuse exists? I was angry after the 1993 election about a lot of things but one of the things I was particularly angry about was that I had direct mailed the electorate of Gilmore and a very large number of those envelopes were returned—`not known at this address', `left address' and a whole lot of other things. I referred all these to the Electoral Commissioner.

There had been a general view in the past that this was all a great waste of time and that the Electoral Commissioner did not think resources should be employed to examine them. I must say I am glad the Electoral Commissioner did in this case examine the returned envelopes. All I have to remark, though, is that I thought the report by the AEC on the investigation of mail returned was precious, illogical, nonsensical and self-serving. Apart from that, it was terrific.

The mail-out I did was based on a return that came in on 7 February or so in 1993. In other words, the final electoral roll for the mid-March election was not made available until 22 February. In other words, the ones I sent out did not include what may well have been a last minute flood of people wanting to get onto the rolls for a whole range of reasons, some of them may well have been fraudulent. The fact is that the end January enrolment list I had probably did not cover those who may have been fraudulently seeking to change their address from a safe Labor seat, which happened to adjoin Gilmore, into this marginal seat.

This is one of my problems. There has clearly, to my mind, been evidence of people moving their addresses from a safe Labor seat into a marginal seat for the purpose of influencing the result in a marginal seat. As I said, the list I had did not include such last minute attempts to do so, but there may have been other people in my list who had done that for that deceptive purpose. What intrigued me was that the investigation by the Electoral Commission concentrated on the fact that, because I had used the end January list rather than the 22 February list, the list somehow massively diminished the merit of my complaining that there had been a lot of people voting who had not received mail because they were not known at that address, yet they voted in that election.

Yes, I had sent them 1,400 names. In fact, after the commission deducted people who died and people who had subsequently changed between the two lists the commission still ended up with 1,058 names on the roll, mail to whom had been returned to my office—1,058 voters in one electorate could be very significant, indeed. I have an analysis here that the commission kindly did showing what that situation really represented.
Of the 1,058, 224 did not vote at the election. As the AEC says, these are the ones most likely to be no longer living in the division of Gilmore. It sensibly concludes:

SPEECH.PARA: These electors played no part in the result of the election.

They only represented 20 per cent of the returned envelopes. Eighty per cent of the people who did not collect their mail did in fact vote. Were they at those addresses or weren't they? I do not know. The AEC did not tell us. The AEC said:

The remaining 817 electors voted for Gilmore in this election. Of these, 608 cast an ordinary vote: 93% of these ordinary votes were cast in the same town as that for which the elector was enrolled, or in a nearby town.
The illogical conclusion that the AEC then drew was:
Given the rural nature of this Division—
it happens to be right next door to Wollongong and has the town of Kiama in it, which is basically now a dormitory suburb of Wollongong—
this would tend to indicate that these electors were still living at, or near, the address for which they appeared on the certified list for this election.

Bunkum! It may well also mean that people had travelled there from the nearby safe Labor seat of Throsby or Cunningham to vote at their phoney address where they are not known and if you send them mail it is returned. What an extraordinary conclusion, unless there is further work done by the AEC, of which there is no evidence here, that it had pursued these matters. It goes on:
Investigations have also shown that of these ordinary voters, 78 re-enrolled for another address in the February-May 1993 period—all but four of these re-enrolled within Gilmore.

There is no doubt that of the 608 who cast an ordinary vote, about 11 or 12 per cent remained within Gilmore and re-enrolled shortly after the election. The remaining 209 of these voters did not vote by ordinary means; they voted by declaration. In other words, 124 cast an absent vote, 36 cast a postal vote, 47 cast a pre-poll vote and 2 cast a provisional vote.

PARA.TAB: The absent vote figure there is about 2 1/2 times the proportion of absent voting for the division as a whole. Surely that kind of high absentee vote should sound some kind of alarm bell because it clearly indicates that those people may well not have been at those addresses. It is certainly a much higher proportion than for other people within the electorate.

Once again, the real probability exists that people who did not live in the electorate—mail to whom was sent back to me `return to sender'—were able to vote in Gilmore and influence the result in a marginal seat. An examination by the AEC of the post office markings shows that, of all the envelopes that came back, something like 579, or 70 per cent, were returned `left address'. Of those, 70 per cent of the addressees were recorded as having voted by ordinary vote while the remainder had voted by declaration.

The AEC says that very few envelopes were returned stating that the elector was not known in the area—eight of which electors cast declaration votes and 55 ordinary votes. It intrigues me how someone can be `not known at this address' but known well enough to be on the electoral roll and turn up to vote. Of course, there are other reasons for people returning their envelopes.

If you have a post office box you may not want to get what appears to be junk mail. I must say that is an appalling description of a nice letter from me recommending how you should vote. If it is to be described as junk mail, it is very high quality junk mail. Of the 62 mailings unclaimed from the post office, it is possible that they could have been returned for that reason. Of them, 52 were marked `return to sender' rather than `unknown at this address'.

That may have been the result of people not wanting to accept that kind of mailing. I do not know. All I do know is that there was a very large number of people who voted but who do not appear to have been at their recorded address and from whom mail was returned. The conclusion drawn by the AEC is interesting. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Two points have become strongly evident from this study. Examination of the list of names from whom the party mailing was returned unclaimed in the election period has uncovered no evidence of organised fraudulent enrolment or voting:
That simply does not follow from anything that the AEC said. It goes on:
the evidence examined has tended to reinforce a finding that the system is operating with integrity.

That is simply not so. For example, it does not deal with the question of multiple enrolments at one address, because I had not raised that matter. There is a fair prospect of multiple enrolments, particularly if people who really live outside the electorate have one address. It does not deal with the question of vacant allotments. I do not know if the AEC followed up to see whether these addresses were vacant allotments. All I know is that people whose mail was returned still voted in considerable numbers.

PARA.TAB: Something else that interested me in the AEC report is where it says that the volume of mail returned unclaimed was less than the number of persons likely to have changed address since the compilation of the end-December 1982 roll data which was apparently used for this bulk mailing. Naturally it would be, because most of the people who change address leave change of address notices with the post office. That is a most nonsensical comment from the AEC.

It is acceptable, normal procedure that you have a forwarding address for a while. The post office does that for a while. We are talking about changes of address in the last month or so. I cannot understand how the AEC could rationally have come to the conclusions they have come to in this report.

The report notes that it was not a close of roll influx. They sure weren't because I had used the earlier roll. It might be interesting next election to keep the overall mailing until the last minute when we get the latest enrolment list. What particularly annoys me about this inadequate AEC examination is this recommendation:

SPEECH.PARA: In future, the AEC not consider any undertaking to conduct investigations of this nature until both the original envelopes (or photocopies thereof) and a computer record of addressees from whom mail has been returned unclaimed have been provided.
As I understand it, I provided all that. It goes on:
The source of this computer record (extract form mailing data base, re-keyed list of names/addresses of mail returned unclaimed, etc) should be provided.

That conclusion is a pretty smart alec way of saying that because I used the end-January list it was massively incorrect and therefore it wasted its time. The fact remains that 1,058 letters were returned, leaving a tiny fraction of the database inactive.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, the AEC could not adequately demonstrate in this examination that there was no fraud, that people were not living in the electorate and were transferring their vote from where they did live in a safe Labor seat into this marginal area. One good idea was the recommendation:

SPEECH.PARA: On the announcement of a general election or by-election, the AEC immediately advise all parties of the date on which close of roll data is likely to be available, and indicate the "lower return unclaimed" rate likely if the last roll data provided to relevant members/parties is used for election mailings.

Has the AEC ever heard of a forwarding address? According to this report it has not. It assumes that because people have changed their addresses letters will not be sent on to them. Because I do send out such mail, it would be handy for me to know when I should time my mail-out. It then says:

When updating an elector's enrolment, particularly where the elector moves to a new suburb, town or city, if no change has been advised to the old postal address the elector be asked to confirm that the old postal address should be retained, or to advise a new postal address.

I am not saying that this AEC report did not have any merit in it at all. It did; it resolved a few problems. The key thing is, though, that it did not resolve the essential problem of the extent to which there is a potential for electoral fraud. To pretend that that examination has demonstrated the integrity of the roll is just absolute self-evident, patent nonsense.

PARA.TAB: It may well be that the government is taking notice of such information when it determines that it should not close these loopholes. Maybe it is the bureaucratic advice on which the government is acting which has encouraged it not to close clear, evident, available opportunities for electoral fraud in a system that is clearly open to large-scale abuse. I would hope that that is the situation, that it is simply because the government has perhaps been in for far too long that it relies entirely on bureaucratic advice which may well not necessarily be what is in the best interests of Australians. It also, however, might be that allowing this potential for electoral fraud suits the government and, as a result, it is quite prepared not to close off these clear loopholes, which certainly should be closed off. I commend the amendments that the coalition is proposing to the government's legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are conspiracy theories and there are conspiracy theories, and I think today we have just heard the bobby-dazzler of them all. I am someone who also sends out welcome-to-the-electorate letters and material. I send them out into conservative seats. I also get returns. So maybe people in the conservative seats also do not want to receive mail from Labor senators. I am quite prepared to believe and support and uphold the work of the AEC. They have a difficult job to do. People setting off hares about conspiracy theories does nothing to maintain the integrity and the value of this system that we have.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Baume wants to really get into conspiracies of all conspiracies, I suggest that he goes and looks at some of his own seats. You can stand here and play tit for tat, but obviously the discrepancies that Senator Baume sees as conspiracies are apparent, and variations are apparent across all seats.

I would commend to his viewing and his investigation the postal votes from the last federal election for the division of Parkes. They disclosed a very interesting result. The votes on those postal votes were totally against the trend of voting in that electorate and every other part of the election. They were totally against the absentee vote percentages. Lest anybody says it was because the postal votes were done early, let me say it was against the trend and the swings in the pre-poll voting and, more importantly, it was different from the swings in the mobile booth.

I am not complaining and I am not alleging conspiracies, but I want to point out to Senator Baume that, if he wants to come in here and allege that all sorts of conspiracies are being done by Labor Party people next door to safe Labor seats in transferring votes, I think he ought to go and check in his own backyard first, just stop being such a conspiracy theorist and look faithfully and actually at the hard work the AEC does—and he should support it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In closing the debate for the government, I want to run through reasonably briefly our response to some of the debate that has occurred. Like Senator West, like Senator Baume and, I think, probably like all of us, I also send letters out from my Senate office in Devonport, and some come back with `returned—address unknown' for a variety of reasons. I do not see it as any conspiracy. Chris Miles, the member for Braddon, is a member of the Liberal Party. I know that I do not have any particular concerns when I get mail back addressed `unknown' for a variety of reasons. I do not see it as some sort of plot by the member for Braddon to enhance his majority. I think for Senator Baume to make that quite spurious sort of allegation on no evidence at all is totally wrong.

PARA.TAB: Senator Minchin has circulated some amendments. Amendment No. 2 is seeking to ensure that polling officials and other election casuals can work after the age of 65 at federal elections. There is no upper age limit in the Commonwealth Electoral Act. However, at present, the AEC has a policy of not employing over-65s in electoral events because of difficulties in relation to the provision of comprehensive compensation. This is an issue. I cannot recall the legislation that I was dealing with on this matter, but it is a service-wide problem; it is not confined to the Electoral Commission.

I am advised that the amendments, as drafted, do not achieve the end intended. In fact, the draft amendments would provide for extension of service for the senior executive or statutory office holders, such as the Electoral Commissioner and the ordinary staff, employed under the Public Service Act to continue to be employed after the age of 65, leaving no change to the status of polling officials and election casuals.

The government is pursuing this issue, the problem of age discrimination, through service-wide consultation on legislation. I understand that Senator Minchin has sighted correspondence between the Electoral Commission and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission on this issue and has been comforted by progress to date. I am advised that you are comforted, but I am not sure whether that means you are still proceeding with your amendment. While the government is sympathetic to Senator Minchin's concern, it cannot support this amendment for the reasons I have outlined.

In respect of the Democrat amendments, the government recognises that the Democrats do have some concerns with funding particular to their party. We are willing to find a solution, but our advice from the Electoral Commission is that the Democrat amendments will adversely affect other political parties who have not been consulted to date on the proposal to pay money centrally rather than to each state branch. So, until agreement is reached in consultation with other affected political parties, these amendments should be held over for bill No. 2.
A lot has been said about truth in advertising. The opposition—and it is pretty obvious—are still peeved about losing the last election.

TALK.START.PARA: —You stole the election.

—We stole it, did we? That is an interesting reflection on history. We are coming close to the next election, and the opposition seem to be reasonably confident. Concentrate your energies on that. I can recall a lot of federal campaigns since the mid-1960s, since I was politically involved. I can remember some dreadful campaigns about the Labor Party being portrayed as the mask of communism—the communist hordes were going to come down from Asia and Vietnam. We all got pretty agitated about truth in advertising during those election campaigns.
—The DLP.
—The DLP, yes. It is going back to the 1960s. I think that was probably Australian politics at its dirtiest and its worst.
—It was accurate.

—Senator O'Chee, with a smile on his face, says, `It was accurate.' Senator, if you believe that, you would believe anything, wouldn't you? I would suggest you concentrate on the next election rather than continue to perpetuate the myth that you were robbed at the last one. It was your own political stupidity that cost you the probable victory that the polls predicted at the last election. In your quieter and more reflective and honest moments, when you are telling yourselves the truth, you recognise your own stupidity at the last election.
—We were stupid to be honest.
—You weren't honest. We just showed the electorate the consequences of your policies. You know as well as I do that the electorate did not want you.

PARA.TAB: Returning to the provisions: in 1983 the parliament inserted in the Commonwealth Electoral Act provisions requiring truth in political advertising. Those amendments were subsequently considered in depth by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. That committee concluded they were unworkable and recommended their appeal. That was in 1984.

In 1993 the Australian Electoral Commission, an independent organisation, produced a paper on truth in political advertising, again expressing the opinion that such provisions were unworkable. The commission took the view that, while everyone agrees that fair advertising is a desirable objective, political advertising is of such a nature as to make it impossible to legislate for fairness. This is because political advertising promotes intangibles, ideas, politics and images. It is invariably vigorous and controversial, and its truth or falsity frequently depends very much on the personal viewpoint of the voter.

In December 1991 the parliament sought to ban political advertising on radio and television. The High Court ruled this unconstitutional because of an implied guarantee of freedom of speech in our constitution.
Senator O'Chee interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —On reflection, I am very glad we were able to vigorously pursue your policies on TV and radio at the last federal election. I am very glad to be able to do that. Legal opinion obtained from the Attorney-General's Department suggested that, despite the recent judgment of the Supreme Court of South Australia, the opposition's amendment could still be struck down by the High Court as being contrary to Australia's constitutional right of freedom of communication.

PARA.TAB: The Democrat amendment would make it an offence to tell an untruth during political campaigns. I am advised that, contrary to what Senator Lees and Senator Minchin have indicated, this is not the same provision as the provision in the South Australian electoral act. Section 113 of the South Australian act makes it an offence to make inaccurate statements of fact. This is quite different from an offence of making an untrue statement. An offence that is confined to issues of fact is far easier to regulate than an offence requiring the definition of truth. The Australian Electoral Commission argues that it places them in an extremely difficult position—regulating truth in the heat of an election campaign. It will undoubtedly lead to perceptions of bias, thus possibly compromise the political neutrality of the commission.

No parliamentary electoral committee has ever recommended legislation for truth in political advertising. To the contrary, the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters has twice, in the space of a decade, recommended against making untruths in political advertising an offence. In each case, the committee concluded that it would be impossible to regulate truth in a political context. The recent free speech cases in the High Court also suggest such legislation might be unconstitutional.

In recent times the government has noticed that the Liberal Party has increased its campaign of untruths. We have seen pamphlets placed in letterboxes falsely claiming that ordinary Australians each owe a personal debt of $10,000 with respect to Australia's overseas debt. I could speak more about Australia's overseas debt and put it in perspective but this is not the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —We remember the last time.

—Last time it was quite accurate, but that is another issue and not for this debate. We have seen the opposition seek to mislead electors with untruths about the level of taxation in Australia by falsely including superannuation payments to private companies as a tax. You looked very stupid on that one. It was certainly untrue.

PARA.TAB: We have today seen the `lorry of lies' parading another litany of opposition untruths. I understand it was a lorry that was imported from overseas that was used in trying to show the debt burden of Australia and our balance of payments problems. That must have been very embarrassing for you. The Democrats are right: people who parade untruths need to be brought to book. We agree with the principle of truth in advertising but not the drafting of this amendment. We will reserve our right to reconsider this issue and the penalties in the lower house.

With respect to Senator Minchin's first amendment, the bill presently provides for gender information from the Commonwealth electoral role to be provided to accredited medical researchers. The Liberals want to add the provision of the same information to members, senators and political parties for campaign purposes, in particular for addressing letters to constituents. The Democrats asked the government to consult with the Privacy Commissioner. The Privacy Commissioner is not convinced that this reduction to the confidentiality of gender information is justified in terms of competing public interest. We need to weigh this advice in reaching a decision. In terms of eliminating complaints from constituents wrongly addressed, the government is not opposed to the amendment.

With respect to Senator Minchin's amendments Nos 3 to 8 involving newspaper advertising, the bill originally sought to reduce the requirement in the act to advertise writs and redistribution notices in two newspapers circulated in a state to only one newspaper. This is because these days there are much more efficient and cost-effective ways of bringing notices of this kind to the attention of the public. Further, in some states and territories there may not be two widely circulated newspapers available in any case.

The opposition, following lobbying from the media outlets affected, want to retain the requirement in the act to advertise in two newspapers. The government recognises the practical difficulties faced by the Australian Electoral Commission and the fact that unnecessary expenditure is involved, but it is not going to die in a ditch over this amendment if people want to see advertisements placed in two newspapers.

I think Senator Chamarette has circulated amendments with respect to changing the current provisions in relation to persons in prison being able to vote. I think people carrying a sentence of five years or less can vote. The government will not support the Green proposals.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Ordered that consideration of the bill in Committee of the Whole be made an order of the day for a later hour of the day.
Motion (by Senator Sherry)—by leave—agreed to:
That the consideration of legislation continue till 7.20 p.m. today.
Consideration resumed.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Schedule 1, page 4, after item 7, insert the following items:
"7A. Subsection 21(3):
Omit the subsection.

PARA.TAB: "7B. Subsection 21(4):

SPEECH.PARA: At the end, add `but such terms and conditions must not be such as to require the officer to retire from or otherwise leave the service of the Commission solely on the ground of having attained a particular age.'
"7C. After subsection 29(1):
Insert the following subsection:

`(1A) A member of the staff of the Commission, including a temporary staff member and a senior executive staff member, is not to be required to retire from or otherwise leave the service of the Commission solely on the ground of having attained a particular age.'
"7D. Subsection 29(2):
Omit `The Electoral Commissioner', substitute `Subject to subsection (1A), the Electoral Commissioner'.
"7E. Subsection 35(3):
Omit `The terms and conditions', substitute `Subject to subsection 29(1A), the terms and conditions'.".

I wish to speak briefly to amendment No. 2 standing in our name. This amendment refers to the issue of age discrimination within the Australian Electoral Commission. This has been prompted, as the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) said, by the concerns expressed to all of us, I think, by temporary staff of the Electoral Commission who work tirelessly on polling booths at election times, many of whom are elderly and retired and wish to keep up this sort of activity. As soon as they turn 65 they are told that, under the law, they are not allowed to work for the Australian Electoral Commission, and they lose the opportunity to participate in elections in the way they have done for many years.

PARA.TAB: We do not believe that situation is acceptable. We have had discussions with the government about the problem of dealing with these issues on an agency by agency basis. We understand that the government does have, under active consideration, measures to remove age discrimination across the board. But, as I said in my second reading speech, those who have been around longer than I keep telling me that the government has been saying this for many years—and we still have not seen any action.

In fact, there was a letter in the Australian today from my colleague Senator Patterson reminding us that the Hawke government gave an undertaking in 1990 that it would remove age discrimination, and five years later we have seen nothing of that—another broken promise, something we are used to from the government. Of course, Senator Patterson was referring to the paradox in all of this: that Minister Lee, the minister for arts, said last week that he was considering amending the National Gallery Act to enable Mrs Betty Churcher to remain as director even though she had turned 65. So we do find the government's position on this less than convincing, given that for its own purposes it is considering making a specific amendment to overcome the problem of age discrimination inherent in the public sector.
We are advised that our amendment will deal with the problem of temporary staff. One of our amendments is to insert, after subsection 29(1), a new subsection (1A) which says that:

A member of the staff of the Commission, including a temporary staff member and a senior executive staff member, is not to be required to retire from or otherwise leave the service of the Commission solely on the ground of having attained a particular age.

SPEECH.PARA: We are advised that that would cater for the problem that we have raised. We do hope that the government in the next week or so can resolve this problem, particularly in relation to the AEC—and I have sighted correspondence to that effect. But as I say, we are not going to take a pig in a poke on this. There have been a lot of promises made that have not been delivered on. At this stage it is our intention to proceed with our amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will be continuing our support for the basic principle that we should not discriminate on the basis of age. Minister, I note your comments, in particular your suggestion that perhaps this amendment is not doing everything that we hoped it would. If that is the case, then I look forward to you drafting anything that may be additionally required.

PARA.TAB: The minister's office has had long notification that this certainly was going to be on the table today. Like my amendments later where again you are finding bits and pieces that you do not like, although you support the general thrust, I do not think it is good enough. If you have some concrete suggestions, then please bring them back in here. In the meantime we will be supporting the Liberal's amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment, which removes the provision for electoral officers and commission staff to retire at the age of 65, was one that the Greens initially were not planning to support. We certainly believe that people in their later years make an enormous contribution to society in a myriad of endeavours. Even though there may be cases of reduced mental capacity in some people in positions of social responsibility, ideally we should be able to trust both the government and community to recognise where appointments of people or of a person in particular would be inappropriate—not because of age but because of their inability for whatever reason to fulfil the functions they are appointed to carry out.

PARA.TAB: The difficulty we have with this amendment is that there is a retirement age set for all other Commonwealth officers, and we found it difficult to see the argument as to why these officers should be exempted without an across-the-board exemption. So while we would have been more than happy, as we were, to support the removal of the age discrimination when it was proposed by Senator Patterson for Commonwealth public servants, we were not going to support this amendment on the basis of: what is the point of doing it in one case when it is not across the board?

However, having listened to Senator Minchin, I have realised that there may be people who can be of great assistance in the electoral process—at polling booths, et cetera—who have years and years of experience and would be of great benefit to the community by taking on that role. So for that reason I have changed my mind, and the Greens also indicate our support for this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a brief contribution and support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Minchin. It is good to see that his oratory skills have won over the Greens in relation to this proposed amendment.

PARA.TAB: The matters which have been outlined by Senator Chamarette are of some significance. It just seems strange that, within the Constitution, there is no age limit in relation to those who can hold office in this country. We see people like former French President Mitterand well into his 70s—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Reagan?

—and President Reagan in the United States undertaking real and significant roles. Indeed, in the People's Republic of China I think they get into their 80s whilst still making a very real contribution to the body politic. To somehow say that just because people have reached the magic age of 65 they are unable to make a contribution any more to the electoral process, be it as polling clerks or whatever, seems incongruous. I believe that the amendment ought be supported.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the reasons I outlined in my closing of the debate, the government supports, in principle, the removal of the age discrimination of 65 but believes we should have a composite act to deal with all of government employment rather than doing it bit by bit, legislation by legislation. I look forward to the opposition's speedy advancement of that.
—You have had 13 years to bring it in.

—Why didn't you do it when you were in government for all those years? That is not an argument, Senator Abetz.I look forward to your speedy support of that legislation when it comes to the Senate in the near future. But I can count the numbers, so I will conclude my contribution.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that item 8 of schedule 1 be agreed to.

—I oppose item 8. Items 3 to 8 in our schedule of amendments relate to the issue of advertising by the AEC. Currently, as the Parliamentary Secretary has said, there is a requirement to advertise in two newspapers that circulate widely throughout the state. Obviously, where there is only one newspaper circulating throughout the state, the AEC only advertises in that one newspaper. But we do believe that in the states of New South Wales and Victoria there is a problem with the government's propositions in that there are two major newspapers circulating in those states but they have very different circulations. It would be possible for the Electoral Commission to advertise in each of those states in the one newspaper which has very much smaller circulation than the other newspaper. We think that could be a problem.

PARA.TAB: We think writs for elections and redistribution material is very important electoral information which should be drawn to the attention of as many voters as possible and, therefore, should be advertised in two newspapers in the two states where 70 per cent, or whatever, of our population resides. We have considered it carefully, but we just do not think there is ample justification or reason for the amendment proposed, and we prefer that the status quo be maintained.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are we dealing with item 3, or are we—

—We are dealing with item 3. If it is the wish of the committee, we could deal with items 8, 9, 10, 29 and 30 and schedule 2, item 2, together because I believe they all deal with the same issue. If that is the wish of the committee, it is so ordered.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support what has been said and what Senator Minchin has moved. It is such a small amount of money involved in providing whatever additional information we can to the community. I cannot see what the reason was for the government removing this in the first place. I would like the parliamentary secretary to explain to us what the reason was for reducing the level of information getting out to the community.
—I have already covered this matter in the conclusion of the second reading debate. I do not have any further comment to make about it.

—I am afraid it could not have been sufficiently riveting to have come to my attention. The Greens agree with this decision to oppose the clause in the bill. We see the amount of information that should be circulated within the community as widely as possible a principle that should be encouraged. I believe there have been no grounds presented to dissuade us from that position.

PARA.TAB: However, it does allow me to highlight the inadequacy of current advertising provisions for many functions of government. We seem to believe that by advertising in the mainstream press across the country, and often just on the east coast, it will reach a broad cross-section of the community. The reality is that print media is no longer the primary source of information for most of our constituents. Television, pay TV and the Internet now provide the bulk of news and information to Australian society. Many communities—such as Aboriginal communities, remote rural communities, ethnic minorities and other groups—draw their information from a myriad of community based media such as community radio, newsletters, targeted publications and specialist periodicals.

The Greens believe that it is time to take a more creative approach to informing the community about the electoral and political agenda and related happenings. Anyone who has had any of the publication briefs and letters that come out of Senator Margetts and my office fall into their hands will know that that range of mediums and constituent groups varies very markedly from the mainstream press. We want to encourage far better communication to all levels of the community from all members of parliament and from all levels of the electoral process, and that should be engaged in more consciously in the near future. So we will also be opposing these clauses.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The writs is the formal legal mechanism notifying dates for nominations and the close of nominations. There is still a requirement that those dates, plus other information about the election, be advertised separately in more than the state newspapers. So we did not see it as necessary to advertise the writs, the legal mechanism, in more than one newspaper when that information is transmitted in a whole host of other newspapers, and must be.

PARA.TAB: Items negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Schedule 1, page 4, item 11, omit the item, substitute the following item:

PARA.TAB: Insert:

TAB.TAB: A tape or disk containing information that discloses particulars of the sex of electors may be provided by the Electoral Commission to:
(a)a person or organisation that:
(i)conducts medical research; or
(ii)provides a health screening program; or
(b)a member of the House of Representatives, a Senator or a registered political party.'.".

SPEECH.PARA: This is, as the parliamentary secretary indicated, the amendment relating to information about the gender of electors. The government had moved to make that available to certain health organisations. We took the opportunity to suggest that it would considerably assist the political process if that information were able to be provided to members of the House of Representatives, senators and registered political parties. We think it will assist all of us in the process if we are able to address electors accurately and correctly as to whether they are Miss, Mr, Mrs or whatever, rather than having to go through the elaborate process, which many of us now do, of having computer programs trying to identify gender from first names. While you can get a reasonable degree of accuracy in that, it really seems nonsensical to put us through that process when it will assist us if we have it accurately.

PARA.TAB: Obviously we are sensitive to the privacy considerations, and they should be taken account of. But, on balance, we do not think one's gender is a matter of privacy. It is generally obvious to people what one's gender is—whether you are male or female. While you could argue the case of privacy in relation to age or occupation, which used to be on the rolls and have been deleted, in the case of gender we do not believe, on balance, that there is a legitimate privacy argument. We welcome the government's indication that it is prepared to accept this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will also be supporting this amendment.

—I am uncertain about the validity of this component in the bill—not only the amendment that is being proposed by Senator Minchin, but also item 11 of the bill which is proposed by the parliamentary secretary. I would like an explanation on the public record of why this bill will allow the provision of particulars of the sex of electors to organisations that conduct medical research or provide a health screening program. What does this entail? It may, of course, be entirely innocuous, by providing the number of males and females in a particular state or division. However, I would be greatly concerned if it extends much beyond this. I hope the parliamentary secretary will be able to respond to this and clarify it.

PARA.TAB: Additionally, I have some concerns about the opposition amendment. Certainly the amendment fulfils the same purpose as item 11 and, as I said, I would like that clarified. However, also allowing members and senators to be provided with those details opens the same questions. Would the coalition please explain why we should have access to those details and why you would use them? I know you have said that it is just for addressing it correctly, but I think some members of the community might be concerned. That is why it would helpful if the parliamentary secretary responded to the original request and Senator Minchin made a clarification in such a way that allayed any fears any individuals may have that there would be a violation of their privacy by this request and change in the bill.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will deal with the issue of current access and what we are proposing with the access to gender. Currently, for the purpose of medical research, medical researchers have access to the age of people on the electoral roll. They can write to people in a particular age bracket, say, between the age of 18 and 30, to address a particular medical issue or to seek information from those people.

PARA.TAB: In the same way, medical researchers would like to be able to write to, say, women about breast cancer. They cannot do that at the present time. It is very difficult to deal with particular research for issues that are much more common and obviously, in some cases, particular to women. That is why we are extending that right to medical researchers. We believe the public good that comes from that is overwhelming.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could just clarify why the Democrats are supporting the government's original changes. The national breast screening program fell down in Victoria, which would not release information from its electoral roll. As a result, the program in that state is almost light years behind almost every other state.

PARA.TAB: That program needs to be able to identify women, particularly those 50 years and over, so that letters of introduction can be sent to women, advising them of where their nearest breast screening unit is or to see their doctor or whatever. When we looked at the results as part of the Senate inquiry into the national program in Victoria, we discovered how few women have been able to access this program because they have not been getting the letters inviting them to do so in the first place. That is one of the reasons why this original amendment is needed.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could just respond to Senator Chamarette's contribution. Political parties, members of the House of Representatives and senators are all provided with electoral rolls now. Information as to gender is on the rolls which are held by the Electoral Commission. But, as a result of amendments some years ago, information relating to gender is suppressed. So, when we receive our print-outs, that information is not there. On the face of it, if you want to write to your electors, you do not know whether you are writing to a `Mr', a `Mrs', a `Ms' or whatever. We think that is a fairly silly sort of restriction. It means that you can get it wrong. It upsets the voters if they get letters from members of parliament that are incorrectly addressed. Someone who is actually a `Ms' may get called a `Mr'.

PARA.TAB: The major political parties have had to go through the process of designing computer programs which read first names—they are provided to us—and determine whether they are male or female names. We have about a 95 per cent accuracy rate, but we have to go through that process. What we are saying is that we have to go through the process of determining the gender anyway. We can get it right; we have a 95 per cent accuracy rate. Therefore, what is the point of suppressing that information? As I said, I really do not believe that there are privacy implications with respect to information indicating whether somebody is male or female. The point is that we want to correctly address electors.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) and all the other senators who have commented on this amendment. It was probably helpful for people who might be concerned about that matter. The Greens neither support the amendment nor the proposition by the government. But we can count, as can Senator Sherry. So I am simply going to place on the record the fact that the Greens have always had a concern about unsolicited mail and the fact that parliamentary officers have access to the electoral roll and can, in a kind of scatter-gun approach, send mail to all their electors.

PARA.TAB: It is quite arguable that members of parliament feel that that is their way of being accountable to their community. I am recognising that there is a very strong argument that would support that view. However, there are also other people who are very offended by receiving such unsolicited mail. You are quite right; they do get very annoyed when they can determine how unsolicited it is, particularly when it incorrectly addresses them as `Mr' or `Ms'. However, it is a guide to them that that is what is happening. Once this amendment is passed, it means they will not even have that. There will be the kind of personalised approach which still comes from a battery of computers across the country.

I want to put on the public record that at the moment in our Senate office we make an attempt to write letters only to people whom we know want to receive them from us. You might think that is not electorally very clever, but it is attempting to be respectful to people who do not want to receive junk mail. If we did send out all this unsolicited mail, you would be the first to comment on how many trees we were instrumental in cutting down in order to do so. We do not send out vast quantities of mail to people who may not want to receive it. At this point, I will conclude by saying that this amendment does not have our support.
Amendment agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the general thrust of our first three amendments to the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill. I am interested in the comments of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) in relation to the guarantee that we got last time—I think it was in May or June this year—that the government would assist us and support us in our efforts after we supported your original amendments, which dealt with the needs of your party, the opposition and the Greens.

PARA.TAB: You came back in here and said, `Sorry, the Electoral Commission doesn't like what you're doing,' yet we have never had anything in writing from your office to say precisely what it is that it does not like. All I can go on is what you have said and what the Electoral Commission has said to us, which is basically that it does not like the way our party operates. The fact that we operate nationally somehow does not fit neatly into its scheme of things. Therefore, I suggest that, if we are going to wait until the Electoral Commission approves of the structure and the way in which we operate, we will be waiting an awful long time. Does that therefore mean that you are now making the decision that you are no longer going to abide by your undertaking to help us and assist us with what we are trying to do?

You mentioned that you are worried about it affecting three other parties. Again, we have not had all of this in writing so that we can delve into it further. If these are the same three parties as were mentioned to us yesterday, they are not represented in any federal parliamentary house—neither here nor in the other place. If you read our amendments carefully, you will see that a registered political party may appoint a principal agent. It is not compulsory for them to do so. It is simply an option that they can take.

Before I move these amendments, let me say that I do want to get some amendments that everybody supports. That is the way we worked it last time when we looked after the interests of the Liberal Party, the Labor Party and the Greens. Can I have an undertaking, firstly, that we will deal with this next week when the other bill comes before us and, secondly, that we will seriously work something out whether or not the Electoral Commission ever agrees with the way that the Australian Democrats are structured.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did indicate in my reply to the second reading debate that we support in principle what you want to do. We have given that commitment to you. But we are not going to inadvertently affect other parties, including ourselves, in an adverse way in achieving that outcome.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that, through the second piece of legislation which will come in here next week, we can effect the changes that you desire. But we want to be sure—we have not completed our advice on this—that it is done correctly and that there is no reneging on the commitment given. We just want to make sure that the details are properly covered.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —If that is the case, then I will not go ahead and move these three amendments today. But I do remind the parliamentary secretary that that is exactly the same undertaking that was given in this place three months ago. We have seen nothing concrete. It has been left to us to do the work. Our first lot of amendments was thrown out. That was fine; we went back to the drawing board. We drew up a second lot. It was not until yesterday that we finally got anybody to seriously look at those amendments. So I am going to take you on your word that we will see everything next week. I hope that by Friday of this week we will have a copy of what you are recommending as the workable amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the assurances that I give seriously. If you have a particular problem and you do not believe it is being addressed by the minister's office, you can contact me and I will also get involved in that process.
