SPEECH.PARA: As those who have read through these amendments will note, they mirror one another. Amendment 4 deals with truth in advertising during an election. Amendment 5 deals with the same issue but during the period of a referendum.

PARA.TAB: I will speak very briefly on this because I spent most of my time during my speech on the second reading debate dealing with this issue. I note again with interest that the Labor Party supports the principle, and I am very pleased that we have that undertaking here today. However, again we seem to have these problems with the detail. The government has had these amendments for about two months; certainly for the same amount of time as the Liberal Party. If the government wants to come to us between now and when this goes through the other place and comes back here and actually discuss any finetuning, we are only too happy to talk to it as we always have been. But we will not let the principle slip by at this point.

I believe that the community expects us as politicians to do something about what happens at election times. When you, Senator Sherry, addressed us a short time ago and gave us examples, I argued that you were speaking to my case by saying that you believe there have been problems with the truth during elections. I believe that the community expects all of us to deal with that. That is why I will persist with these amendments at this point. Hopefully, we will see it get through before the federal election.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to confirm the coalition's support for Democrat amendments 4 and 5 which relate to truth in political advertising. A number of coalition speakers, including myself, indicated the reasons why we believe it is now appropriate for the Commonwealth Electoral Act to include such provisions. I said in my speech that in the ideal world one would hope that such legislation was not necessary and that the parties could conduct their affairs in campaign terms in a way that did not require such legislation. But I think the parliament does need to be aware that we have legislated to prohibit corporations from advertising in a way that is untrue and/or misleading to customers. I really do think, as do my colleagues, that we should apply the same standards to ourselves when we are advertising our wares and advertising in our marketplace—the political marketplace—in campaigns.

PARA.TAB: The parliamentary secretary reminded us that the Australian Electoral Commission has a view that this is unworkable. We reject that proposition. The legislation is not that dissimilar to the South Australian legislation. South Australia has proved that this legislation is, in fact, workable. It is worked by the electoral department of that state. The electoral department of that state has no difficulty applying the law. If a complaint is made to the electoral department it refers the matter to the DPP for investigations as to whether a prosecution should be brought. It was the case that in the last state election in South Australia that process occurred. The DPP believed that a prosecution should be brought and the state secretary of the Labor Party was prosecuted successfully. The Electoral Commissioner in the state of South Australia has no difficulty working with this legislation.

The Australian Electoral Commission is responsible to us and to the people of Australia for applying all the rules in the Electoral Act that govern election campaigns. We as a parliament have indicated through legislation that there have to be rules by which elections are conducted. There are many offences provided for in the Electoral Act which the Electoral Commission is responsible for administering and for referring to the appropriate authorities when complaints are brought to them. We do not see that in principle there is any difference between those sorts of offences and the proposed offence of authorising untrue and misleading advertising.

If a complaint is brought, it is for the AEC to refer the matter to the DPP for investigation and determination as to whether a prosecution should be brought. It will not compromise the Australian Electoral Commission in any way. It has not compromised the electoral department of South Australia, which has proved that the legislation is workable. As a state director of the party in that state I operated under this law for the eight years that I was director—a law brought in by the Bannon Labor government in South Australia. It was my responsibility to make sure that our advertisements did not breach the act and I operated on that basis. There was never a complaint brought about any ads that we put to air during that time.

In summary, my position is that such legislation is workable. It is the only argument which the government and the Electoral Commission seem to proffer as to why they are not prepared to accept this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few brief comments. I did address the question of truth in political advertising during the second reading debate on this matter. I concur with the comments made by Senator Minchin that these amendments will not of necessity draw the Australian Electoral Commission into making decisions as to whether or not a certain political party has misled the public or not. If a complaint is received, it would be appropriate for them to simply handball that complaint with any supporting evidence that has been provided to them to the Director of Public Prosecutions and for them to investigate and ascertain whether or not a sustainable case can be brought for prosecution.

PARA.TAB: Just in case there are people listening and concerned about what this amendment is actually all about, I think it is worth while to point out that it deals with untrue, misleading or deceptive advertising. The question arises: what happens if someone makes an honest mistake? That is covered in the raft of amendments proposed by the Australian Democrats, which the coalition supports. It would be appropriate to briefly read that part of the amendment into the record:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is a defence if the person proves that he or she did not know, and could not reasonably be expected to have known, that the electoral advertisement contained a statement of the kind referred to in subsection (2).

For example, if somebody honestly and reasonably relied on a published statistic from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, which was later found or shown to be incorrect, they would have a defence to the allegation that they had been peddling untrue, misleading or deceptive material. I think it is appropriate that it be put on record that there would be a defence to such a charge in the event that the person did not know and could not reasonably have been expected to have known that the information that they were relying on was untrue, misleading or deceptive.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The grounds for the government opposing a number of amendments is not just on the grounds of practicality but also on the grounds of doubtful constitutionality. Senator Abetz was president of the Liberal Party in Tasmania for some years. I do not know whether he still is. I do not know what the Liberal Party has done about truth in advertising legislation in Tasmania as a state government. We look forward to outbreaks of truth in advertising legislation from all Liberal governments around Australia.

—The Greens have obviously indicated to the Democrats that we support the spirit and the principle underlying these amendments. There is only one comment that I wanted to make—that is, that I believe it is quite appropriate that in the amendments the Democrats have allowed for a fine rather than a fine or a prison sentence to be the appropriate penalty for their truth in advertising amendment. I only wish that they had also applied that to the other two offences of a similar kind that relate very much to this. I am only saying this by way of summary because I do not have the act in front of me.

PARA.TAB: The other two offences to which this provision could apply are ones for people who print and publish misleading information or for people who mark their ballot paper other than is appropriate. I think that a penalty is appropriate. I do not believe that a prison penalty is appropriate. The principle that prisons should be a penalty of last resort should operate. People who do this are worthy of receiving some kind of disciplinary action but to have criminal penalties is inappropriate.

I would have been very pleased if the Democrats had exempted (1) and (3) as well as (2) from subsection 329(4)(4A). Unless at this late stage they are willing to accept a further amendment to their amendment, I just make that comment and indicate support for the amendments moved by Senator Lees.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Schedule 1, page 4, after item 12, insert the following items:

PARA.TAB: "12A. Paragraph 93(8)(b):
Omit the paragraph.
"12B. Section 109:
Repeal the section.
"12C. Subsection 110(1):
Omit `sections 108 and 109", substitute `section 108'.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment relates to the qualification of prisoners for voting. I draw the attention of my colleagues to the history of this clause in the bill. The Electoral Act at the moment disqualifies from enrolment and voting any prisoner under sentence for an offence punishable for five years or longer. The act provides that controllers-general of prisons shall, on a monthly basis, provide the AEC with lists of such prisoners. This has constituted an enormous bureaucratic headache not only for the Australian Electoral Commission but presumably for all the controllers-general of prisons, because the basis for disqualification is the potential sentence for an offence and not the actual sentence imposed.

PARA.TAB: The AEC in its submission to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters made the request for a change from potential sentence to actual sentence. This is one of the reasons they gave for the difficulty:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we are just not in a position to recognise all the cases and court outcomes where the offence involved is one punishable by imprisonment for five years or longer. It is possible, for instance, for a person to be convicted of an offence carrying a maximum penalty of five years or longer in prison, with the court then imposing a much lesser penalty such as a bond, fine, probation, home detention, etc . . . other jurisdictions are experiencing the same difficulty [and are] furnishing monthly section 109 returns based on prison sentences of five years or more actually imposed.

You can see that that whole idea of a potential sentence makes it an actual nightmare for the prisons departments to actually track down the location of prisoners who have that offence. The AEC also suggested that that disqualification provision was potentially inequitable—and I quote:

. . . because the exclusion from enrolment refers to a potential rather than an actual sentence, a person serving an actual sentence of one month could be excluded from enrolment, while a person on a sentence of 59 months could be eligible, depending on the potential maximum sentence in each case. Thus the present legislation takes no account of the Court's assessment of the seriousness of the offence.

The AEC submitted that the basis for disqualification should be an actual rather than potential sentence of five years or more. I might add, as somebody who has worked in the prison system, that keeping it as an actual sentence of five years or more will not lessen the bureaucratic nightmare of reporting on a monthly basis because, as people know, remission terms are different in every state and in almost every prison, for good behaviour, or for every individual prisoner. So a remission of one-third of the time or taking it back to three-quarters of the time also is going to cause a nightmare administratively.

PARA.TAB: It would have been very simple to have taken the very enlightened position that this committee took at this point. The majority—that was the Labor members and me—on the committee agreed that the existing legislation should be changed such that enrolment and voting rights be granted to all prisoners regardless of their sentence, with one exception, and that was for treachery.

In support of the recommendation the committee argued that an offender once punished under the law should not incur the additional penalty of loss of franchise. We also noted that a principal aim of the modern criminal law is to rehabilitate offenders and orient them positively towards the society they will re-enter on their release. We considered that this process is assisted by a policy of encouraging offenders to observe their civil and political obligations.

I might add that it was not true altruism and progressiveness in total. In addition, to encourage prisoners to observe their civil obligations, the proposed change would be far simpler administratively than the existing arrangements. That was the position of the committee. Suddenly, as I mentioned in my speech in the second reading debate, there was a change of heart or a change of mind by the government. They originally introduced a bill into the House of Representatives which removed that and allowed franchise for all prisoners regardless of sentence. In his speech on 29 August, the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker), said they had changed their mind. I mentioned in my speech in the second reading debate that there seems to have been a bit of cross-issue petulance that led to the change. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We had reached agreement on this particular issue with the opposition and other parties. Unfortunately, that agreement has been reneged upon and we are now getting into the usual auction that we see in the community today on who is the toughest on crime. The proposition that the Electoral Commission put forward—that a crime with a sentence of five years be the appropriate provision—has now been changed to one year.

What he said next was extraordinary and illustrates the political nature of views in this regard. He was declaring, I believe, a conflict of interest. Maybe I should, too, because I am sure there are prisoners within the Western Australian prison system who may want to exercise their votes and who may want to vote for me. So I declare that right now and say that it is not just in order to gain their votes that I am pressing for these changes. In fact, if you think about it, for senators to resist the changes on the basis that it would deprive me of those votes would be a very ill-judged and unfortunate thing to do. To illustrate the potential political nature of this decision and to support my argument that we should go back to the more progressive, enlightened stance, I quote from this extraordinary paragraph in Mr Walker's speech:

I find it a little difficult to speak on this issue, given that I was the minister responsible for the New South Wales Electoral Act for many years, which had a 12-month provision. My motives were purely political at the time. We did a survey of prisoners and discovered that 80 per cent of them wanted to vote Liberal if they had the opportunity. So, for pure political reasons we were never prepared to amend the act. There are other more altruistic people out in the community who wanted to rehabilitate prisoners, so we saw a five-year provision prevailing in most of the country. . .

And here I am going on to another salient point, which is that it is different in many states. He says that in Victoria, the ACT, the Northern Territory and federally, there are differences in who is allowed to vote. He makes the point that there are extremes. He says:

In South Australia all prisoners vote. That is the one extreme. The real extreme is in Tasmania, where no prisoners vote, no matter what the sentence—whether it is a day for a parking fine or whatever, you do not vote. That is the hard line. I would have thought that is where we would have ended if I got into an auction today of one year, five years or whatever. We would have ended up with the Tasmanian position. However, that is not the case. The amendment that will be moved later is for 12 months.

My understanding is that all of this would be made a lot simpler if I could persuade my colleagues in the chamber to support the Greens' amendment, which would revert back to what I believe is the only position that can be justified on a civil liberties stance. It is totally unjust and it is totally arbitrary. We are not saying that once you have been in prison for a certain length of time, when you get out of prison you cannot vote. It is a distinct double punishment for people who happen to be in prison at the time of an election who actually want to vote. I urge people to rethink their position on it. I certainly urge support for my amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I place on record the coalition's complete opposition to the Greens' amendment. While we respect the integrity of the position adopted by Senator Chamarette, we believe she is completely out of touch with community sentiment on this issue. What her amendment seeks to do is to restore the government's original position, which was to allow all prisoners to vote, as is the case, I understand, in South Australia. In fact, I gather that is still the platform of the Labor Party. The Labor Party platform still says it wants all prisoners to vote, which we think is completely unacceptable and, as I say, quite out of touch with community sentiment.

PARA.TAB: What happened was that, when the government announced that it was going to let all prisoners vote, the community reaction was just extraordinary. The fact is that people in Australia are very worried about the law and order issue. People generally think there is a problem with prisons and prison sentences. Most law-abiding Australians believe that if you commit a crime you should be punished and, when receiving your punishment—punishment meaning you are in prison—you should lose the rights and privileges of normal civil society and be denied the freedom of normal social intercourse.

One of the rights that you should by definition lose if you commit a serious offence is the right to vote. The irony is that, under our compulsory voting laws, prisoners are compelled to vote unless they are disqualified by the current arrangements. In passing, may I say that I heard what the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Walker) said about the law in New South Wales. I cannot believe that Mr Walker would do anything political, and I am sure that he was speaking tongue in cheek when he referred to a survey that he had done.

The point about New South Wales law is important. We will be moving amendments to the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) to provide that the trigger for disqualification be 12 months. One of the reasons we are doing that is to bring the Commonwealth law into line with the law in New South Wales, where half the prisoners in Australia reside. We think it makes a lot of sense for the New South Wales and Commonwealth laws to be similar.

We also note that the Commonwealth constitution states that there is a prohibition on anyone serving in this place who is also serving a sentence of 12 months or more. We think there are a lot of reasons for going the other way and making the law in the legislation a 12-month rule. I want to point out that the current law—the five-year cut off—affects only a tiny number of prisoners. The fact is that, under current law and even with our amendments, the overwhelming majority of prisoners in prison on election day will still be entitled to vote and will in fact be compelled to vote. Only 10 per cent of prisoners are serving a sentence of 12 months or more, so the proportion of prisoners serving sentences of five years or more must be absolutely minuscule. On those grounds, we believe that Senator Chamarette's amendment is inappropriate, should be opposed and is out of touch with community sentiment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking individually on this issue, because I have not had the opportunity to discuss this with my colleagues. I understood that this was coming up when we discussed the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. I hope we will see that bill next week, and I will give the formal opinion of my colleagues then as well. I certainly have sympathy for what Senator Chamarette said.

PARA.TAB: I would like to look at the Liberal amendments, and this is the first time I have heard of them. I am not prepared at this point to vote one way or the other on this issue. I would like to discuss it with my colleagues and also look at what happens in other states. Therefore, the Democrats, at this point, will not be supporting the Greens. We will simply be staying out of this vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few brief comments in relation to this matter. I also oppose the amendment moved by the Greens, but I do not do that on the basis of what Senator Chamarette described as the auction currently taking place within the body politic of who is toughest on crime.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry, who reads the Tasmanian papers, will be able to indicate to the Senate that I was severely criticised by one member of the Tasmanian parliamentary Liberal Party at our recent state council meeting for my stance and proposed suggestions on how crime ought to be dealt with. Let me say that I was delighted that my point of view received a majority support.

I am not trying to be hairy chested on this issue and say that we are tough on crime. Having spent a lot of my time as a defence lawyer visiting people and clients in prison, I realise the importance of trying to rehabilitate people and give them an opportunity to be part of mainstream society. It would be fair to say from the statistics that those who are sentenced to imprisonment for an actual period of 12 months or more usually fit into the recidivist category and are in prison for more serious offences.

I was interested to hear the survey that Senator Chamarette quoted that Mr Walker allegedly undertook. It is clear that the survey could not have been undertaken in a Western Australian prison, because I am sure that the Labor Party would get about 100 per cent support in those prisons. I suppose in New South Wales during the Labor Party's reign the former Minister for Corrective Services, Rex Jackson, undoubtedly got donations for the Labor Party to allow people out of gaol. So chances are that those left in the gaols were those who refused to give donations to the Labor Party; undoubtedly, they were Liberal voters.

On a more serious note, I refer people to section 44(ii) of the constitution, which says that a person is disqualified from sitting in either house if they have been convicted and are under sentence, or subject to be sentenced, for any offence punishable under the law of the Commonwealth or of a state by imprisonment for one year or longer. I think the 12-month period we on this side are suggesting will somehow fall into line with the constitutional provisions. I think that makes sense. Time is getting on, so let me simply repeat again that I concur with the comments of Senator Minchin.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose the Greens' amendment. We believe the current provision of five years is an appropriate balance. Obviously, we will not be supporting the amendments foreshadowed by Senator Minchin to the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill (No.2). We believe the current provision is appropriate and reflects community views.
—I just indicate that I am not planning to call a division on this, but I would like my name and my colleague's name recorded as wanting to support this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the adjournment debate tonight I wish to once again canvass the activities of the National Media Liaison Service. This is an organisation which has the benefit of $1.5 million worth of taxpayers' funds. It is allegedly an organisation or a service to the public designed to provide timely information. It is clear from talking to journalists in the press gallery here that it is anything other than that and, in fact, is an active propaganda machine on behalf of the Australian Labor Party and this current government.

PARA.TAB: In recent times, Senator Kemp and I have been pursuing the question of the National Media Liaison Service and have been successful in having Mr Epstein removed from being in charge of that service. It has in recent times lowered its profile, but people who have been following the debate on the National Media Liaison Service will know that we have been pursuing the issue of the National Media Liaison Service and its operations now for some considerable period of time.

Within the Senate, there are estimates committee hearings which allow senators to question the allocation of funds and the functions of various areas of the Public Service as administered by the government. We on this side of the chamber have experienced all sorts of problems in trying to get to the truth of what the National Media Liaison Service gets up to. Both Senator Kemp and I have been very active in pursuing the issues during estimates hearings and have posed a lot of questions.

In recent days, I have received certain answers to questions raised about the National Media Liaison Service. It is noteworthy that those questions were asked on 22 June 1995. It has taken nearly three months for these answers to come back from an organisation which allegedly provides timely information. The delay clearly is unacceptable, especially when one looks at the answers that were provided. As an example, I asked for a copy of the memorandum which gave rise to the Attorney-General's opinion on the status of Mr Epstein's employment, who was at that stage signing letters as the Director of both the Ministerial Media Group and the National Media Liaison Service. The answer we were provided was:

SPEECH.PARA: Communication between solicitor and client is privileged.
It took us three months to get that information from an organisation which claims that part of its function is to provide timely information.

PARA.TAB: If we were to accept that answer, how on earth does the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, explain his willingness to provide Dr Griffith QC's opinion in relation to the payment of Dr Carmen Lawrence's legal costs? Who is the client in this case? It was not Mr Epstein. The client was the minister seeking information to ascertain the true status of Mr Epstein's employment. We are told that it has solicitor-client privilege, the government claiming within itself this sort of privilege. Seeing that the Leader of the Government in the Senate is prepared to release letters when it is of assistance to him, the opposite undoubtedly is true—that, when the letters are not of assistance, solicitor-client privilege is claimed. To get that seven-word answer it took three months.

I asked another question in relation to Mr Epstein's activities and his continual denials that he was the Director of the National Media Liaison Service when he had, in fact, signed letters saying that he was the Director of the National Media Liaison Service. Indeed, one of those letters was published in the Age newspaper, so he could not deny that he had written the letter. We happened to ask for a file copy of that. It took them three months to tell us:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no copy of the letter in the files of the NMLS.
Three months!

PARA.TAB: One has to ask: why not? What is the state of the files within the National Media Liaison Service? Who is responsible for keeping those files? Is this a situation where certain evidence has been destroyed? Because another question was asked: `Are there any other letters signed by Mr Epstein as director of both the Ministerial Media Group and the National Media Liaison Service?' It took another three months for this answer:

SPEECH.PARA: No such letters have been located on the files of the National Media Liaison Service.

But it does not mean they have not been written, because we already have proof positive from the letter published in the Age that those sorts of letters were in fact written and signed by Mr Epstein as the director of the National Media Liaison Service. If that letter, which we know existed, is no longer around, one has to ask: what has happened to that letter as well as all the others?

PARA.TAB: My colleague Senator Kemp asked for a copy of Mr Epstein's pay slip advice which Mr Epstein had shown to the media. That was of some particular importance to us. Let me remind the Senate that a lot of the material that Senator Kemp and I have been able to rely on has been a result of journalists, to use that term, leaking it to us to explain what the National Media Liaison Service gets up to. We knew that Mr Epstein had shown his pay slip to the media. We asked for a copy of that. The answer—and it took three months for this answer to be thought of and provided to us—states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Epstein advises that Senator Kemp is in error as he did not show any such document to the Press Gallery.

We did not ask about the press gallery; we asked about the media. It could well have been a member of the media who is not part of the press gallery. Once again, we will have to ask further questions, dig further, dig deeper, to come up with the truth as to how the National Media Liaison Service has been operated.

PARA.TAB: We were very much of the view that Mr Epstein used to operate as both director of the ministerial media group and the National Media Liaison Service. Therefore, we asked for a copy of the cards that used to be printed for Mr Epstein at taxpayers' expense. I asked for a copy of all business cards that Mr Epstein had during his role with the National Media Liaison Service. One would expect that with the printing approval, the dockets, et cetera, there would have been a draft of the business card so that the printing people would know what to print. The answer—once again, it took three months—states:

SPEECH.PARA: No further material can be provided.

The simple fact is: no material has been provided whatsoever in relation to the business cards. It just seems somewhat incongruous that like the letters they cannot find—letters we know were actually written but they cannot find the carbon copies of—similarly for some reason all the records in relation to the business cards also seem to have disappeared.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp asked, for example, for a copy of any amended advice from the Attorney-General concerning the employment of Mr Epstein in light of the questions Senator Kemp had raised on the advice. The answer—once again, it took three months to get this answer—states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister was not moved by Senator Kemp's questions to seek further advice.

Basically, it is all too embarrassing for the government and, therefore, the minister will not provide the information. Let me say to the government and the National Media Liaison Service that this issue will be further pursued at estimates. This lack of detail, failure to answer questions and obfuscation highlights the need for the new person in charge of the National Media Liaison Service to explain its terrible approach to reporting to the parliament and answering questions that were appropriately asked by Senator Kemp and me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday we had an urgency debate in relation to tailings dams associated with gold mining. In the course of that debate, Senator Campbell made some rather outrageous statements in relation to the `endlessly renewable nature of non-renewable resources' and accused me of being a fairy at the bottom of the garden. Among other things, he, by implication, accused the World Bank of being an even bigger fairy and the ABS, which has also estimated the value of resources in the ground, of being a fairy at the bottom of the garden. I will develop that as I go along.

PARA.TAB: The point I was making was that the two mines in question in New South Wales had claimed in a 60 Minutes interview that the gold would produce wealth of $250 million in one case and $100 million in the other. The point I was making was very simple—those resources have a value in the ground and estimating their value, once you have dug them up without taking off the capital value of those resources in the ground, is simply a trick of accounting.

Senator Campbell is not stupid. Senator Campbell is either ignorant of basic accounting methods or he is being deliberately misleading. Every accountant knows that in a business you keep a capital account and a cash flow account. When you cash in part of your capital you do not show that as an increase in wealth; you show that as a transfer from capital to cash flow.

The World Bank—and I think all senators will have seen this earlier in the week—has attempted to develop a system of national capital accounts. It has done so for the very good reason that unless you do keep account of those national assets, those non-renewable resources—the forests, the clean air, the water and all the other assets, as well as the human assets of education and health, which the World Bank counted, and the built environment assets—and put them down as capital value, you are totally misled in relation to the exploitation of those resources.

The value of those when you cash them in appears as if by magic in your cash flow account and you think you have become more wealthy, whereas all you have done is transferred wealth from one account to the other. I repeat again: the World Bank is carrying out this exercise. If Senator Campbell wants to call the World Bank a fairy at the bottom of the garden, let him do so. All I say is: some fairy, some garden!

Non-renewable resources within the bounds of a country are exactly like wealth. A country which is rich in natural resources is rich compared with a country which has no natural resources. Non-renewable resources, the mineral resources, can be exploited once. They can be taken out of the ground. They can be cashed in, as it were, just like money in the bank. But once they are cashed in those resources are to longer there. That wealth has disappeared but you have the cash in hand.

The whole point about sustainability is that you take into account what is called intergenerational equity. That wealth in the ground, which is owned by the whole country, is not only owned by the present generation; it is also owned by all future generations of Australia. Consequently, the principle of intergenerational equity means that you husband that wealth; you exploit it very slowly, recognising that it is non-renewable and also you should be very careful as to what exactly you spend it on when you do cash it in.

I think it was Amery Loven some years ago who drew a very nice analogy in this area. He said you do not develop a bank account by drawing money out of it. Yet that is precisely what we are doing when we mine non-renewable resources because non-renewable resources are just that; they are non-renewable. They are not, as Senator Campbell and others have tried to maintain, endlessly renewable. Once exploited, they cannot be exploited again.

When you take a tonne of coal out of the ground and you burn that coal, you cannot burn it again. You have burnt it once; it is gone. If you take metals out of the ground, such as gold, and you use those, certainly you can recycle the uses of those but you can never get 100 per cent recycling. The second law of thermodynamics tells you quite incontrovertibly that you cannot get 100 per cent recycling. There is a continual run down in those resources once they are exploited.

The value of these resources in a proper accounting system should be shown exactly as a business does its accounting. When you exploit a capital asset such as a gold deposit in the ground, you show that as a shift of wealth from your capital account into your cash flow account. If you take $1,000 out of the bank, you are not more wealthy; you have simply converted it from capital to cash.

Why would you take resources out of the ground? Senator Campbell was quite wrong yesterday. I am not opposed to mining. I am just saying that you need to do the accounting correctly and you need to be very judicious in the way you spend the money that you get from that non-renewable resource.

You can spend the money, and that is exactly what this country has been doing. We set up a system of totally deregulated money markets and an enormous amount of our international debt is related simply to speculation in those foreign exchange markets. A lot of the wealth—I am talking about wealth, not cash—which is being exploited has simply been frittered away, it has been spent.

Conversely, you might decide to invest that wealth. What you should be doing with those non-renewable resources is making sure that you reinvest that money in capital assets that will have long-term value. You must recognise that with the human built environment there is an aggressive deterioration of most of those assets, whereas natural assets, when they are in the ground, tend to actually appreciate in value over time.

I turn now to the document that Senator Gareth Evans produced the other day, the ABS figures, which, I guess, Senator Campbell would say were produced by fairies at the bottom of the garden. The ABS has estimated the value of our non-renewable resources in the ground. The net present value of our subsoil assets is listed at $145 billion, a very interesting figure because, if it is right, it indicates that if we take all those resources out of the ground and cash them in they would not even pay the national debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which is a worry.

—Which is a great worry. However, the very important point I want to make here, which I also made yesterday, is that the ABS has estimated this value using a 7.5 per cent discount rate. In other words, it is saying that if we exploit those resources today, we might invest the money in the exploitation of some other resource, earn interest on that money and, in the process, increase our wealth, which is a false way of doing these sorts of sums.

PARA.TAB: The bigger the discount rate, the more effectively you are discounting the future. You are saying that a resource 10 years hence at a 7.5 per cent discount rate has no value whatsoever. In fact, with respect to most of these non-renewable resources and, indeed, many of the resources which are not counted by the ABS as resources—natural environments, clean air, clean water and so on—actually appreciate in value because of the increasing scarcity of those resources. If you are going to do the sums correctly you should be putting in a negative discount rate with respect to many of those resources.

So I have serious difficulty, not with the ABS attempting to do these sorts of sums—that is very creditable—but with the way in which it has attempted to carry out this study. By putting in discount rates they have almost guaranteed that they will come up with a silly answer. I am talking about doing proper accounts.

Finally, Senator Campbell talked about the cleaning up of the spill in Guyana. I point out to him that the cost of cleaning up that spill goes down as an addition to the gross domestic product of Guyana. That is another major failing in the way we keep our national accounts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, tonight I want to draw attention to the fact that in only nine days time the Earth Exchange Museum of Sydney will be closing its doors. I hope that anyone who is concerned about this and who lives in or near Sydney would recognise that they still have time—only nine days—in which to see this extraordinary, unique and impressive exhibition of mineral history.

PARA.TAB: It is to close because last month, only five days after confirming that it was going to provide funding for the financial year, the Carr state government broke yet another promise and withdraw its $1.35 million funding for the year. So the 31 full-time and 22 casual staff at the museum, which is the show piece of Australian mining and geology and has been for 120 years or so, will lose their jobs. The New South Wales Labor Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's assessment of the Earth Exchange is that it is poorly located, too small, too expensive and too specialised, and now faces terrific competition from other museums.

But the President of the Earth Exchange Museum Society, Mr Ray Beale, said that the museum attracted more than 100,000 visitors last year, a quarter of them students on formal education programs. I understand that many of the people visiting that museum are overseas visitors who are aware of the international status of this outstanding museum, which is part of our heritage but is now to be dismantled.

PARA.TAB: The Geological and Mining Museum, as it was originally known, started in the 1870s. It was revamped as the Earth Exchange Museum about 10 years ago by the Wran Labor government, which contributed $16.6 million to its $20 million refurbishment. At least the Wran government had some concern about Australia's heritage. The Carr Labor government clearly has no such concerns and this internationally renown resource is to be wiped out.

There is no doubt that it has been an expensive hobby for people to go to this museum anyway because of the low level of state government subsidy. A family of four have to pay $27 for entry to this museum—which, by the way, is also supported by the private sector, particularly the mining industry.

As I understand it, the New South Wales Labor government intends to relocate the mineral display, including the world renowned Albert Chapman collection—which was bought for way under its market value for $1 million about five years ago—at the Australian Museum. But the Australian Museum is already massively overcrowded. It simply does not have the space or the resources to adequately display this outstanding collection. I am concerned in those circumstances that this historic collection may be split up—parts sold and spread around—because of the limit on space not only in the Australian Museum's display areas but also in its storage areas. It would be absolutely disgraceful if this collection were to be split up.

In any event, I hope that in the remaining nine days many more people in Sydney will go to look at these exhibitions. They can rock with an earthquake, walk through a volcano, see an underground mine, find out how to save dollars on their energy bills, enjoy Australia's finest collection of minerals, and join in the fun of the earth explorer adventure for kids. This hands-on program will run until the museum closes on 29 September.

It is extraordinary that having survived for 120 years, including the Great Depression of the 1930s, apparently we can no longer afford this museum. Maybe it is true that people are worse off now, certainly in heritage terms, than people were then but it is extraordinary that, whereas all of the highly civilised and developed countries of the world have a quality museum devoted to the earth's mineral treasures, with special emphasis on unique and beautiful specimens, our only museum dedicated to showing the mineral treasures of our country, as well as other classic localities in the world, is now to be closed.

When I was a boy, admission was free—that might be why I so often visited it—and there was a very strong educational value in its mineral display. The Chapman collection, which I referred to earlier, is the result of a lifetime of work by a talented and dedicated individual, who was famous among mineral collectors the world over. Mineral collectors from all nations have been coming to Sydney to see and admire this collection.

The minerals on display can simply never be replaced. In most cases, they are the best examples of their kind ever found. They are rare and formed under unique conditions in nature. Such specimens simply cannot be reproduced artificially or found elsewhere. Surely there is a need to preserve our mineral heritage, and it should not be destroyed by a decision of one ill-informed government. This is really part of our heritage, including the building.

I am wondering whether the state government has another agenda here and whether, because this building is at the Rocks and in the centre of the tourism area, it might want to use it or lease it or sell it for some expensive tourist proposition—restaurants or a hotel or something like that—due to its location. I would have hoped that other factors than financial ones might have encouraged the state Labor government to have been concerned about its heritage, particularly as some of these specimens do need careful handling. Many are extremely fragile and delicate and must be protected from handling, particularly by inexperienced people. Even moving them around can be dangerous. Every time such specimens are relocated, they are subject to the danger of being damaged. The collection certainly, as I said earlier, needs to remain intact in recognition of Chapman's efforts.

Unfortunately, some other famous collections over the years have been split up and are certainly unavailable for regular visit. I must say that I am not quite certain what has happened to the old Bureau of Mineral Resources display. Many years ago, I worked in the department of national development. That BMR display was important and, to my knowledge, is not readily available to be seen at the moment. I think it was dedicated to some other part of the Commonwealth government. It may well, in fact, even be with the National Museum, which the federal Labor government now does not appear to be proceeding with despite, once again, a whole series of promises.

Although this Earth Exchange Museum is not to close until 29 September, a friend of mine has indicated that some of the specimens in the collection are no longer on show, and he wonders whether they have disappeared. For example, there is some scheelite from Nundle in New South Wales and there is scheelite from Wolfram Camp in North Queensland which he had seen on display before and which is not there now. It does seem that such a far-reaching decision to close this part of our heritage was taken on very short notice.

By the way, another comment made by my friend was that historic photographs of the Chapmans already seemed to have been removed from the display area when he was there. The display area is to be used for some kind of function, and I do not know to what extent that puts these things at risk either. The fact is that Australians do rely on governments to protect such rare and beautiful assets, and this government is letting Australia down.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was recently sent a most disturbing account of the Bengal famine of 1943-44. As a person born in India and a former community worker in Bangladesh, I found the account one which roused strong personal interest as well as outrage. It was made the more distressing because it sets out in considerable detail the clear responsibility of the British administration of the time for bringing about the famine and for that same administration's failure to respond appropriately and in a timely fashion.

PARA.TAB: Five million people have been estimated to have died through these famines that were raging in Bengal. The material sets out the ravages wrought by the colonial administration on the local social structures and disaster response capability. While the colonial administration had already compounded problems created by natural famines in the 19th century, the onset of World War II in 1942 made the situation even worse.

The document which I will seek leave to table in a moment was provided to me by Dr Gideon Maxwell Polya, and I am indebted to him for his work. The famine, he argues, was in fact not a shortage of food, but rather a diversion of food from the local population, particularly the rural people, in the effort to deny food stocks to the Japanese and to keep the war production effort going in the cities and in other parts of the British empire. Food was kept from the rural poor, and those who dared to try to make it to the cities were soon forcibly removed and left to starve.

It is estimated that between 3.5 and five million people perished—and this in a country which was exporting rice throughout this time. The famine shows the extent to which a colonial administration was prepared to rape a country to serve the home interests.

Dr Polya, whose family was largely wiped out in the 1943-44 famine, does not simply concern himself with the injustice, not to say outrage, perpetrated on the people of Bengal in the 1940s. He is also concerned that as global warming begins to exact its victims over the next decades the rich industrialised countries, like Australia, may see fit to leave countries like Bangladesh behind again in the rush to self-survival. He points out that the Berlin Climate Change Conference ended with no greenhouse gas emission targets—while each continues to produce far more than its per capita share of greenhouse gasses.
It may be that we have achieved a no-regrets policy for us, but other countries, especially low-lying ones like Bangladesh, may have much to regret because of our arrogance and selfishness.

I urge honourable senators to become acquainted with the horror of this famine and to give consideration to the new economic colonialism which the industrialised countries are visiting on the Third World. I seek leave to table the document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I came into the chamber earlier this evening with the intention of speaking in the adjournment debate in response to some matters referred to by Senator Chris Schacht, the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, who took the government's lead role in the matter of public importance debate this afternoon. However, I must say that when I came in here Senator Coulter leapt to his feet and started to suggest that I was not stupid, but I might be ignorant. As Forrest Gump says, `Stupid is as stupid does.' I do not claim to be particularly bright or anything else, but I do not think I am stupid.

PARA.TAB: The point I want to make is that I understand, from my relatively short time in this place, that if you are going, to use the colloquial term, to `drop a bucket on someone', or make the sorts of comments that Senator Coulter made tonight, it is polite to at least inform the person who is going to be referred to in such an exchange. You should do so to provide an opportunity for the other senator to either respond on that evening or at least to tune in so that that senator might have the chance to do so at a convenient time. I would suggest to Senator Coulter that I would have appreciated that.

It does not detract from the importance of the debate that he has raised in relation to a sensible way of accounting for the value of natural resources, be they renewable or non-renewable resources—be they things such as clean air, clean water or virgin forests. For example, although I disagree with much of the methodology of what Senator Coulter put forward in his contribution to this debate here tonight, I do in broad principle agree that if there is a way of placing sensible values on things such as those natural resources then they will be more properly used.

I think in a way, even though Senator Coulter may not admit it, he is supporting the concept of applying some free market principles to nature conservation. Only when you bring in some more sensible market orientated economics to manage natural resources will you get more sensible outcomes, which will ensure a balanced use of those natural resources for economic development and the benefits they provide to this generation, both in the conservation that those resources can produce in terms of climate—and Senator Chamarette has just raised a very fascinating example tonight—and also for future generations.

In relation to that section of the debate, I stand by the comments I made about the tailings dam catastrophe at Northparkes and the valuation of the assets. Clearly, any sort of assessment of the value of a commodity such as gold, any other commodity such as uranium and iron ore or any other precious mineral or natural resource under the ground depends entirely on the cost of extracting that resource from time to time and the value of that resource in the world market.

Clearly, it is very hard to place any sort of estimate on the value of minerals and resources in the ground unless you have a complete knowledge of what is in the ground. If a massive resource that can be recovered at low cost is suddenly discovered, that will affect the supply of that mineral, whether or not that mineral is precious, the value of it and therefore the value of it in the ground, let alone the cost of extracting it. So I am still a little bit wary about Senator Coulter's valuation methods. Nonetheless, I think there is great merit in this debate. But I encourage Senator Coulter to ensure that, when he wants to have this debate, he at least lets the other participant in it know that it is going on.

I wish to get back to the subject that I came into the chamber to debate, and that was to refute a numbers of matters that Senator Schacht raised during this afternoon's debate on youth issues. I think it was Senator Reynolds, as Acting Deputy President, who, with I think the guidance of a clerk, quite correctly ruled on my use of standing order 191 to correct a number of matters. Indeed, that advice and the Acting Deputy President's ruling were quite correct in that I was not correcting matters that I had said but correcting what the minister had said.

I wish to get back to the points I was making. During that debate Senator Schacht said that I was not prepared to go on Triple J and defend Senator Herron's comments and his attack on the quite sordid piece on anal sex contained in the infamous Cleo sex guide. On a number of occasions in front of the national press I have not only defended Senator John Herron's attack on that guide but indeed encouraged him to go further. I am quite proud that I have distributed across Western Australia petitions condemning the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) for putting her name to that guide and further condemning her for spending scarce taxpayers' funds on distributing it.

Most of the people who think that the Liberal Party is, by taking this attitude, against sex education tend to think that we are sort of prudish or something. I would always bow to Senator Herron's advice on the people in the high risk category of getting sexually transmitted diseases. Earlier this evening Senator Herron referred to a survey that had been done relating to some homeless kids in Melbourne. The statistics in relation to anal sex were very high amongst that survey's target group of something like 35 homeless kids in Melbourne.

During the youth bus tour, which I undertook a couple of weeks ago, I heard some horrendous tales about sexual intimidation that takes place amongst that sector of our society—that is, kids who are on the streets and who are desperate for money, food and shelter—and the way that many children in Australia are prostituting themselves for their basic needs of life. That is a target group that certainly needs sex education, but I must tell the minister that those kids do not have the money to buy Cleo and many of the target audience in Cleo are, I suspect, not the sort of people who need to know about that.

The final point I raise in the few seconds I have left is that the minister said that we chose to run the tour through marginal seats. The reality of the matter is that I do not know what the margins are in many of the seats that I visited, but I am informed that, if you take a bus from Sydney to Cairns, it is virtually impossible not to drive through an enormous number of marginal seats. Indeed, to put pay to the minister's attack that the tour was in marginal seats, I remind him that the tour kicked off in Wentworth, which is a safe Liberal seat. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 6 April 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Barry Arnold and Son (BAS) timber company in Tasmania and export woodchip licences:
(1) How long has BAS had an export woodchip licence and for what amounts each year.
(2) How much wood has BAS exported during that time as woodchips.
(3) What area of land has BAS cleared or has been cleared on behalf of BAS to supply BAS's export licence each year and in total.

(4) Has BAS complied with licence conditions applicable to all other Tasmanian woodchip licence holders, in particular, has BAS complied with the undertaking to regenerate 5 hectares for every 1,000 tonnes exported.
(5) Is there any proof that BAS has or has not complied totally with this condition.
(6) What is the Commonwealth obliged to do if BAS has not complied totally with this condition.
(7) During all periods of time BAS has had a licence, has it complied with all conditions.
(8) (a) Has BAS breached conditions at any time it has held an export woodchip licence.
(b) What are the full details of any breaches.
(c) What were the conditions each year.
(9) What is the Commonwealth doing to ensure BAS does not overrun its export quota.
(10) What monitoring systems are in place.
(11) Has or will the Commonwealth stop BAS cutting or producing chips for export; if so under what circumstances.
(12) If any company which has an export woodchip licence breaches licence conditions, will the Commonwealth either prosecute, take back that licence and/or refuse future licences.
(13) Under what conditions would a company have its licence rescinded or be prosecuted.
(14) Under what conditions would a company be refused an export licence.
(15) Will BAS be licensed to continue exporting woodchips past March 1995.
(16) Who is responsible for checking on the company's export operations and State logging operations.
(17) What are Federal Police seeking with reference to BAS.
(18) Does the company Taiwan Pulp and Paper (TPP) have a contract for up to 300,000 tonnes per year from BAS and is TPP investigating the feasibility of building a pulp mill in northern Tasmania.
(19) What incentives will the Federal Government use to ensure that the wood used in any such mill would be totally sourced from plantations.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Barry E Arnold and Sons (BAS) have held several export licences since December 1991, some of which were not used either in part or total and were replaced by new licences. A breakdown of BAS, licences is as follows:
1991—MEPWOOD 698 issued for 60,000 tonnes
1992—MEPWOOD 736 issued for 60,000 tonnes
1993—MEPWOOD 783 issued for 60,000 tonnes; MEPWOOD 836 issued for 37,000 tonnes
1994—MEPWOOD 938 issued for 40,000 tonnes; MEPWOOD 975 issued for 26,000 tonnes
(2) In 1993 BAS shipped 63,000 tonnes of woodchips. In 1994 BAS shipped 101,000 tonnes.

(3) While the Department of Primary Industries and Energy receives locations of properties on which operations may take place, these do not generally quantify the net area subject to such operations, nor do they detail treatment of the land following the operations. In some cases the operations are used as a tool to `clear' land for future agricultural purposes, but in other cases the land is not `cleared'. For example, it is either selectively logged (and thus remains forest) or regenerated.

Given this and the variety of sources from which BAS sources woodchips such as sawmill residues, thinnings, logging residues and salvage operations, it would be difficult to attempt to calculate the exact areas `cleared' as a result of BAS' operations.

(4) The export licences previously held by BAS contained conditions which are similar to all other exporters including requirements relating to forest practices. Additionally, export licences granted to Tasmanian exporters include conditions reflecting agreements between the Commonwealth and Tasmania on forest issues.

In respect of conditions relating to forest practices, my Department has been advised that legal action has been initiated by the Forests Practices Board of Tasmania in relation to possible forest practices breaches by BAS. Until the outcomes of that legal action are known, the Government is not in a position to comment on BAS' adherence to conditions relating to forest practices.

Consistent with the 1986 Memorandum of Understanding between the Commonwealth and Tasmanian Governments BAS's recently expired export licences contained provisions concerning regeneration of private land logged for the purpose of export woodchips. For example, under licence Mepwood 975 BAS was required under Clause 11 (a) to regenerate such land at a minimum rate of four hectares per 1,000 tonnes of pulpwood extracted.

Clause 11 (b) provided that BAS shall, as soon as practicable after 18 March 1995, establish a minimum plantation area in the State of Tasmania, calculated at the rate of one hectare for each 1,000 tonnes of pulpwood that has been extracted from private land by the exporter for export as woodchips in accordance with his licence. This can only be waived if BAS is unable to comply with the requirement due to circumstances beyond its control and if it has agreed to make corresponding arrangements, not less onerous, for example regeneration in another FORWOOD Zone. These arrangements would need to be approved by my Department and Private Forestry Tasmania.

In addition Clause 11(c) provided that BAS must, as soon as practicable after 7 March 1995, provide my Department with, amongst other things, particulars of the location and area of land regenerated and planted in compliance with these conditions. BAS has now provided this report and it has been provided to Private Forestry Tasmania to enable verification by field inspection.
(5) See my answer to question (4).

(6) The Commonwealth is not obliged to take any action, but it has to consider what actions may be relevant if any exporter fails to meet a licence condition. A range of legal measures are available to me as outlined in sections 8 and 9 of the Export Control Act 1982 and Regulations 14 and 15 of the Export Control (Unprocessed Wood) Regulations. These measures include instituting proceedings for offences against section 8 and 9 of the Act, suspension or revocation of a licence or, where relevant, the forfeiture of goods which are the subject of the licence. Whether any of these measures would be appropriate would depend on the circumstances of the case.

(7) It appears that BAS may have shipped a load of woodchips (approximately 34,000 tonnes) in excess of volumes for which it had an export licence. This matter has been investigated by the Australian Federal Police. The AFP have now provided a report to the Australian Government Solicitor. As indicated in my answer to Question (4) legal proceedings have been initiated by the Forests Practices Board of Tasmania in relation to possible forestry practice breaches by BAS.
(8) See my answer to Question (7).

(9) Each export licence specifies a woodchip volume. The Australian Customs Service maintains data on woodchip volumes exported and my Department has access to this data. In addition, the Commonwealth Government announced in the 1995-96 budget context that it would be establishing a new unit within my Department to monitor compliance with export licence conditions. This will further strengthen existing arrangements.
If BAS does exceed licence volumes there are a range of legal measures the Commonwealth can pursue, as indicated in my answer to Question (6).

(10) See my answer to Question (9) concerning monitoring of export volumes. In addition, Tasmanian forestry agencies are responsible for monitoring of compliance with woodchip export licence conditions and other obligations under the 1986 Memorandum of Understanding between the Commonwealth and Tasmanian Governments. Export licences also now include a provision requiring the licence holder provide a report to my Department on their compliance with licence conditions.

(11) While the Commonwealth cannot prevent the cutting or production of woodchips, I can refuse to grant a licence to export those woodchips under the Export Control Act 1982. On 18 April 1995 and 7 August 1995 1 refused to grant woodchip export licences to BAS.
(12) If a company is found to have breached its licence a range of legal measures are available to me as outlined in my answer to question (6).

(13) Regulations 14 and 15 of the Export Control (Unprocessed Wood) Regulations set out the circumstances in which I can suspend or revoke a licence. For example, where I have reasonable grounds to believe that the holder of a licence has not complied with a condition or restriction and by reason of such non-compliance, damage, degradation or disruption of the environment has occurred or there is an imminent threat that it would occur, I may suspend the licence, vary the conditions or impose additional conditions upon the licence.

(14) In making a decision on whether I will grant or refuse an export licence I may take account of a number of relevant considerations, such as past performance of the company, if any, and any failure to demonstrate the ability to meet licence conditions.

(15) As at 28 August 1995 BAS does not have a valid woodchip export licence. On 18 April 1995 and 7 August 1995 1 decided to refuse to grant export licences to BAS to export a total of 80,000 tonnes of woodchips.
(16) State forest agencies are responsible for monitoring State logging operations under State statutes. The Commonwealth in conjunction with State agencies monitors export licence compliance.
(17) See my answer to question 7.

(18) The first part of the question raises commercial-in-confidence issues upon which I would not wish to comment. I can advise that TPPC is investigating the feasibility of value adding in northern Tasmania.

(19) The Prime Minister, in his statement of 22 December 1994 on woodchip exports, indicated that the Government would consider helping industry make the transition to greater use and development of plantation and regrowth timbers. While the Federal Government is encouraging an expansion in plantation establishment, it would be a matter of commercial judgement for a new pulpmill proponent, potential suppliers to the mill and the State Government as to whether to source wood requirements from native forests or plantations or a mix of both.

The Federal Government is continuing to facilitate commercial plantation development on cleared agricultural land through the Farm Forestry Program and the North Queensland Community Rainforest Reforestation Program.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 8 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why did the department undertake the `payment of legal agent's fees for unemployed client to sell/buy house to take up permanent work', at a cost of $2 031, through Area North, Broken Hill region.
(2) What was the total cost of this transaction.
(3) How often does this happen.
(4) What legislation or regulation allows the department to intervene or assist with this type of payment.

(5) Across Australia, how often has the Department assisted an unemployed client to sell/buy house to take up permanent work in each of the 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years and the 1995-96 financial year to date.
(6) What is the total cost per financial year listed above.
(7) Why is this deemed a necessary form of assistance.
(8) What is the departmental policy in relation to this issue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Under the Relocation Assistance provisions of the Mobility Assistance Scheme the Commonwealth Employment Service helps eligible jobseekers with some of the relocation costs involved in taking up the offer of permanent employment in another location. These costs may include legal and agents' fees associated with the sale and/or purchase of the jobseeker's home. Assistance is provided only if the person is unable to find work where he/she is living and the position cannot be filled by an unemployed person already living in the area of the vacancy.

Relocation Assistance is considered to be an important element of structural adjustment of the labour market because it facilitates the movement of workers to meet the skill needs of employers located elsewhere and helps meet labour shortages. If assistance was not available to help jobseekers with the costs of selling/buying their homes, a large number of relocations that would be of benefit to the community would not occur. The benefit to the community is derived from having an otherwise vacant job filled and the savings in Government income support.

Where approval is granted for Relocation Assistance, a funding limit applies to each jobseeker that is determined by the number of dependants. In this instance the jobseeker was eligible for assistance totalling $6 000. This amount included a re-establishment grant and removal costs as well as $2 031 for legal and agents' fees.

(4) The Mobility Assistance Scheme is one of the Government's Labour Market Programs administered by the Department of Employment, Education and Training. The Department has comprehensive guidelines setting out the rules for administration of the program.
