TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, upon notice on, 15 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the first date on which the Australian Federal Police (AFP) briefed the United States Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) on matters relating to the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission (CJC) investigation, Operation Wallah and the AFP's Operation Gallon.
(2)(a) Who provided this briefing to the FBI; (b) how did this briefing take place; and (c) to whom was this briefing given.
(3)(a) What was the first date on which the CJC requested the AFP to brief the FBI; and (b) to whom was this request made.

(4)(a) What were the dates of all subsequent briefings that have occurred between the AFP and the FBI on the matters relating to Operation Wallah and Operation Gallon; and (b) who undertook these briefings on behalf of the AFP.

(5) Did the AFP provide any advice to the CJC that it had briefed the FBI on matters relating to Operation Wallah and Operation Gallon as requested by the CJC; if so, to whom was this advice given and on what date did this occur.

(6) During the course of these briefings by the AFP to the FBI, was the FBI advised by the AFP about the possibility of organised crime involvement in the semi-conductor trade as identified in Operation Wallah; if not, why not.
(7) Is the AFP presently conducting any inquiries into any events surrounding Operation Wallah and Operation Gallon.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) 20 December 1994.
(2)(a) Acting Commander E Tyrie; (b) orally at the FBI Legal Attache's Office, United States Embassy, Canberra; (c) Assistant FBI Legal Attache Stephen J Ramey.

(3)(a) and (b) When Acting Commander Tyrie was briefed by the CJC on 2 November 1994 he was made aware of prior briefings made by the CJC to the FBI Legal Attache, and that an invitation had been extended to the CJC to travel to the USA for the purpose of providing briefings to US authorities. After the meeting with the FBI Legal Attache on 20 December 1994 and being satisfied that the US authorities were adequately briefed on the issues, which was confirmed in subsequent meetings between the AFP and the FBI Legal Attache's office, the AFP was of the view that any briefing on issues affecting the Commonwealth was a matter for federal agencies to consider and would be premature until a substantive assessment of the allegations made by the CJC had been conducted.

The AFP subsequently advised the CJC that should a decision be made by the CJC to brief the US authorities prior to an assessment of Commonwealth matters being available, then that was a matter for the CJC to consider. The AFP advised the CJC that there were no objections to the CJC responding to the FBI's request. It is understood that the CJC has not subsequently acted upon the invitation.

(4)(a) and (b) Subsequent meetings between the AFP and FBI representatives took place on 6 February 1995 involving Acting Assistant Commissioner Schramm and Acting Commander Tyrie; on 22 February 1995 involving Acting Assistant Commissioner Schramm and Acting Commander Tyrie; and on 1 March 1995 involving Acting Assistant Commissioner Schramm.

(5) At a meeting on 22 December 1994 between Acting Commander Tyrie and Messrs Pearce and McGrath of the CJC together with representatives of the Australian Customs Service it was agreed that the US authorities would continue to be kept abreast of developments through their Canberra based legal attache. This advice was confirmed in a letter to the CJC on 13 January 1995 by Assistant Commissioner Mills of the AFP.

(6) It has been disclosed in evidence before the Hanson Inquiry into the unlawful disclosure of confidential information that the CJC had provided information and communicated on numerous occasions with the FBI prior to the AFP being briefed on these matters. I am advised that CJC briefings included background on the possibility of organised crime involvement in Operation Wallah. Acting Commander Tyrie was satisfied as a result of his meeting with Mr Ramey on 20 December 1994 that the US authorities had been adequately briefed.

It has subsequently been revealed there was no organised crime involvement in the semi-conductor trade and no offences against Commonwealth law have been disclosed as a result of the AFP's investigation. US Customs have advised that no offences have been committed against US law.

(7) Yes. There are two peripheral matters concerning possible passport offences and allegations of impropriety concerning an employee of the Department of Defence. There is no other current investigation of matters relating to Operation Gallon however, should other credible information come to light that investigation could be re-opened.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 7 June 1995 (Hansard page 979) Senator Margetts asked me a question without notice as to why the Industry Commission's assessment of the growth and revenue implications of the Hilmer and related reforms should be believed. Senator Margetts also asked who in the Government or bureaucracy is able to undertake cost-benefit studies of potential reforms and where the resources to undertake these studies would come from.

PARA.TAB: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

On 19 August 1994, the Council of Australian Governments asked the Industry Commission, considered to have expertise in conducting large-scale econometric analyses, to undertake an assessment of the growth and revenue implications of the Hilmer and related reforms. The Commission chose the ORANI model of the Australian economy for this exercise and made modifications to simulate the impact of these reforms.

ORANI is a multisectoral model and is able to provide information at the Federal/State level as well as for several industries. The analysis takes the Australian economy in 1993-94 as the base and compares this with the economy assuming the Hilmer and related reforms have been implemented. The estimate does not include any potential dynamic growth benefits engendered by the more competitive environment.

It is important to emphasise that the reported increase in the size of the economy is an estimate. Models are not able to capture all the factors at work in analysing a particular set of issues. Furthermore, due to the approximate nature of models and the difficulty in quantifying particular policy changes, assumptions have to be made. In recognition of these limitations, the Commission in the preface of their published report state that "it is clear that no single number can be produced to capture accurately the full benefits and costs of these reforms . . . [t]he best they [technical modelling exercises] can do is provide general indications of the direction and magnitude of the benefits that flow from these reforms of different sectors of Australian society".

The Commission have sought to make assumptions, approximations, workings and limitations of the model simulations clear and transparent. Consequently, there will be criticism over the model used for the simulations and assumptions made in conducting the analysis. However, the Commonwealth Government is confident that, consistent with the Commission's findings, the benefits from Hilmer and related reforms are substantial. As a result, the Commonwealth has subsequently committed itself financially to rewarding jurisdictions that implement the relevant reforms.

With respect to the process of undertaking cost-benefit studies of potential Hilmer and related reforms, this should be seen as a normal part of the evaluation process in Commonwealth departments and agencies. Cost-benefit analysis using quantitative and/or qualitative assessments are a requirement for new policy proposals. The decision as to whether such studies can be done `inhouse' or contracted out to external consultants is appropriately a matter for department/agency heads. Regardless of this decision, the intention of the Competition Principles Agreement is to provide guidance in terms of the key issues that should be addressed when governments undertake reviews, for example, concerning anti-competitive regulation and reform of public monopolies.

By way of example, the Department of Communications and Arts has recently undertaken a major review in the context of the development of the Government's post-1997 telecommunications policy, which includes the facilitation of greater competition in that sector.

The Industry Commission itself has developed expertise across a range of industries and may also be asked to conduct sectoral reviews. For example, in March 1995, the Commission reported on the implications of recent developments in the Australian gas industry for the enhancement of competition in the production, distribution and use of gas. (This study assisted the Trade Practices Commission (TPC) in its review of an authorisation granted to the Australian Gas Light Company in 1986 covering its gas marketing arrangements with Cooper Basin gas producers. The original authorisation was granted following an assessment of the public benefit.)

The competition policy reforms will result in the creation of two new national competition institutions, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC), formed out of a merger of the TPC and PSA, and the National Competition Council (NCC). It is intended that the NCC will conduct, or provide assistance with reviews under the Competition Principles Agreement, such as concerning structural reform of public monopolies. The reviews it undertakes will be in accordance with a work program determined by Commonwealth and State/Territory Governments.

The ACCC will have the expertise to undertake reviews of anti-competitive regulation. For example, the TPC prepared a submission to the Industry Commission's 1994 Urban Transport inquiry assessing the effects of regulation of the taxi industry. In March 1994, it published a study report on competition and regulation in the legal profession, which followed reports of a similar nature on the accountancy and architecture professions, published in July and September 1992 respectively.

The Office of Regulation Review (ORR) is responsible for administering the Government's regulation review policy, including examining and advising on proposals of new or amended business regulation. As part of its Working Nation statement, the Government announced a business regulation reform package designed to reduce the cost to business of Commonwealth regulation. In meeting its commitments under the Competition Principles Agreement and Working Nation statement, all Commonwealth portfolios will be required to prepare a draft schedule of all regulation administered in their portfolio which confers costs and/or benefits on business or which restricts competition. The ORR will assess the review schedules prepared by departments/agencies and provide advice to the Government in the context of the development of a four year regulation review timetable.

A Council on Business Regulation has been established to advise the Government on review priorities and on reform of regulation required to ensure that regulations are serving the public interest. The Chairman of the Industry Commission will chair the Council, he will be joined by another eight prominent people representing business and community interests.

The resources to undertake cost-benefit studies will be met from portfolios' budget allocations. In some cases, this may require funds to be re-allocated to evaluation processes or require a re-ordering of evaluation priorities. Again, this is appropriately a decision for department/agency heads. Portfolios will also be able to draw on the expertise of the various research bureaux, such as the Bureau of Industry Economics.

The NCC and ACCC will be fully funded by the Commonwealth. Furthermore, as part of the national competition policy reforms, the Government has provided significant extra resources for the ACCC and some will be available to make further assessments of micro reforms at the industry level. In addition, the ORR was provided with additional resources as part of the Working Nation statement to assist it advise departments on regulation assessment and review techniques, including cost-benefit analysis.

ANSWER.PARA: Licence number: MEPWOOD 975
LICENCE TO EXPORT UNPROCESSED WOOD
(COMMONWEALTH EXPORT CONTROL ACT 1982)

PARA.TAB: I, DAVID BEDDALL, Minister for Resources, acting pursuant to Regulation 8 of the Export Control (Unprocessed Wood) Regulations, hereby grant BARRY E. ARNOLD & SONS a licence to export HARDWOOD WOODCHIPS during the period commencing on 13 MAY 1994 and ending on 8 MARCH 1995.

ANSWER.PARA: Pursuant to Regulation 9 of the Export Control (Unprocessed Wood) Regulations, this licence is subject to the conditions and restrictions specified below.
Signed D Beddall Date
DEFINITIONS
1In this licence:
"the exporter" means Barry E. Arnold & Sons, of Lilydale, Tasmania, or any other person or company acting by, or on behalf of, or under the authority of, Barry E. Arnold & Sons;
"the Department" means the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industries and Energy;
"the Minister" means the Commonwealth Minister for Resources;

"the Memorandum of Understanding" means the Commonwealth/State Memorandum of Understanding on Tasmanian Woodchip Exports dated 12 June 1986, a copy of which has been formally provided to the exporter;
"cool temperate rainforest" means rainforest as defined by S.J. Jarman and M.J. Brown in Search Vol. 14, 3-4, April/May 1983;
"sawmill residues" means waste material resulting from sawn timber production, consisting of slabs, offcuts, dockings and boxed hearts rejected in normal sawmilling operations.
PRICING

2(a)The exporter shall not export woodchips under this licence except for the purpose of fulfilling a contract of sale in relation to those woodchips between the exporter and an overseas buyer, being a contract that has been approved by the Department.
(b)A minimum price unit f.o.b. applies to all hardwood woodchips exported under this licence.
EXPORT LIMITATIONS
3(a)The exporter shall not export woodchips under this licence from any place other than the port of Bell Bay in the State of Tasmania without the prior approval of the Minister.
(b)The quantity of woodchips exported under this licence shall not exceed 26,000 green tonnes in total.
(c)The exporter must obtain all relevant State and local government approvals, including in relation to port facilities, before commencing exports under this licence.
(d)The exporter must comply with the requirements of the Tasmanian Forest Practices Code and all other requirements of the Tasmanian Government and all relevant local authorities.
INSPECTION

4The exporter shall take all steps within its power to facilitate the inspection by officers of the Department or of the Tasmanian Forestry Commission of any area (whether on Crown or private land) where the exporter is carrying out operations connected with the export of woodchips under this licence.
SOURCE MATERIAL

5(a)Source material for the production of woodchips for export under this licence shall be limited to pulpwood obtained from Crown and private lands, and sawmill residues, obtained in the State of Tasmania.

(b)All hardwood woodchips exported under this licence must be produced from sawmill residues, from the heads, limbs and butts of trees felled for sawlogs, but found to be faulty or from trees felled as part of silvicultural operations approved by the Tasmanian Government.
(c)The exporter shall, in extracting pulpwood for export as woodchips under this licence, give preference to timber from the following sources:

PARA.TAB: (i)pulpwood produced from approved sawlog operations (selection harvesting and clearfelling);
(ii)silvicultural operations (eg thinning, overwood removal) to enhance sawlog production;
(iii)sawmill residues;
(iv)regeneration of understocked stands for future sawlog production;
(v)salvage (eg fire, pests, diseases, construction activities); and
(vi)plantation establishment (for sawlog trials and pulpwood).

(d)The exporter shall not carry out logging of pulpwood intended for export as woodchips in, or export woodchips produced from logs removed from, an area which has been entered on the Register of the National Estate or placed on the interim list of the Register of the National Estate unless the exporter has received prior written notice from the Minister or the Department that logging can take place in that particular area.

(e)Until an environmental impact statement on logging of rainforest for woodchip exports has been duly dealt with in accordance with the Administrative Procedures of the Commonwealth Environment Protection (impact of Proposals) Act 1974, the exporter shall not extract pulpwood for export as woodchips from any Crown cool temperate rainforest unless:
(i)the extractive operations take place in an area of such rainforest of less than 10 hectares in size contained within a designated harvesting coupe of predominantly eucalypt forest; and
(ii)the operations occur concurrently with harvesting operations in the surrounding predominantly eucalypt forest.
(f)The exporter shall not export woodchips derived from regrowth pulp logs for which it can be demonstrated that there is an economic demand for their use in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: ENVIRONMENT PROTECTION

6(a)Subject to Clause 7, the exporter shall ensure that all logging operations on any Crown land for the purpose of obtaining wood for export in accordance with this licence are carried out in accordance with such plan of management as is prepared or approved by the Tasmanian Forestry Commission, and the forest practices of the exporter shall be in accordance with the Tasmanian Forest Practices Code.
(b)Subject to Clause 7, the exporter shall, in respect of logging operations on any private land for the purpose of obtaining wood for export in accordance with this licence:

PARA.TAB: (i)ensure that all operations are conducted in accordance with the Tasmanian Forest Practices Code and that the results of pre-logging surveys are supplied at the request of the Department;
(ii)plan and supervise those logging operations on that land so as take account of soil, water or other special values; and

(iii)carry out those logging operations in accordance with such logging operations standards prepared by the Tasmanian Forestry Commission as are in force at any time during the period of this licence.

(c)The exporter shall ensure that any of its operations conducted in association with activities approved under this licence do not threaten with extinction, or significantly impede the recovery of, a native species listed in Schedule 1 or an ecological community listed in Schedule 2 of the Endangered Species Protection Act 1992.

ANSWER.PARA: 7In the event of disagreement between the Tasmanian Forestry Commission and the Department over the effectiveness of particular forest practices guidelines and logging operations standards ensuring environmental protection on Crown and private land, the Tasmanian Minister for Forests and the Minister shall discuss the problem with the intent of reaching a mutually acceptable solution in accordance with the Memorandum of Understanding. In the event those ministers are unable to resolve the matter through such discussions, the exporter shall plan its export logging operations on private land and carry out its export logging operations on Crown and private land in accordance with requirements specified by the Minister and in accordance with requirements Specified by the Minister.

8The exporter shall conduct its operations under this licence in accordance with the statement entitled "Environmental Impact Statement on Tasmanian woodchip exports beyond 1988" and the supplement to that statement in accordance with the relevant provisions of the Memorandum of Understanding and the Appendix to the Memorandum.
OTHER

9(a)The exporter shall comply with the terms of any written agreement made between the Commonwealth and the State of Tasmania in relation to the funding of research in connection with woodchips or logging.

(b)The exporter shall co-operate with the Department in developing research proposals and shall, if requested by the Minister or the Department, undertake or have undertaken such research projects relevant to its operations under the licence as are specified in the request and provide the Minister or the Department as the case requires, with a report setting out the results of that research and containing advice of any action that has been taken as a consequence of those results.

10The exporter shall, if requested by the Department, carry out a study of the feasibility of establishing facilities for the further processing in Australia of resources available to the exporter for export as woodchips under this licence and submit the results of that study to the Department within such reasonable time as is specified in the request.

11(a)Where the exporter extracts pulpwood from private land in a "FORWOOD" zone for export as woodchips in accordance with this licence, the exporter shall ensure the regeneration of a minimum area of that land calculated at the rate of four hectares for each 1,000 tonnes of conventional pulpwood so extracted.

11(b)The exporter shall, as soon as practicable after 18 March 1995, establish a minimum plantation area in the State of Tasmania, calculated at the rate of one hectare for each 1,000 tonnes of conventional pulpwood that

TAB.TAB: has been extracted from private land by the exporter for export as woodchips in accordance with this licence. The Minister may, at therequest of the exporter, waive compliance with this condition by the exporter if, and only if, the Minister is satisfied that:

PARA.TAB: (i)the exporter is unable to comply with the requirement due to circumstances beyond its control; and

(ii)the exporter has agreed to make corresponding arrangements, not less onerous, for example, regeneration in another "FORWOOD" zone, and those arrangements have been approved by the Department and the Tasmanian Forestry Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: (c)The exporter shall, as soon as practicable after 7 March 1995, provide the Department with particulars of the volume of pulpwood extracted by the exporter from private land for the purposes of export in accordance with this licence, and of the location and area of land regenerated and planted in compliance with these conditions.
